headline: Israel Detains 2 In Burial Alive Of Palestinians
abstract: LEAD: The Israeli Army said today that it had opened an investigation into reports that its troops had buried four young Palestinians alive. It said that it had detained two soldiers and that it expected to detain others.

headline: KEY RATES
abstract: LEAD:               Previous   Year     In percent   Yesterday   Day   Ago              PRIME RATE   8.50   8.50   7.50        DISCOUNT RATE   6.00   6.00   5.50        FEDERAL FUNDS   6.54   6.64   6.23        3-MO. TREAS. BILLS   5.74   5.79   5.61        6-MO. TREAS. BILLS   6.04   6.04   5.73        7-YR. TREAS. NOTES   8.33   8.41   7.31        30-YR.

headline: Malay Party Ruled Illegal, Spurring Conflicts
abstract: LEAD: The political party that has headed every Malaysian Government since independence in 1957 was ruled illegal last week by a Malaysian judge because some of its branches were improperly registered. The unexpected ruling is likely to pose political, legal and possibly financial problems for Prime Minister Mahathir Mohamad and the party, the United Malays National Organization.

headline: I.B.M. Net Rises 50.4% In Quarter
abstract: LEAD: In a long-awaited and somewhat muted rebound, the International Business Machines Corporation said yesterday that its fourth-quarter net income rose 50.4 percent, to $2.09 billion, after a year of cost-cutting measures that John F. Akers, the company's chairman, declared ''are beginning to pay off.

headline: 'Woo 'em or Lose 'em' to Local Delis
abstract: LEAD: THE EASTMAN KODAK COMPANY has the nation's largest self-operated food service for its employees. At its Rochester headquarters, 45,000 employees frequent 56 dining areas and use 1,300 vending machines.

headline: Factory Orders Fall By 0.8%
abstract: LEAD: Orders to American factories for manufactured goods fell for the second consecutive month in February, the Commerce Department reported today, but analysts said the decline of eight-tenths of 1 percent was not a cause for alarm.

headline: Standard Endorses Kelso Bid
abstract: LEAD: After a two-month battle to preserve its independence, American Standard Inc. yesterday accepted a takeover offer of $78 a share, or slightly more than $2.5 billion in cash, from the small Manhattan investment house Kelso & Company.

headline: A Nutrasweet Product Is Due
abstract: LEAD: The Nutrasweet Company is planning to announce the development of a fat substitute that could reduce calories and cholesterol in many foods, according to a report published in Crain's Chicago Business, a weekly publication. The company declined to comment, but a spokesman said Nutrasweet had scheduled a news conference in New York on Jan.

headline: Keycorp Buys A Utah Bank
abstract: LEAD: Keycorp of Albany has acquired the Commercial Security Bancorpation of Salt Lake City, according to officials of both companies.

headline: Isolated Afghan Refugee Camp Life Turns Women Into 'Birds in a Cage'
abstract: LEAD: ''We never ask the women,'' Sultan Mohammad said indignantly.

headline: Panel Sees Abuse in Phone Bids
abstract: LEAD: A Senate committee said yesterday that it had evidence that an official of the General Services Administration had passed secret bid information to at least two competing telephone companies.

headline: EAST BERLIN FREES ITS RIGHTS LEADERS
abstract: LEAD: Leading members of East Germany's fledgling human rights movement were released from prison today, and they left for West Germany, possibly against their will.

headline: Bonds Fall Sharply on Job Report
abstract: LEAD: Bond prices tumbled yesterday after the Labor Department reported an unexpectedly large increase in the nation's employment for February.

headline: House Roll-Call on Contra Aid
abstract: LEAD: Following is the roll-call vote of 345 to 70 by which the House of Representatives today approved a $47.9 million package of assistance to the Nicaraguan rebels. A ''yes'' vote was a vote in favor of the aid; a ''no'' was a vote against it. Voting ''yes'' were 179 Democrats and 166 Republicans. Voting ''no'' were 65 Democrats and 5 Republicans.

headline: Shift in Gulf Battlefronts; Widening War on the Cities and Shipping Reflects a Desire for Diplomatic Advantage
abstract: LEAD: In sharp contrast to recent practice, the Iran-Iraq war has become focused on offensives far from the major battlefronts on land that Teheran views as decisive in determining the eventual victor.

headline: S.E.C. Details Canada Accord
abstract: LEAD: The Securities and Exchange Commission and its Canadian counterparts today set up a framework for close cooperation in an effort to stem a broad range of cross-border violations of securities laws.

headline: Sandinistas Begin Talks With Indian Rebels
abstract: LEAD: The Sandinista Government opened formal peace talks today with Miskito Indian leaders who have been waging a sporadic anti-Sandinista war for seven years.

headline: Campeau, May in Deal on Federated
abstract: LEAD: The Macy-Campeau tussle for Federated Department Stores Inc. continued yesterday, while one of the rivals took steps to cash in.

headline: Timbuktu Journal; Sadly, Desert Nomads Cultivate Their Garden
abstract: LEAD: Mohammed Ag Mahamoud, a descendant of the fierce Tuaregs once called lords of the desert, crouched behind a sand dune and weeded his carrots.

headline: Fast Start for Bioengineered Drug
abstract: LEAD: At Williamsport Hospital and Medical Center in Pennsylvania, a special committee is supposed to decide whether the hospital's pharmacy will carry a particular drug, and the process can take several weeks. But when Genentech Inc.'s heart attack drug came out in November, hospital officials eager to get their hands on it bypassed the committee and placed an order immediately.

headline: Gain for Texas Instruments
abstract: LEAD: Texas Instruments Inc., the nation's largest maker of computer chips, said today that it had posted the most profitable quarter in its history.

headline: Judge Blocks Owens's Acquisition of Brockway
abstract: LEAD: A Federal judge in Washington yesterday temporarily blocked the $750 million proposed acquisition of Brockway Inc. by Owens-Illinois Inc., as the Federal Trade Commission had requested.

headline: C.I.A. Official Who Administered Contra Aid Program Quits Agency
abstract: LEAD: Alan M. Fiers, the Central Intelligence Agency official who was in charge of aiding the Nicaraguan rebels and who was reprimanded in the wake of the Iran-contra affair, has resigned from the agency.

headline: NEC Challenges Intel Copyrights
abstract: LEAD: The NEC Corporation and its California subsidiary asked a Federal judge to rule that the Intel Corporation had forfeited the copyrights it claims for the powerful and widely used 8086 and 8088 microprocessors. The action by NEC of Tokyo and NEC Electronics Inc., based in Mountain View, Calif., is the latest salvo in a two-and-a-half-year battle with Intel over the microprocessors.

headline: People
abstract: LEAD: * Clark Hine, formerly of D'Arcy Masius Benton & Bowles, Chicago, joining Quaker Oats U.S. Grocery Products as vice president, advertising.

headline: BRIEFS
abstract: LEAD: * Aetna Life and Casualty Co., Hartford, said it had introduced liability insurance policies for independent corporate directors.

headline: Singer Funds For Bilzerian
abstract: LEAD: Paul A. Bilzerian, the Florida investor whose bid to take over the Singer Company has been accepted by company executives, said yesterday that he had obtained about $505 million in financing for his offer.

headline: Saudis Plan Refining of Oil Abroad
abstract: LEAD: Fifty years after it first discovered oil, Saudi Arabia is setting out to establish its own marketing and refining network abroad, primarily in the United States and Western Europe.

headline: Cloning Brings Factory Precision to the Farm
abstract: LEAD: A new and powerful biological technology that enables livestock breeders to clone large numbers of identical animals from a single embryo is nearing commercial application in the United States and Canada.

headline: JAPANESE-HELD U.S. BANK PLANS ACQUISITION
abstract: LEAD: In a bid to bolster its position as a business lender, the California First Bank said today that it had agreed to acquire the much larger Union Bank, a subsidiary of Standard Chartered P.L.C., for $750 million.

headline: Brockway Bid Cleared
abstract: LEAD: Owens-Illinois Inc. has won another victory in its attempt to purchase Brockway Inc., another glass maker. The company said that the Court of Appeals in Washington on Friday unanimously denied the Federal Trade Commission's motion to block the merger.

headline: Jersey Utility Agency Bonds
abstract: LEAD: The Bergen County Utility Authority in New Jersey is tentatively offering $139 million of solid waste system revenue bonds with a top yield of 7.795 percent for those due in 2013 through underwriters led by J. B. Hanauer & Company.

headline: Economic Scene; A Little Daylight On the Deficits
abstract: LEAD: VIRTUE is nice, but sometimes luck will suffice: Four months and much hand-wringing after the October crash, the United States economy seems no worse for wear. In fact, there is growing reason to think that the stock plunge may actually protect the nation from a dollar crisis that would cut deeply into income and employment.

headline: Market Place; Raising Margins On Index Futures
abstract: LEAD: TO Chicago's futures industry, the most controversial proposal contained in the Presidential panel's report on the October market collapse is that margins should be made consistent across markets as a way to avoid another stock market free fall.

headline: Wine Makers Divided on How to Fight Curbs
abstract: LEAD: As efforts to curb wine consumption gain momentum, American vintners are widely divided about how to combat the movement.

headline: The New Math for Joining a 401(k) Plan
abstract: LEAD: NOW that the stock market has recovered somewhat from its recent rout, shaken investors are reassessing their long-term finances. Those who are counting on investment earnings to fund their retirement may find new appeal in 401(k) employee retirement plans, especially because the new tax law now prevents many people from making tax-deductible contributions to Individual Retirement

headline: A Civilian President Named in Suriname To End Army Rule
abstract: LEAD: The National Assembly elected a civilian President today, paving the way for a return to democracy after seven years of military rule.

headline: Shultz Plans Arms Focus in Moscow
abstract: LEAD: Secretary of State George P. Shultz said today that he and Soviet leaders would try to ''energize'' their sluggish negotiations on a strategic arms treaty when he holds talks in Moscow Sunday and Monday. But he cautioned against expecting any breakthroughs.

headline: Makers Display New Computers
abstract: LEAD: Three companies have introduced new high-powered computers. Apollo Computer Inc. of Chelmsford, Mass., has a work station for engineers with supercomputer power that is priced from $69,900 to $130,000.

headline: Bid for Singer Extended
abstract: LEAD: The investor Paul A. Bilzerian has extended his $50-a-share offer for the Singer Company until next Monday amid talks with Singer's banks about the company's credit status after the $1.06 billion proposed takeover. He also said Tuesday that almost 15.7 million of the 21.1 million shares had been tendered.

headline: I.B.M.'s New System For Huge Computers
abstract: LEAD: Seeking to outmaneuver several Japanese competitors, the International Business Machines Corporation introduced an improved operating system for its largest computers yesterday. It said the system would be provided without charge to current owners of its most advanced mainframes.

headline: Advertising; Ted Chin to Handle Work for Irving Units
abstract: LEAD: The Irving Bank Corporation has called on Ted Chin & Company to handle the creation of advertising and collateral material for four of its divisions. The budget is about $2 million.

headline: PROFITS SCOREBOARD
abstract: LEAD:            Net      Percent       Income      Change                $      Net income   Percent   Oct.-Dec.   Change        1987   From '86       Aluminum Co. of America   $132,800,000   -19.7        Amdahl Corp.   53,000,000   +79.1        Ameritech   322,200,000   +16.1        Boise Cascade Corp.   57,200,000   +78.8        Champion International Corp.

headline: SPAIN PLANS TALKS WITH SEPARATISTS
abstract: LEAD: The Spanish Government has agreed to open formal peace talks with the radical Basque group that has waged a violent campaign for autonomy in northern Spain.

headline: Campeau Renews Bid for Retailer
abstract: LEAD: The Campeau Corporation, strengthened by an alliance with two powerful real estate developers, yesterday renewed its $61-a-share cash offer for Federated Department Stores Inc. Separately, the Securities and Exchange Commission supported Campeau's right to challenge Delaware's new anti-takeover law.

headline: Many Arab Schools Are Shut In Israeli Bid to Curb Unrest
abstract: LEAD: Israel ordered widespread closings of Palestinian schools and universities in the occupied territories today in the face of continuing unrest.

headline: 44 Slain in Sikh-Hindu Violence
abstract: LEAD: At least 32 people were killed and 25 wounded when gunmen attacked a village crowd celebrating a Hindu festival in the Punjab Thursday night, the state government said today. Another 12 people were killed in separate incidents Wednesday night.

headline: Medical Care Sought by Arbitrager Held on Gun Charges
abstract: LEAD: John A. Mulheren, the arbitrager arrested last Thursday on charges of illegal weapons possession, spent the weekend in a county jail in New Jersey and will seek to be hospitalized this week, according to people familiar with his case.

headline: Russian Church Leader Is Urged to Step Down
abstract: LEAD: A group of Soviet Christians called today on Patriarch Pimen, the ailing 77-year-old spiritual head of the Russian Orthodox Church, to step down and make way for a younger, dynamic leader.

headline: Decision to Pay Fees to Econocom
abstract: LEAD: The Decision Industries Corporation has agreed to pay Econocom International N.V. $1.85 million for certain expenses relating to Econocom's failed takeover offer for the computer concern based in Horsham, Pa.

headline: Advertising; Burnett, in 4-Way Race, Wins a Noxell Account
abstract: LEAD: With a limited amount of chortling, the Leo Burnett Company of Chicago announced yesterday that it had beaten three New York agencies by wnning the $20 million Clarion ac-count from the Noxell Corporation.

headline: British Government to Yield Its 'Golden Share' of Britoil
abstract: LEAD: The British Government said today that it would relinquish its ''golden share'' of Britoil P.L.C., removing a major roadblock to the British Petroleum Company's takeover of the independent North Sea oil company.

headline: Advertising; Nostalgia Highlights Sugar Drive
abstract: LEAD: THE suppliers of the nation's refined sugar, which have been hit by both changing industrial and consumer uses, are going to try to win back consumers with an adroit use of nostalgia.

headline: Advertising; People
abstract: LEAD: * Kenneth A. Glaser joins Solin Associates as executive vice president.

headline: Icahn Gives Court Plan On Texaco
abstract: LEAD: Carl C. Icahn, the Wall Street financier who is the largest Texaco shareholder, has made good his promise to offer an alternative to the company's plan to emerge from Federal bankruptcy protection.

headline: First Boston Official Quits
abstract: LEAD: The First Boston Corporation suffered another high-level defection yesterday with the announcement that Yves-Andre Istel, co-head of its international operations, had resigned to join a new firm being formed by other former senior First Boston executives.

headline: PROTEST LEADERS SEIZED, ISRAEL SAYS
abstract: LEAD: Israel's Police Minister asserted today that underground leaders of the 15-week-old Palestinian protest had been seized in a sweep that included hundreds of arrests.

headline: Bonds Advance After Fed's Report
abstract: LEAD: Bond prices rose yesterday in fairly active trading after commodity prices dropped and the Federal Reserve predicted that economic growth would be more modest than it had previously anticipated.

headline: 2 Steel, 2 Gold Stocks Top List of Best Gainers
abstract: LEAD: In a wildly turbulent year, the largest gains on the New York Stock Exchange were registered by two steel producers and two gold-mining companies.

headline: From Poles' Ferment, a Socialist Party
abstract: LEAD: The party's founding unfolded, amid police harassment, in three acts: the first in a garden house, the second in a cafe, the third in an apartment.

headline: New Round of Higher Bids for I.C.L.
abstract: LEAD: The SmithKline Beckman Corporation raised its tender offer for International Clinical Laboratories Inc. to $37 a share today, or about $400 million, just hours after Corning Glass Works made a sweetened $35-a-share offer.

headline: Navy Awards Pact
abstract: LEAD: The Navy has awarded a $644 million contract to the General Dynamics Corporation to build the 15th Trident missile submarine. The submarine will be built by General Dynamics' Electric Boat division in Groton, Conn., and is scheduled to be completed in July 1994, the Navy said. The submarines will each carry 24 of the Navy's updated Trident 2 missiles, or D-5, which is undergoing flight tests.

headline: Dallas Bank's Deposits Fall
abstract: LEAD: First Republicbank Dallas lost more than 8 percent of its deposits as customers withdrew $599 million in one week last month amid speculation about the financial health of its parent company, regulators said.

headline: Phone Contract Testimony Indicates Early Sign of Leak
abstract: LEAD: The General Services Administration met with a representative of the American Telephone and Telegraph Company weeks before the final bids were due for Government phone contracts to discuss a possible leak of the company's secret bid information to competitors, an agency official said today in a deposition proceeding.

headline: Seabrook Filing Stirs Fears on Rates
abstract: LEAD: Who will set electricity rates for the customers of the Public Service Company of New Hampshire and whether the utility's assets will be sold emerged as major issues today following the utility's filing for bankruptcy protection.

headline: PIPELINE DEAL: INTRIQUE IN HIGH PLACES
abstract: LEAD: Shortly after Rear Adm. John M. Poindexter became national security adviser in December 1985, a predecessor in the job offered him sober advice about a billion dollar Iraqi oil pipeline project that was supported by the National Security Council and by President Reagan.

headline: Portable Macintosh Details Published
abstract: LEAD: A trade journal published this week contains thorough details of Apple Computer Inc.'s portable Macintosh personal computer - a serious breach of internal security. Macintosh Today said its article was based on a 160-page confidential document. Apple has declined comment.  The article said the machine, code-named Laguna, will weigh 12 pounds and will feature an active matrix screen, which will work better with graphics than the displays in current laptops.

headline: For Nomadic Rodeo Cowboys, a Few Dollars More
abstract: LEAD: Kyle Whiting, a 26-year-old cowboy, pulled into an Astrodome parking lot two weeks ago for the start of the Houston rodeo shortly before his event, the bull ride. He had just completed a six-hour drive from Baton Rouge, La., and tomorrow he would drive to Tucson, Ariz., and another rodeo.

headline: Mexico Oil Price to Rise
abstract: LEAD: The Government-owned oil company Pemex has announced that it will increase the price of light Isthmus crude by 30 cents a barrel to its customers in the United States. Pemex, whose official name is Petroleos Mexicanos, said in a statement released late Thursday that the change would go into effect Feb.

headline: U.S. OFFICIAL MEETS AFGHAN ALLIANCE
abstract: LEAD: A State Department official met with representatives of all seven Afghan guerrilla factions today in Pakistan to discuss a Soviet troop withdrawal from Afghanistan, the department announced.

headline: Advertising; A Travel Weekly to Hit Newsstands
abstract: LEAD: WITH support from one TV commercial for men, one TV commercial for women and one radio commercial that is sexually ambiguous, Fairchild Publications on Monday will be offering its new weekly consumer publication Travel Today to the East Coast reading public.

headline: Bell & Howell Breakup Likely
abstract: LEAD: The investment group that has agreed to acquire the Bell & Howell Company for $64 a share said today that it was considering selling certain ''non-core'' Bell & Howell assets in order to finance the transaction.

headline: G.M. Chief Promises To Hold '88 Car Prices
abstract: LEAD: The General Motors Corporation will hold the prices of its cars and trucks for the rest of the 1988 model year, Roger B. Smith, the company's chairman, promised dealers here.

headline: Kirkpatrick Assails Treaty But Urges Senate Approval
abstract: LEAD: Jeane J. Kirkpatrick, the former American delegate to the United Nations, said today that the new missile accord was a bad agreement but one the Senate should approve anyway.

headline: Korea Opposition Fails In Reunification Effort
abstract: LEAD: An effort to forge a united opposition to the Government of President Roh Tae Woo collapsed today.

headline: In Jerusalem, Shopkeepers on the Front Line
abstract: LEAD: The main street of Arab East Jerusalem was a long line of closed, gray steel shutters today as Palestinian shopkeepers refused to open their stores for the 13th day in a row.

headline: Macy's Plans for Federated
abstract: LEAD: R. H. Macy & Company said it would divest Federated Department Stores Inc. of all its non-department store divisions and certain other assets within a year of a Macy's-Federated merger and would expect net proceeds from the sales of about $2.9 billion, according to documents filed by Macy with the Securities and Exchange

headline: Visa Charges Increase
abstract: LEAD: United States Visa card holders charged nearly $100 billion last year, a $13 billion increase over 1986. the company said Thursday. Third- and fourth-quarter volumes set records and exceeded expectations by more than 50 percent, Charles T. Russell, president of Visa U.S.A. Inc., said. The number of card holders increased from 98.2 million in 1986 to 106.5 million in 1987, including more than five million Premier Visa card holders, the company said.

headline: Gulf Canada Resources To Acquire Asamera
abstract: LEAD: Gulf Canada Resources Ltd., controlled by the Reichmann family of Canada, said today that it had agreed to buy Asamera Inc., an oil, natural gas and gold producer, for $512 million (Canadian), or about $413 million (United States).

headline: DATA BANK: February 14, 1988
abstract: LEAD:                  THE ECONOMY               Gross National Product   IV Q'87   III Q'87   Year Ago        Annual rate, 1982 dollars, in billions   $3,870.0   $3,835.9   $3,702.4               Real G.N.P. Growth        Annual rate, 1982 dollars, in percent   4.2   4.3   1.7               Corporate After-Tax Profits   III Q'87   II Q'87   Year Ago        In billions, annual rate   $141.9   $134.5   $130.2

headline: Advertising; Margeotes Gains New Recognition
abstract: LEAD: ''IT used to be,'' said George A. Fertitta, president of Margeotes/ Fertitta & Weiss, ''that when we were after an account the competition was usually our size. Now because of the mergers the big agencies are going after smaller but noncompetitive accounts.''

headline: Anti-Israeli Protests in Cairo Broken Up by Egypt's Police
abstract: LEAD: Egyptian police with riot sticks charged and beat hundreds of anti-Israeli protesters chanting Islamic fundamentalist slogans today and besieged others at one of Cairo's most eminent mosques, witnesses said.

headline: A Kibbutz Is Confronted With a Hard New Truth
abstract: LEAD: Duby Bar is the secretary of this kibbutz 600 yards from the border with Jordan, and last Friday, he said, a faith that survived wars and four decades seemed suddenly to whither.

headline: Arab Stresses P.L.O. Role
abstract: LEAD: Yasir Arafat, chairman of the Palestine Liberation Organization, has rejected Secretary of State George P. Shultz's approach to an international conference on the Middle East and insisted that the P.L.O. must be fully represented at any such talks.

headline: Exxon Net Rises 5.4%; ARCO, Ashland Gain
abstract: LEAD: The Exxon Corporation said yesterday that strong sales of chemicals and refined oil products, as well as higher average crude-oil prices, lifted its fourth-quarter net income by 5.4 percent.

headline: Husky Presses for Texaco Canada
abstract: LEAD: In a proposal that would make Li Ka-shing, the Hong Kong real estate investor, a major player in Canada's oil and gas industry, Husky Oil Ltd. of Calgary, Alberta, said today that it would press forward with proposals for a takeover of Texaco Canada Ltd., the Canadian unit of financially troubled Texaco Inc.

headline: Poachers Lurk at Hutton's Door
abstract: LEAD: In 1981, when Sears, Roebuck & Company bought Dean Witter Reynolds, other brokerage firms gleefully lured away some of the firm's finest talent.

headline: British Utility and U.S. Bank Find Good Investor Demand
abstract: LEAD: Two corporate issues totaling $550 million were offered yesterday through Goldman, Sachs & Company at prices slightly higher than had been expected because of strong investor demand.

headline: New Yorkers & Co. A Man Paid to Get in People's Hair
abstract: LEAD: Louis Licari can't tell you whether it's true blondes have more fun. But he can answer that other question asked in the old Clairol hair color commercials, ''Does she or doesn't she?''

headline: Merger by Holmes a Court
abstract: LEAD: Robert Holmes a Court, the Australian financier, today announced a plan to merge his two leading companies after clearing the decks two weeks ago with huge write-offs of losses in the stock market.

headline: Tokyo Action Seen Over Jet
abstract: LEAD: The Japanese Government plans to impose sanctions on North Korea for its suspected role in the destruction of a South Korean airliner Nov. 29 with 115 people aboard, news reports said today. Newspapers, quoting unidentified Foreign Ministry officials, said the measures would include a ban on North Korean officials entering Japan, and barring most trips to North Korea by Japanese officials.

headline: Time to Buy Oil and Gas Income Funds?
abstract: LEAD: WORLD oil prices are dropping again. Not to worry, say the sponsors of the new wave of oil and gas income funds. That just means that those who buy into the funds now will make that much more money later, when oil is sure to rebound.

headline: Oslo's Insider Inquiry
abstract: LEAD: The Oslo stock exchange said today that it would investigate trading in the shares of Norway's biggest bank to be sure no insider dealing occurred before the bank announced a huge loss. Insider dealing is a criminal offense in Norway. The exchange said it would check with dealers, including those at Den Norske Creditbank, because its shares fell sharply on Wednesday just before the bank disclosed that it had a 1987 loss of 1.5 billion kroner, or about $236 million.

headline: BUSINESS DIGEST: MONDAY, FEBRUARY 15, 1988
abstract: LEAD:  International Report

headline: Panama Strongman on Visit
abstract: LEAD: Panama's military leader, Gen. Manuel Antonio Noriega, arrived here unexpectedly today and said he was on a private visit.

headline: Ex-CBS Official In Joint Venture
abstract: LEAD: The former president of the CBS entertainment division, B. Donald Grant, and a subsidiary of the Tribune Company said they had agreed to form a venture to produce television programs.

headline: MOSCOW DECLARES ITS AIM IS TO LEAVE AFGHANISTAN IN '88
abstract: LEAD: Foreign Minister Eduard A. Shevardnadze said today in Afghanistan that the Soviet Union hoped to remove its troops from Afghanistan by the end of the year, and indicated that the withdrawal would not depend on creation of an acceptable transition government.

headline: Brazil Seeks To Mend Rift With Lenders
abstract: LEAD: One year after suspending most payments on its $113 billion foreign debt, Brazil has quietly abandoned its confrontational debt strategy and is now seeking to restore normal relations with its creditors as soon as possible.

headline: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
abstract: LEAD: * Aaron Spelling Productions Inc. named Douglas S. Cramer vice chairman and E. Duke Vincent president of its executive committee.

headline: Dow Barely Budges, Posting Gain of 0.83
abstract: LEAD: The stock market treaded water yesterday, with the Dow Jones industrial average managing a gain of only 0.83 point to close at 2,039.95.

headline: Patents; Equipment Assists In Editing of Documents
abstract: LEAD: The International Business Machines Corporation this week patented equipment that helps in the editing of complex documents, including text, graphics, images, tables and handwriting. It can be used with large or personal computers.

headline: BUSINESS DIGEST: THURSDAY, FEBRUARY 11, 1988
abstract: LEAD:  International

headline: For the Poor of Calcutta, a Threat to Mobility
abstract: LEAD: To some, the hand-pulled rickshaw makes life a little more efficient in one of the world's most unlivable cities. To others, it is a degrading anachronism symbolizing the city's inhumanity.

headline: Kodak's Diversification Plan Moves Into a Higher Gear
abstract: LEAD: Until the Eastman Kodak Company agreed Friday to spend $5.1 billion to acquire Sterling Drug Inc., it had been pursuing a diversification strategy that could best be described as busy but dainty.

headline: McDonnell to Follow His Advice and Retire
abstract: LEAD: Sanford N. McDonnell, a 6-foot-2-inch native of Arkansas, says he feels vigorous enough to keep working even though he has announced his retirement as chairman and chief executive of the McDonnell Douglas Corporation, effective March 2.

headline: THE PIPELINE DRAMA: 5 ACTORS
abstract: LEAD:  Edwin Meese 3d: A longtime associate of Ronald Reagan who became counselor to President Reagan in 1981, and Attorney General in February 1985. Backers of the pipeline project sought his aid in obtaining United States Government support for their plans.  Bruce Rappaport: A Swiss businessman based in Geneva, who has close ties to officials in Israel, including Shimon Peres.

headline: A RISK OF UNREST SEEN IN EAST BLOC
abstract: LEAD: Reagan Administration officials who analyze political and economic trends in Eastern Europe say they believe three of the six Warsaw Pact countries face domestic instability, mainly as a result of deterioration in their economies.

headline: Peres Says Hint of Bribe Offer Is 'Nonsense'
abstract: LEAD: Shimon Peres, the Israeli Foreign Minister, today dismissed as ''nonsense'' reports suggesting that his Labor Party was offered a bribe in 1985 in exchange for a promise not to interfere with the building of a proposed Iraqi pipeline.

headline: Federated Delays 'Poison Pill' Plan
abstract: LEAD: Federated Department Stores said that its board had postponed putting into effect the rights plan attached to Federated's common shares until next Friday or later. The shareholder rights plan, sometimes referred to as a ''poison pill,'' would allow shareholders to buy new Federated shares at a 50 percent discount if another company acquired 30 percent of the company.

headline: Manila Captures 2 Top Communist Leaders
abstract: LEAD: President Corazon C. Aquino and military officials claimed a major victory over Communist rebels today after the capture of the rebel army's leader and the Communist Party's No. 2 man.

headline: The Senate and Conditions
abstract: LEAD: Although senators routinely speak of offering amendments, reservations or understandings to the Soviet-American treaty on intermediate-range nuclear missiles, staff members of the Senate Foreign Relations Committee say these terms are outmoded.

headline: Finns Choosing President in 2-Day Election
abstract: LEAD: Finns began voting today in a two-day presidential election, with President Mauno Koivisto regarded as almost certain to win a second six-year term as custodian of Finland's sensitive relations with the Soviet Union.

headline: Gurkhas Attack in India
abstract: LEAD: Militant Gurkhas blew up road bridges, set fire to government offices and ambushed a police patrol on Friday night as a 40-day strike called to press their demand for autonomy took hold, security officials said.

headline: COMPANY BRIEFS
abstract: LEAD: * Allied-Signal Inc., Morristown, N.J., said the Federal Aviation Administration had certified its aircraft collision avoidance system for use by United Airlines.

headline: U.S. Declares Japan in Violation On Whaling and May Curb Trade
abstract: LEAD: Commerce Secretary C. William Verity Jr. today declared Japan in violation of a moratorium on commercial whaling. A spokesman for Mr. Verity said the Secretary might recommend an embargo on imports of fish from Japan.

headline: Timing Helps Decker Bid, Traders Say
abstract: LEAD: Through a quirk of timing, the Black & Decker Corporation stands a fairly good chance of winning a battle to take over American Standard Inc., even though it is trailing in a bidding contest by more than $30 million, traders said yesterday.

headline: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
abstract: LEAD: * Dean Witter Reynolds (Canada) Inc., Toronto, which is affiliated with the Sears Financial Network in the United States, appointed Peter K. Lundgren executive vice president and director of retail sales, marketing and training.

headline: Forecasts Favoring Lower Rates
abstract: LEAD: At the present time the credit markets are leaning in the direction of lower interest rates, as traders and investors seem to be anticipating weak economic data in the first several months of 1988.

headline: For African Island Nation, Foreign Aid Is a Lifeline
abstract: LEAD: Anchored in the rich fishing waters of the Gulf of Guinea, the African archipelago of Sao Tome e Principe was shaken in 1981 by food riots. The new Government could no longer afford to import dried fish.

headline: AMERICAN STOCK EXCHANGE ISSUES
abstract: LEAD:  AMEX VOLUME  Total share volume on the American Stock Exchange for 1987.  1987 ........................ 3,505,950,000  1986 .................. 2,978,540,000  1985 ............. 2,100,860,000  1984 ....... 1,545,010,000  1983 ........... 2,081,270,000  MOST-ACTIVE AMEX ISSUES IN 1987  Only common stocks are listed; adjusted for stock splits (s).

headline: Nissan Official Sees Quota Cut
abstract: LEAD: The import quota on Japanese cars will probably be reduced in 1988 as a means of easing trade frictions with the United States, a top official of the Nissan Motor Corporation said today.

headline: Mitel-G.E. Deal
abstract: LEAD: Mitel Inc., the United States subsidiary of the Mitel Corporation of Canada, said it had agreed to acquire the General Electric Company's RCA Telephone Systems Business. RCA Telephone Systems Business sells private branch exchange systems to small and medium-sized businesses.

headline: British Car Sales Record
abstract: LEAD: New-car sales in Britain last year exceeded two million for the first time, the industry said today. The Society of Motor Manufacturers and Traders said that December sales of 91,000 vehicles, the best since 1971, raised the year's total to 2,013,693. The group's provisional figures show that British plants made just under 1.2 million cars last year, up from about a million in 1986.

headline: Chrysler Unit's Auto Loans Back $753 Million Offering
abstract: LEAD: In one of the largest offerings of asset-backed debt sales of the year, the Chrysler Financial Corporation yesterday offered $753 million of debt securities backed by car loans through a syndicate led by Salomon Brothers.

headline: BUSINESS DIGEST: WEDNESDAY, MARCH 16, 1988
abstract: LEAD: COMPANIES  First Republicbank asked the F.D.I.C. to prevent its failure. The largest Texas banking company, with assets of more than $33 billion, was besieged anew by negative reports in the press and depositor withdrawals. A bailout would likely be among the most costly in the history of the F.D.I.C.

headline: Beazer Chief's Global Ambitions
abstract: LEAD: Brian Beazer, the 53-year-old chairman of Beazer P.L.C., which has made a bid for the Koppers Company, is renowned for the exhaustive research he does on companies he wants to buy. Typically, according to one of his financial advisers, Mr. Beazer will show up at an acquired concern's headquarters at 7 A.M.

headline: Pretoria Signals Move On Economic Change
abstract: LEAD: South Africa's President P. W. Botha has announced plans to privatize five major state-run corporations that employ a total of 400,000 people and have combined assets of $30 billion.

headline: Seemingly Endless War Is Strangling Mozambique
abstract: LEAD: This desperately poor nation on the southeastern coast of Africa is playing out a tragic drama whose chapters are scrawled in blood. A 12-year-old conflict is strangling Mozambique.

headline: Trade Gap Narrows For the 2d Month
abstract: LEAD: The trade deficit for December was the lowest in 11 months, coming in at $12.2 billion. With imports unchanged, the improvement came from a 4.2 percent gain in exports, to a record $24.8 billion. Most predictions had been for a December deficit of at least $13 billion, and the financial markets strengthened when the report came out.

headline: Federated Shares Dip as Deal Stalls
abstract: LEAD: The price of Federated Department Stores' common stock fell $1.75, to $60, on the New York Stock Exchange yesterday, suggesting that some investors may be growing uncomfortable with the lingering impasse in the Campeau Corporation's takeover attempt. Federated's directors rejected Campeau's $66-a-share offer on Tuesday, and the next day

headline: Growth Lag Reported by Purchasers
abstract: LEAD: The rate of growth of the nation's economy slowed in January, lagging behind December in production and employment, the National Association of Purchasing Management said in its monthly report, scheduled to be released today.

headline: For Reagan, Bizarre Turn; The Options Dwindle On Central America
abstract: LEAD: Even with the long and tortured history of the Reagan Administration's Central American policies, no one could have anticipated the bizarre convergence of events today. In the United States

headline: Kissinger Urged Ban on TV Reports
abstract: LEAD: Henry A. Kissinger has privately urged that Israel bar television cameras and reporters from the occupied territories as part of its effort to put down violent protests.

headline: Autos: Detroit's Rosy View Has Some Support
abstract: LEAD: America's passion for new transportaton vehicles remains nearly as ardent as ever. Most industry forecasts call for sales of about 10 million cars and 5 million light trucks - roughly the same as last year but down from 1986, when 16.3 million vehicles were sold.

headline: Concessions by Sandinistas Asked In Peace Talks With the Contras
abstract: LEAD: In an effort to break the deadlocked peace talks here, the mediator today offered his own peace proposal and asked the Nicaraguan Government to make major political concessions to the rebels.

headline: Advertising; Manager Set At Burkhardt
abstract: LEAD: Greg Bathon, one-time president of J. Walter Thompson U.S.A., a unit of the WPP Group, has joined Burkhardt & Christy, an $8 million agency with 12 employees.

headline: CREDIT MARKETS
abstract: LEAD: Government bond prices moved slightly lower yesterday, following the release of retail sales figures for January that were stronger than had been anticipated.

headline: 22 Are Killed in Raid on Mozambique Train
abstract: LEAD: At least 22 people were killed last week when a group of right-wing guerrillas derailed and plundered a train packed with migrant workers returning from South Africa, the national press agency reported today.

headline: Nabisco Bakery
abstract: LEAD: RJR Nabisco Inc. plans to build a $600 million bakery, covering 1.1 million square feet on 120 acres near Raleigh, N.C. The bakery will make Nabisco-brand cookies and crackers. Construction is to start this spring and is scheduled to be completed in 1990, the company said.

headline: Union Pressure At Chrysler
abstract: LEAD: The United Automobile Workers' council at the Chrysler Corporation voted today to halt all cooperative undertakings with the company, such as productivity and quality improvement programs, and threatened to disrupt operations with strikes at local plants until plans to sell Acustar, a Chrysler division, are shelved.

headline: New York State Income Tax Rates Cut
abstract: LEAD: The rates will be lowered over a five-year period, and at the same time larger standard deductions will be phased in, as shown below. The top marginal rates will apply to most taxpayers; the 1987 threshold is $14,000 for single persons and $23,300 for married couples filing jointly.

headline: Tishman Plans Tall Tower in Europe
abstract: LEAD: In the face of widespread opposition in Europe to the construction of skycrapers, a New York real estate developer said yesterday that he would build the tallest building in Western Europe.

headline: Borrowing Against Life Insurance
abstract: LEAD: A NEW JERSEY executive, eager to participate in a joint venture, ''needed to get his hands on some funds, fast,'' said the executive's financial planner, Paul S. Brienes, president of Paul Stewart Associates in Princeton, N.J. After assessing his client's portfolio, Mr. Brienes tapped the executive's life insurance policy for a loan.

headline: Advertising; Sherwood & Schneider
abstract: LEAD: Consumers Digest, a Chicago-based magazine that sizes up products ranging from automobiles to zoom lenses, has tapped Sherwood & Schneider to handle its consumer and trade advertising, after a three-way competition. The budget is somewhere in the $1 million to $1.2 million range. The former agency is Jameson Advertising.

headline: J. P. Morgan Loses a Top Credit Rating
abstract: LEAD: J. P. Morgan & Company, the last bank holding company in the United States to hold the top rating of the two major credit-rating agencies, lost one of those ratings yesterday.

headline: Time Reportedly Weighs Unit's Sale
abstract: LEAD: Time Inc. is believed to be considering the sale of Scott Foresman & Company, its textbook publishing unit, Wall Street sources said. The company refused to comment. Time bought the company two years ago for $520 million.

headline: Patents; A Catheter With Better Steerability
abstract: LEAD: Medical specialists in San Diego have devised a catheter with improved steerability for opening blockages in arteries. The device is faster than the equipment now in use and causes less stress to patients, according to its inventors. Blockages are caused primarily by a buildup of cholesterol.

headline: Top S.E.C. Accountant Chosen From Ranks
abstract: LEAD: The Securities and Exchange Commission said yesterday that after a nationwide search, it had selected a new chief accountant from its own ranks, naming Edmund Coulson to the important financial post.

headline: Executives
abstract: LEAD: Bacardi Imports Inc., Miami, the U.S. marketer of Bacardi rum, named Eduardo Sardina and Rodolfo Ruiz executive vice presidents. It also named Steven Naclerio senior vice president.

headline: Lisbon Seeks Revision Of U.S. Defense Accord
abstract: LEAD: Portugal plans to ask for a ''thorough overhaul'' of a 37-year-old mutual defense treaty with the United States that allows the use of military sites in the Azores Islands, the Portuguese Foreign Minister says.

headline: In East Bloc, an Expanding Network of Dissenters
abstract: LEAD: Hundreds of East Europeans who are critical of Communist authority issued an appeal today for the right to refuse to go into the army.

headline: Democratic Group Said to Agree on $25 Million Package of Aid for Contras
abstract: LEAD: A task force of 15 House Democrats representing liberal, moderate and conservative wings of the party has tentatively agreed on a $25 million aid package for the Nicaraguan rebels, according to Congressional aides. Jim Wright, the House Speaker, hopes to bring the proposal to the House floor for a vote on

headline: A Computer Traffic Cop
abstract: LEAD: Anyone who has ever given a computer a command and received a response, intelligible or not, has used a computer operating system. People who seek to explain computers to the unintiated often search for operating system metaphors. A traffic cop is a common one. Another is a super-efficient office manager.

headline: Reaching for Cognac, Seagram Is Blocked
abstract: LEAD: The Seagram Company has learned that it is not easy to wed a sexy French company like Martell & Compagnie, the renowned cognac house.

headline: Air Canada-Airbus Deal
abstract: LEAD: Air Canada is near agreement with Europe's Airbus Industrie to buy 34 short-haul A320 airliners and take options on 20 more in a contract worth more than 10 billion francs, or about $1.75 billion, the newspaper Le Monde said Friday. A spokeswoman for the European consortium declined to confirm the report, but said Airbus was in talks with Air Canada as well as with other airlines.

abstract: LEAD:           THE ECONOMY               Gross National Product   IV Q'87   III Q'87   Year Ago        Annual rate, 1982 dollars, in billions   $3,870.0   $3,835.9   $3,702.4               Real G.N.P. headline: CBS Sweetens A Pension Plan
abstract: LEAD: CBS Inc., which has made a string of moves to cut back the size and scope of the company, said yesterday that it would offer increased pension benefits to about 11 percent of its employees if they elect to retire within the next four months.

headline: BRIEFS
abstract: LEAD: * CFM International, a company jointly owned by General Electric Co. and Snecma of France, said Lufthansa German Airlines had placed a firm $150 million order for 15 CFM aircraft engines.

headline: Texaco Facing Back Tax Claim For $6.5 Billion
abstract: LEAD: Texaco Inc., the nation's third-largest oil company, disclosed yesterday that the Federal Government might seek $6.5 billion in back taxes as part of Texaco's bankruptcy proceedings.

headline: DATA BANK: February 7, 1988
abstract: LEAD:                  THE ECONOMY               Gross National Product   IV Q'87   III Q'87   Year Ago        Annual rate, 1982 dollars, in billions   $3,870.0   $3,835.9   $3,702.4               Real G.N.P. headline: Carbide Files India Appeal
abstract: LEAD: The Union Carbide Corporation today appealed a court decision that ordered it to pay $270 million in interim relief to victims of the 1984 gas leak that killed more than 2,800 people.

headline: Fed's Talks This Week To Yield Signs on Goals
abstract: LEAD: This week's meeting of the Federal Reserve, which stands almost alone these days in managing the economy, will provide important indications of its goals for growth and interest rates and will test its resistance to political influence.

headline: At Bangladesh University, Studies in Despair
abstract: LEAD: Amid the poverty, political turmoil and violence of Bangladesh, there is no sadder place than the University of Dhaka.

headline: After 1988, Higher Rates?
abstract: LEAD: WASHINGTON

headline: Stock Prices Rise in Tokyo, Fall Sharply in Hong Kong
abstract: LEAD: Stock prices jumped here today in active midday trading. Brokers said that the activity reflected the beginning of the new stock market fiscal year, ignoring a faltering dollar and a weaker trend overseas.

headline: Ohio Pays Off Bank Bonds
abstract: LEAD: Gov. Richard F. Celeste said the state had completed the early payoff of its obligation on bonds issued after the collapse of the Home State Savings Bank.

headline: Israeli Police Challenged on Palestinian Death
abstract: LEAD: An Israeli magazine asserts that the police investigating the sudden death of a Palestinian prisoner have rewritten their opinion ''to make it possible to close the file.''

headline: The Politician Shifts In Drive for Change
abstract: LEAD: The imperative of political accommodation has begun to reshape the policies and public posture of Mikhail S. Gorbachev, moving him increasingly toward the center of the Soviet political spectrum.

headline: Former Actresses Compete for Political Power in India State
abstract: LEAD: Indian politics were enlivened last week by a dramatic confrontation between two women, both former actresses, competing for power and office in the southern state of Tamil Nadu.

headline: Europe Holds Farm Talks
abstract: LEAD: Ministers of the European Community renewed attempts today to curb soaring European farm spending and prevent the bloc from falling into bankruptcy.

headline: Retail Sales Climbed 0.7% In December
abstract: LEAD: The nation's retail sales rose seven-tenths of 1 percent in December over the November level, the best performance in four months, spurred in great part by higher auto sales, the Commerce Department said yesterday.

headline: Forstmann Little
abstract: LEAD: Forstmann Little & Company, the investment firm that specializes in buyouts, announced that some of its affiliates plan to divest themselves of four units with the help of Morgan Stanley & Company, the investment banking firm. The units, which have total annual sales of $500 million, are American Electric of Memphis, a unit of FL Industries; Reznor, of Mercer, Pa., another FL division; Janitrol Aero, a division of the FL Aerospace Corporation, based in Columbus, Ohio, and the Management Services Corporation of Oklahoma City, a unit of Lear Siegler Holdings.

headline: Tet Offensive: Turning Point in Vietnam War
abstract: LEAD: At 3 o'clock in the morning of Jan. 31, 1968, North Vietnamese and Vietcong forces launched a wave of simultaneous attacks on South Vietnamese and American forces in major cities, towns and military bases throughout South Vietnam.

headline: Top Pentagon Officials Back Plan Keeping Arms Balance in Europe
abstract: LEAD: Top Pentagon officials have endorsed an armaments plan intended to maintain the military balance in Europe after the withdrawal of nuclear missiles under a new treaty.

headline: European Prices Rice
abstract: LEAD: Consumer prices in the 12-nation European Community rose three-tenths of a percent in February from January, and 3 percent from February 1987, the European Community reported today. The 3 percent rate remained unchanged from January. That compares with inflation rates of nine-tenths of 1 percent in Japan and 3.9 percent in the United States.

headline: U.S. Unsure Pakistan Seeks 2d A-Fuel Plant
abstract: LEAD: Pakistan may be building a second plant to enrich uranium to be used for nuclear weapons, in the view of some American officials.

headline: Move to End Belgian Crisis
abstract: LEAD: Jean-Luc Dehaene, a Flemish Christian Democrat, was asked by King Baudouin today to form a government and haul the country out of a five-month crisis. Mr. Dehaene was appointed the King's mediator two months ago to sound out the parties' positions on a new coalition, but abandoned the mission on Thursday after talks failed to bridge differences over the language problem that toppled the Government of Prime Minister Wilfried Martens in October.

headline: WPP Makes New Charges In Dispute Over Walkout
abstract: LEAD: The dispute over the walkout by the top executives of the Lord, Geller, Federico, Einstein advertising agency heated up yesterday.

headline: RIGHTS ADVOCATES AND U.S. CONDEMN SALVADOR AMNESTY
abstract: LEAD: The United States Embassy and human rights advocates are strongly criticizing a blanket amnesty law here that has pardoned several gunmen accused of killing Americans and Salvadorans civilians in recent years.

headline: First Nationwide Sets Joint Venture
abstract: LEAD: First Nationwide Bank and the J. E. Robert Companies said they planned a new business of managing troubled savings institutions.

headline: First Boston Is Penalized
abstract: LEAD: The National Association of Securities Dealers said today that its market surveillance committee had censured and fined the First Boston Corporation and one of its managing directors for trade-reporting violations.

headline: Text of Shultz Letter to Israeli Prime Minister
abstract: LEAD: Following is the text of the letter that Secretary of State George P. Shultz wrote last week to Prime Minister Yitzhak Shamir of Israel outlining the American peace proposal. A similar letter was sent to King Hussein of Jordan.

headline: BUSINESS PEOPLE; USG Chairman Fights To Discourage Raiders
abstract: LEAD: Robert J. Day, the chairman of the USG Corporation, did all he could to ward off raiders. He oversaw a restructuring that added $600 million in debt, helped the company adopt a ''poison pill,'' and saw that directors' terms were staggered so they could not all be replaced at once.

headline: Roper Endorses G.E. Bid; Whirlpool Weighs Action
abstract: LEAD: Directors of the Roper Corporation recommended yesterday that shareholders tender their shares to the General Electric Company, withdrawing the company's endorsement of a bid by the Whirlpool Corporation.

headline: Advertising; 2 Executives Leaving J. Walter Thompson
abstract: LEAD: With an exceedingly flowery memo, Burton Manning, chairman and chief executive of the British-owned J. Walter Thompson Company, notified his people that two members of Don Johnston's management team would be leaving the agency - as Mr. Johnston, the former chief executive, quietly did himself late last year.

headline: Honda Lifts Prices
abstract: LEAD: The American Honda Motor Company said it had raised its prices to reflect the falling value of the dollar against the yen. The Honda division, which sells Civic, Accord and Prelude cars, raised prices by an average of 2.2 percent, or $274 a car.

headline: Sundstrand Filing
abstract: LEAD: The Sundstrand Corporation, an aerospace contractor, has said in a Securities and Exchange Commission filing that it expects to be fined heavily by the Government because of an investigation into reported overcharges. Last July, the Defense Department said that Sundstrand, based in Rockford, Ill., had overbilled the United States over two years by more than $100 million on military contracts.

headline: Markets to Close Friday
abstract: LEAD: The nation's stock and commodity markets will be closed April 1 in observance of Good Friday. Most foreign stock exchanges will be closed. Banks will be open, as will most businesses and Government offices. The Labor Department is scheduled to report on the nation's unemployment rate for March, and the Commerce Department is scheduled to report on construction spending for February.

headline: Speaker Asks Reagan's Help on Contras
abstract: LEAD: Jim Wright of Texas, the Speaker of the House, solicited the Reagan Administration's help today in fashioning a bipartisan aid package for the Nicaraguan rebels, known as contras.

headline: France Acts In Takeovers
abstract: LEAD: France will tighten laws on corporate takeovers in response to a continuing wave of hostile bids, Finance Minister Edouard Balladur said today. He told a news conference that he would require anyone buying more than 10 percent of a company to dislose his final intentions.

headline: Bond Prices Steady in Listless Day
abstract: LEAD: Bond prices were little changed yesterday, as dealers struggled through another listless session. For the most part, traders shrugged off new economic data, even though the reports offered scant evidence of strength.

headline: NCR Chairman Gives Up His Position as President
abstract: LEAD: The NCR Corporation said yesterday that it had named Gilbert P. Williamson president.

headline: Italy's Government Falls After Budget Defeats
abstract: LEAD: Prime Minister Giovanni Goria resigned today after six months as head of Italy's 47th postwar Government, a coalition battered by political infighting and a hostile Parliament.
