headline: Sterling Drug Obtains $2 Billion to Fight Bid
abstract: LEAD: Sterling Drug Inc. disclosed today that a leading New York bank had agreed to arrange a $2 billion line of credit to help the company ward off a hostile takeover offer of nearly $4.4 billion from Hoffmann-La Roche & Company of Switzerland. Sterling did not identify the bank.  In a filing with the Securities and Exchange Commission, Sterling said the $2 billion could be used for ''acquisitions, stock repurchases and extraordinary dividends.

headline: Patents; Record Year For Nation's Inventors
abstract: LEAD: A RECORD number of patents was issued last year, and the Patent and Trademark Office expects no letup. The total was 88,793 in the fiscal year ended Sept. 30, and the brisk pace continued during the rest of 1987.

headline: Retin-A's Impact On Johnson Stock
abstract: LEAD: AN old product with new and potentially profitable applications can excite investors, especially when the maker of the product is an established company that has not had anything new and hot in some time.

headline: Plan to Bar CD Piracy Is Called Inadequate
abstract: LEAD: A system designed by CBS Records to prevent the recording of compact disks onto digital tape is inadequate, a Government agency has reported after a five-month test.

headline: ZZZZ Best Indictment
abstract: LEAD: A young entrepreneur who started a carpet-cleaning business in his parents' garage and turned it into a million-dollar enterprise was charged Friday along with 11 other people in a 54-count Federal indictment that includes accusations of securities fraud and embezzlement.

headline: 9 Get Corporate Conscience Awards
abstract: LEAD: The Council on Economic Priorities, a nonprofit research organization, has awarded its second annual America's Corporate Conscience Awards to nine corporations that it feels exemplify corporate social responsibility.

headline: Israel's Army Battles Arabs And an Image
abstract: LEAD: The Israeli Defense Force, the citizen army that has seemed to many Israelis the finest expression of their nation's modern spirit, is facing a difficult and divisive battle as it struggles to suppress Palestinian protests in the occupied West Bank and Gaza Strip.

headline: Navy Sale to Japan Meets Opposition
abstract: LEAD: A small group of lawmakers in the House of Representatives is trying to block the sale of the Navy's most sophisticated air defense system to Japan, an export that would be worth at least $500 million.

headline: Bridgestone In Deal for Firestone
abstract: LEAD: In a stunning move intended to shut out the unsolicited intentions of Pirelli S.p.A., the Firestone Tire and Rubber Company agreed last night to be acquired by the Bridgestone Corporation of Japan for $80 a share, or $2.6 billion.

headline: BUSINESS PEOPLE; Weyerhaeuser Picks Successor to President
abstract: LEAD: The Weyerhaeuser Company of Tacoma, Wash., said John W. Creighton Jr., an executive vice president, would succeed George H. Weyerhaeuser as president. Mr. Weyerhaeuser will continue as chief executive and succeed Robert B. Wilson as chairman, becoming the first person to hold both jobs at once.

headline: A New Chief For Britoil
abstract: LEAD: The British Petroleum Company said on Monday that it intends to name John Saint as chief executive of Britoil P.L.C. as soon as B.P. completes its acquisition of the company. The British Government has given B.P. permission to acquire Britoil.

headline: DATA BANK: March 27, 1988
abstract: LEAD:           THE ECONOMY               Gross National Product   IV Q'87   III Q'87   Year Ago        Annual rate, 1982 dollars, in billions   $3,880.8   $3,835.9   $3,702.4               Real G.N.P. Growth        Annual rate, 1982 dollars, in percent   4.8   4.3   1.7               Corporate After-Tax Profits   IV Q'87   III Q'87   Year Ago        In billions, annual rate   $144.2   $141.9   $144.2

headline: Egypt Says It Arrested Iranian in Terror Plot
abstract: LEAD: Egypt said today that it had arrested an Iranian agent who was setting up a sabotage group and attempting to recruit adherents from among Moslem fundamentalists. The announcement came a few days after Bahrain reported the arrests of members of what it called a terrorist network directed by Iran.

headline: Advertising; Public Service Effort Promotes Teaching
abstract: LEAD: Because it believes that the nation will need 1.5 million new teachers in the next six years, an organization called Recruiting Young Teachers turned to the Advertising Council for a public service campaign.

headline: S.E.C. Is Said to Broaden Its Sterling Drug Inquiry
abstract: LEAD: The Securities and Exchange Commission has broadened its investigation of suspected insider trading in the securities of Sterling Drug Inc., issuing nearly two dozen subpoenas to arbitragers who bought the securities while the merger was being planned or negotiated, a number of Wall Street professionals said yesterday.

headline: CARL MARKS SELLS UNIT TO BRITONS
abstract: LEAD: Carl Marks & Company, the venerable New York investment bank, said yesterday that it had agreed to sell its securities business, the largest sector of its operations in terms of personnel, to Smith New Court P.L.C., a British concern.

headline: Dow Plunges 43.77 Points, To 2,023.87
abstract: LEAD: Stock prices plummeted yesterday in a broad decline that analysts linked to various factors, including a sharp drop in the dollar's value and worry over interest rates.

headline: A PLEA FOR MARKET COORDINATION
abstract: LEAD: The Presidential panel's report on the stock market crash has run into a cool reception from some in the White House and heavy criticism from some in Congress and on Wall Street for its proposed reforms of the financial system. Already there have been predictions that the proposals will never be enacted.

headline: Nortek-Mohasco
abstract: LEAD: Nortek Inc. has purchased a 7 percent stake in the Mohasco Corporation and said it might seek control of the carpet and furniture manufacturer, which is based in Fairfax, Va. In a Securities and Exchange Commission filing, Nortek said that its efforts last week to discuss a friendly transaction with Mohasco had been rebuffed by the company's management.

headline: Ohio Nuclear Plant Bonds Backed by Lease Payments
abstract: LEAD: A $646 million bond issue was offered yesterday by the Beaver Valley Power Station Funding Corporation, a specially created company whose debt will be backed by lease payments of the Ohio Edison Company.

headline: Federated Holders Get Sweetened Tender Offer
abstract: LEAD: The Campeau Corporation turned yesterday to the shareholders of Federated Department Stores Inc., raising its cash tender offer by $14, to $61 a share.

headline: Talley Plans to Retain McMullen's Chairman
abstract: LEAD: John J. McMullen has made a career of sports and business since he retired from the Navy as a captain in 1954.

headline: Sony Disk Players
abstract: LEAD: The Sony Corporation will begin marketing multidisk players able to play compact disks, compact disk videos and optical laser disks in the United States around May, a company spokesman said. The models cost between $970 and $1,315 in Japan at current exchange rates, but United States pricing is still undecided.

headline: Japan Increases Its Reserves
abstract: LEAD: Japan became the world's biggest holder of currency reserves last year, gaining an equivalent of $32 billion, for a total of $81.1 billion, the International Monetary Fund said today.

headline: Fire at Russian Palace
abstract: LEAD: A fire broke out in the 18th century Yekaterinsky Palace on Friday night, slightly damaging its gilded throne hall, the Communist Party newspaper Pravda reported today. The palace in the town of Pushkin, near Leningrad, is considered one of the finest examples of Russian Baroque architecture.

headline: Dividend Meetings
abstract: LEAD: Following is a partial list of dividend meetings for the week of March 21, 1988:  MONDAY  Ames Dept Stores JC Penney Co  Bunker Hill Inc Rochester Tel  Horizon Bancorp Standard Products  TUESDAY  HF Ahmanson & Co Hydraulic Co  Centerior Energy Park Electrochemical  WEDNESDAY

headline: USX President Is Seen As Chairman Candidate
abstract: LEAD: The USX Corporation announced yesterday that its board had elected Charles A. Corry, a leading company strategist, as president of the giant steel and energy concern.

headline: Advertising; Ex-New Yorkers Start San Francisco Agencies
abstract: LEAD: Out in San Francisco, two new ad agencies are on the scene, each started by creative people from New York - one by an old pro and the other by a couple of under-30 upstarts.

headline: Caracas Journal; A President, a Liaison and a Lot of Political Clout
abstract: LEAD: When President Jaime Lusinchi took office in early 1984, his longtime liaison with his private secretary, Blanca Ibanez, seemed nothing out of the ordinary for a country where the extramarital relationships of prominent politicians have traditionally been heralded as signs of virility.

headline: U.S. and Bonn Seek Harmony Over Missile Issue
abstract: LEAD: The United States and West Germany have agreed to put aside the contentious issue of modernizing short-range nuclear missiles to guarantee harmony in the Atlantic alliance, according to American and German officials.

headline: Polaroid Suit Seeks $5.72 Billion
abstract: LEAD: The Polaroid Corporation is seeking as much as $5.72 billion in damages from the Eastman Kodak Company for infringement on its instant photography patents, according to court documents released yesterday by the Federal District Court in Boston.

headline: S.&P. Index Futures Get New Limits
abstract: LEAD: The Chicago Mercantile Exchange said today that it would impose a new system of adjustable daily price limits on its Standard & Poor's 500-stock index futures and options contracts.

headline: No Plan to Ask Meese to Resign, Baker Reports
abstract: LEAD: The White House Chief of Staff, Howard H. Baker Jr., said today that President Reagan had no intention of asking Attorney General Edwin Meese 3d to resign because he is under investigation for his involvement in an Iraqi pipeline project.

headline: Advertising; Accounts
abstract: LEAD: * Merrill/Norstar Bank, Portland, Me., to Arnold & Company Advertising/Marketing, Boston.

headline: Tobacco on Trial
abstract: LEAD: To the Editor:

headline: S.A.S. to Buy 9 Boeing Jets
abstract: LEAD: The Boeing Company won a $660 million contract today from the Scandinavian Airlines System for nine twin-engined 767 jets, wresting a major sale from Airbus Industrie, the European consortium, and the McDonnell Douglas Corporation.

headline: 2 American Senators Dispute Criticism of Shamir
abstract: LEAD: United States Senators expressed disagreement today with a letter signed by 30 of their colleagues criticizing Prime Minister Yitzhak Shamir of Israel, suggesting he was obstructing peace efforts.

headline: Bethlehem Sets Price Increases
abstract: LEAD: The Bethlehem Steel Corporation will increase its prices from $20 and $30 a ton on certain steel products. The steelmaker increased its base price for carbon and other brands of its steel plates by $20 a ton, or 4.5 percent, to $465 a ton, Gary Graham, a spokesman for the nation's third-largest steel producer, said.

headline: Business and the Law; Suits Mounting On Toxic Waste
abstract: LEAD: IN what has become a virtual race for the courthouse, manufacturers and insurance companies are filing a flurry of lawsuits against one another over who must pay for the cleanup of toxic waste sites throughout the nation.

headline: Southdown Offer
abstract: LEAD: Southdown Inc. said it would raise its bid for Moore McCormack Resources Inc. a second time, by adding $5 a share worth of Southdown bonds to its $35-a-share offer. The revised offer is valued at $512 million, up from $450 million. Moore, a cement maker based in Stamford, Conn., has been resisting the overtures of Southdown, a cement maker based in Houston.

headline: Profits Plunge At First Boston
abstract: LEAD: First Boston Inc., battered by losses in its risk arbitrage unit and by the general downturn in business activity after the stock market collapse in October, reported yesterday that its fourth-quarter earnings plummeted 91.7 percent on a 35.3 percent decline in revenues.

headline: Saudis Debate How to Handle Iran Pilgrims
abstract: LEAD: Saudi Arabia is struggling with ways to handle tens of thousands of Iranian pilgrims who will arrive for the annual pilgrimage, or hajj, to Mecca in July.

headline: Will Riot Role Blunt Israelis' Warrior Spirit?
abstract: LEAD: Since early December, the Israel Defense Force, envied among armies of the world for courage and performance, has been playing an unaccustomed role as policemen in trying to put down Palestinian riots in the occupied West Bank and Gaza Strip. It is hardly a role that the combat-oriented army relishes.

headline: New Seoul Chief's Aides Dampen Expectations
abstract: LEAD: As President Roh Tae Woo took charge of the South Korean Government today, his advisers and neutral analysts warned against overly high expectations for swift or dramatic political and economic change.

headline: Advertising; Emhart Begins Ads For Its New Operation
abstract: LEAD: For some 75 years the Emhart Corporation had two operations, one producing such industrial products as machine tools, the other making such consumer goods as Tru-Temper lawn and garden tools and golf club shafts.

headline: 4 Palestinians Linked to Protests Are Expelled to Lebanon by Israel
abstract: LEAD: Israel expelled four West Bank Palestinians today, taking them by helicopter to a lonely mountain road in southern Lebanon.

headline: Stock Index Inquiry Report
abstract: LEAD: The Commodity Futures Trading Commission said today that it had found no evidence of price manipulation in the Major Market Index, a stock index futures contract traded on the Chicago Board of Trade, during the October market collapse.

headline: Money Funds' 2d-Biggest Rise
abstract: LEAD: Assets of the nation's 414 money market mutual funds increased $7.62 billion, to $271.51 billion, for the week ended Wednesday, the Investment Company Institute said yesterday.

headline: Wells Fargo to Buy Barclays in California
abstract: LEAD: Wells Fargo & Company said today that it had agreed to acquire Barclays Bank of California for about $125 million in cash. A subsidiary of the London-based Barclays Bank P.L.C., Barclays Bank of California is the 17th-largest bank in the state, with 1987 year-end assets of about $1.3 billion.

headline: Artists' Profits
abstract: LEAD: To the Editor:

headline: South Africa Clerics Defy Threats With Services Against Crackdown
abstract: LEAD: Striking a new note of militancy, South African church leaders today dismissed the latest Government threats to silence them and held defiant and well-attended protest services around the country to reiterate their support for civil disobedience.

headline: BUSINESS DIGEST: WEDNESDAY, JANUARY 13, 1988
abstract: LEAD:  International

headline: Israeli Officers Ordered to Watch Tape of 4 Soldiers Beating Arabs
abstract: LEAD: The Israeli Army commander in the West Bank summoned all his officers above the rank of captain today and made them watch American television footage taken of four of his soldiers beating two captured Palestinian youths for nearly 40 minutes.

headline: Dow Tops 2,000, but Trading Is Slow
abstract: LEAD: Stock prices rose broadly yesterday in subdued post-holiday trading.

headline: European Bank Plan Supported
abstract: LEAD: West Germany officially gave its support last week to the establishment of a Western European central bank that would be independent of European Community governments. Finance Minister Gerhard

headline: Advertising; Sun-Diamond Goes to Y.&R.
abstract: LEAD: Young & Rubicam, San Francisco, will no doubt be toasting its 10th anniversary this month with glasses of prune juice.

headline: Citicorp Rates Up
abstract: LEAD: Interest rates rose about one-fifth of a percentage point at Citicorp's weekly auction of commercial paper. The bank holding company sold $50 million of 91-day paper at an average rate of 6.625 percent, up from 6.431 percent last week. Another $50 million of 182-day paper sold at an average rate of 6.667 percent, up from 6.4306 percent.

headline: G.M. Increases Some Dividends
abstract: LEAD: The General Motors Corporation increased the dividends on its class H and class E stock, reflecting improved earnings of the independently reporting subsidiaries that they represent. Class H shares, which represent G.M. Hughes Electronics, will pay 22 cents each, up from 18 cents. Class E stock, which represents Electronic Data Systems, will pay 17 cents a share, up from 13 cents.

headline: Harvard Study In Soviet Is Set
abstract: LEAD: Two professors at the Harvard Business School have received permission from the Soviet Union to conduct a comprehensive study of management procedures at two Soviet industrial sites.

headline: Dollar Advances Overseas; Gold Little Changed in U.S.
abstract: LEAD: After rising against all key foreign currencies in overseas trading yesterday, the dollar held its gains in New York, where it traded in a narrow range.

headline: RAIDS MAKE IRAN IMPORT REFINED OIL PRODUCTS
abstract: LEAD: Repeated Iraqi air raids have damaged Iran's oil refineries, causing the nation, a leading oil producer, to import between 200,000 and 300,000 barrels a day of refined products such as jet fuel, gas oil and kerosene for home consumption.

headline: Advertising; Beech-Nut Nutrition Hires Makovsky & Co.
abstract: LEAD: After all the bad publicity it received for selling phony apple juice for infants, Beech-Nut Nutrition has retained the public relations firm Makovsky & Company for a national program.

headline: Nicaraguan Leader Is Calling For Economic Aid From U.S.
abstract: LEAD: President Daniel Ortega Saavedra has made several public pleas in recent days for American economic help and a diplomatic thaw, suggesting that a desire to rebuild relations with Washington was his main reason for approving a cease-fire agreement.

headline: Allied-Signal Cites Error
abstract: LEAD: A processing error at Allied-Signal caused a loss of millions of dollars in an employee retirement savings plan during the stock market crash in October, company officials said. Allied said it was making up the difference to employees.

headline: REAGAN ON TV FOR CONTRA AID
abstract: LEAD: President Reagan will go on television Tuesday to press his plea to Congress to approve fresh aid for the rebels fighting the Nicaraguan Government, the White House announced today.

headline: In Seoul, 'Things Have Collapsed' for Opposition
abstract: LEAD: Hopes that this nation's fractured opposition would be able to unite in time for next month's legislative elections dimmed today as merger talks collapsed again.

headline: FINANCE/NEW ISSUESFarm Credit Sale Comprises 4 Issues
abstract: LEAD: The Federal Farm Credit Banks is offering four tranches of bonds totaling $3.3 billion at par through various securities dealers.

headline: Hostile Bidder for IU Tops a Friendly Offer
abstract: LEAD: The protracted battle for control of the IU International Corporation intensified today as the company announced a friendly leveraged buyout proposal and later became the subject of a higher hostile takeover offer.

headline: Cuba Reportedly Gives U.S. Schedule for Angola Pullout
abstract: LEAD: Cuba has presented the United States with a proposed timetable for the withdrawal of its nearly 40,000 troops in Angola, the Government of President Jose Eduardo dos Santos says.

headline: Czechoslovak President Praises Soviet Goals
abstract: LEAD: President Gustav Husak, who was replaced last month as Communist Party chief, praised innovation in Kremlin policies today but indicated that economic change in his country has not even begun.

headline: COURT IN CANADA RULES ON ABORTION
abstract: LEAD: The Supreme Court ruled today that Canada's restrictive abortion law unconstitutionally interferes with a woman's right to control her own body.

headline: Soviet and Swedes Sparring Over Submarines
abstract: LEAD: The Soviet Prime Minister, Nikolai I. Ryzhkov, finished a three-day round of fence-mending in Sweden today with an agreement on fishing rights in the Baltic Sea, an accord on sharing information about nuclear accidents and a pledge to step up trade.

headline: Mixed View of G.M. Sales
abstract: LEAD: Officials of the General Motors Corporation's Pontiac, Buick and Oldsmobile divisions gave a mixed view Friday of auto sales for 1988.

headline: Righting English
abstract: LEAD: To the Editor:

headline: Meese Will Travel This Week To Spain, Italy and Mexico
abstract: LEAD: Attorney General Edwin Meese 3d, who faces a rising number of calls for his resignation, will make trips to Spain, Italy and Mexico in the next week.

headline: U.S. TO WITHDRAW 72 JET FIGHTERS FROM SPANISH BASE
abstract: LEAD: The United States, after months of negotiations with Spain, has decided to accede to Spanish demands and withdraw 72 F-16 jet fighters based there, Defense and State Department officials said today.

headline: Baker Presses Seoul to Spur Imports
abstract: LEAD: Treasury Secretary James A. Baker 3d told South Korea's new Government today that the United States expected it to move quickly to accept more imports and to strengthen the value of its currency, the won.

headline: CONTRA AID TALKS REACH AN ACCORD
abstract: LEAD: House Democratic and Republican leaders said tonight that they had agreed in principle on a package of about $50 million to aid the Nicaraguan rebels.

headline: Caraguatay Journal; People Leave and the Dollars Arrive
abstract: LEAD: Many inhabitants of this small farming town have never visited Asuncion, the Paraguayan capital, and a few speak only the traditional Guarani language, but everyone, it seems, has a daughter or a cousin or some other close relative living in New York.

headline: German Backs Dollar Level
abstract: LEAD: In the clearest sign of the intentions of the major industrial countries for the recently tumbling dollar, West Germany's Finance Minister, Gerhard Stoltenberg, said today that the current exchange rate was acceptable.

headline: General Mills' Profits Rise
abstract: LEAD: General Mills Inc. said today that its earnings jumped 25.5 percent in the third quarter, primarily because of growth in its consumer foods division.

headline: I.B.M. Is Gaining a Foothold In the Minicomputer Market
abstract: LEAD: With the 9370 minicomputer introduced last year, the International Business Machines Corporation is gaining a foothold in medium-priced computer systems after a slow start, company executives said here today.

headline: Japan's Output Rises
abstract: LEAD: Japan's industrial production in December rose a revised 2 percent from the previous month and a revised 9.2 percent from a year earlier, the Ministry of International Trade and Industry said today.

headline: Chrysler's Sales Fell 8.1% in 1987
abstract: LEAD: The Chrysler Corporation said it had sold 2,012,950 cars and light trucks in the United States in 1987, down 8.1 percent from its own 1986 sales plus those of the American Motors Corporation, which it acquired last year. Its car sales were down 20.9 percent, to 1,096,385, and its truck sales were up 14.1 percent, to 916,565.

headline: Cellular Makes Bid
abstract: LEAD: Cellular Communications Inc., based in New York, has begun an unsolicited tender offer for a majority holding in the American Cellular Network Corporation for $15.50 cash a share, or a total of $69.75 million. The bid was disclosed in a filing with the Securities and Exchange Commission. American Cellular builds and owns cellular telephone systems in the Middle Atlantic region from its headquarters in Pleasantville, N.J.

headline: 'Give Us Your Money or Give Us Your Influence'
abstract: LEAD: MORGAN STATE, a cultural and educational oasis amid Baltimore's inner-city bleakness, is borrowing heavily from techniques of Madison Avenue and Hollywood to promote its resurgence.

headline: Advertising; Goodyear Picks HDM For Los Angeles Work
abstract: LEAD: The Goodyear Tire and Rubber Company, based in Akron, Ohio, has named HDM, Los Angeles, to handle its Los Angeles retail broadcast advertising. The budget is estimated between $3 million and $5 million.

headline: Bangkok Emerges as a Major Jewelry Center
abstract: LEAD: Bangkok is rapidly climbing to the top of the international jewelry trade, and Thai jewelers say it is partly because cutting and setting gemstones is still a traditional family craft here.

headline: COMPANY BRIEFS
abstract: LEAD: * Alexander & Alexander Services Inc., an insurance brokerage, completed sales of its two major underwriting units, Sphere Drake Insurance Group P.L.C. and Shand Morahan & Co., to separate investor groups. Terms were not disclosed.

headline: Increase in Oil Use Seen
abstract: LEAD: Oil consumption in the Organization for Economic Cooperation and Development countries is expected to grow by 1 percent, or about 300,000 barrels a day, over 1987 levels, the International Energy Agency said. In its latest monthly report, the agency projected average world consumption, excluding the centrally planned economies, at between 49 and 49.5 million barrels a day in 1988, with non-O.E.C.D.

headline: Advertising; Joint Venture For Fortune In France
abstract: LEAD: IT is entirely appropriate that the first issue of Fortune France has the chairmen of Louis Vuitton and Moet-Hennessy on the cover toasting one another with - what else? -champagne. The pair are the subject of the lead article on the giant luxury goods conglomerate.

headline: 'Limits to Our Patience,' U.S. Cautions Noriega
abstract: LEAD: A White House spokesman expressed outrage today over the violence against opposition figures and American reporters in Panama, and he warned that ''there are limits to our patience.''

headline: Delaware Takeover Curb Near
abstract: LEAD: Delaware will soon have a new law that makes hostile takeovers of corporations more difficult.

headline: Business Technology; Advances; Silicon Chips Are Promising A New Era for Computers
abstract: LEAD: COMPUTER memory technology is advancing so rapidly that some engineers believe that in the next decade silicon chips will begin to replace magnetic disks as the main way of storing information in computers.

headline: Cambodian Is Said to Offer To Return American Remains
abstract: LEAD: A high-ranking Cambodian official told three Congressmen touring Southeast Asia that his country has the remains of 80 American servicemen killed during the Vietnam War and is prepared to release them to the United States, the lawmakers said today.

headline: Israel Detains 2 In Burial Alive Of Palestinians
abstract: LEAD: The Israeli Army said today that it had opened an investigation into reports that its troops had buried four young Palestinians alive. It said that it had detained two soldiers and that it expected to detain others.

headline: Malay Party Ruled Illegal, Spurring Conflicts
abstract: LEAD: The political party that has headed every Malaysian Government since independence in 1957 was ruled illegal last week by a Malaysian judge because some of its branches were improperly registered. The unexpected ruling is likely to pose political, legal and possibly financial problems for Prime Minister Mahathir Mohamad and the party, the United Malays National Organization.

headline: I.B.M. Net Rises 50.4% In Quarter
abstract: LEAD: In a long-awaited and somewhat muted rebound, the International Business Machines Corporation said yesterday that its fourth-quarter net income rose 50.4 percent, to $2.09 billion, after a year of cost-cutting measures that John F. Akers, the company's chairman, declared ''are beginning to pay off.

headline: 'Woo 'em or Lose 'em' to Local Delis
abstract: LEAD: THE EASTMAN KODAK COMPANY has the nation's largest self-operated food service for its employees. At its Rochester headquarters, 45,000 employees frequent 56 dining areas and use 1,300 vending machines.

headline: Factory Orders Fall By 0.8%
abstract: LEAD: Orders to American factories for manufactured goods fell for the second consecutive month in February, the Commerce Department reported today, but analysts said the decline of eight-tenths of 1 percent was not a cause for alarm.

headline: Standard Endorses Kelso Bid
abstract: LEAD: After a two-month battle to preserve its independence, American Standard Inc. yesterday accepted a takeover offer of $78 a share, or slightly more than $2.5 billion in cash, from the small Manhattan investment house Kelso & Company.

headline: A Nutrasweet Product Is Due
abstract: LEAD: The Nutrasweet Company is planning to announce the development of a fat substitute that could reduce calories and cholesterol in many foods, according to a report published in Crain's Chicago Business, a weekly publication. The company declined to comment, but a spokesman said Nutrasweet had scheduled a news conference in New York on Jan.

headline: Keycorp Buys A Utah Bank
abstract: LEAD: Keycorp of Albany has acquired the Commercial Security Bancorpation of Salt Lake City, according to officials of both companies.

headline: Isolated Afghan Refugee Camp Life Turns Women Into 'Birds in a Cage'
abstract: LEAD: ''We never ask the women,'' Sultan Mohammad said indignantly.

headline: Sandinistas Call for Ouster Of Mediator in Peace Talks
abstract: LEAD: The Sandinista Government said tonight that it was ready to hold high-level talks inside Nicaragua next week with leaders of United States-backed contra guerrillas.

headline: BUSINESS FORUM: WHO HOLDS THE REINS; 'Privatizing' Doesn't Always Work
abstract: LEAD: PRIVATIZATION in developing countries is a highly desirable goal and is often long overdue. But the belief that privatizing is the only acceptable alternative to state ownership can lead to strategies that are economically impractical and politically naive.

headline: Trump Withdraws Proposal To Take Resorts Private
abstract: LEAD: Donald J. Trump, chairman of Resorts International Inc., said today that because of confusion created by a competing offer he was withdrawing his $22-a-share, $123 million proposal to take the Atlantic City casino operator private.

headline: ICH to Raise Stake In First Executive
abstract: LEAD: The ICH Corporation, already a leading shareholder in the First Executive Corporation, said it intended to make a cash tender offer of $12 a share, or $134.4 million, for 11.2 million more shares of the Los Angeles-based life insurer. ICH, an insurance holding concern based in Louisville, Ky., must seek regulatory approval and the consent of certain lenders before making the purchase.

headline: Israeli Army Also Worried By the Settlers
abstract: LEAD: Growing unrest and threats of vigilantism among the Jewish settlements rooted like citadel-suburbs amid resentful Arabs are posing new problems for the Israeli Army as it faces a third month of Palestinian protest.

abstract: LEAD: To the Editor:

headline: U.S. Backs Panamanian's Tactic And Weighs Canal Funds Cutoff
abstract: LEAD: With the backing of the Reagan Administration, political opponents of Gen. Manuel Antonio Noriega today presented a campaign of economic warfare intended to create a cash flow crisis for Panama.

headline: BELL COPTER AND ARMY SETTLE CASE
abstract: LEAD: The Army and Bell Helicopter Textron Inc. have settled a four-year dispute over accusations that the Army was fraudulently overcharged for helicopter spare parts. The Army said today that Bell had agreed to pay the Government about $88 million.

headline: Minister of Defense Quits in Philippines, Citing Rise of Rebels
abstract: LEAD: Defense Minister Rafael Ileto announced today that he had submitted his resignation, saying the Government had failed to address the welfare of the people, allowing the Communist insurgency to grow ''alarmingly strong.''

headline: New Yorkers & Co.; An 18-Year Court Fight Still Awaiting an Ending
abstract: LEAD: Gather round and listen to the tale of Saul S. Weitzman. It is the oldest one in the book - the docket book, that is, of the Federal Court for the Southern District of New York. For that matter, it ranks among the 100 oldest civil cases still active in the Federal judicial system.

headline: Pillsbury to Keep Burger King, Despite Rumors
abstract: LEAD: The Pillsbury Company's stock soared early today in anticipation that the Minneapolis company's new top officer would announce dramatic plans like the sale of the Burger King chain. But the shares fell back when he said he had no such intentions.

headline: Mexican Asks U.S. Not to Use Force in Region
abstract: LEAD: President Miguel de la Madrid of Mexico called today for a negotiated settlement of the Nicaragua-contra war and for a United States policy of nonintervention in Latin America.

headline: Broken Marriage and Brawl Test a Cohesive Caste
abstract: LEAD: After five years of marriage, Ganga walked out on her husband the other day, announcing that she would no longer submit to his beatings. She then returned to her parents in another part of this northern Indian village.

headline: German Steel Week Cut
abstract: LEAD: West German steelworkers agreed with employers today to cut the workweek in the troubled industry to 36.5 hours, the shortest ever, beginning Nov. 1. The agreement, covering the majority of West Germany's 150,000 steelworkers, is expected to be ratified by union members on Tuesday. The powerful I.G.

headline: 2d Haitian Leader Detained After Criticizing Vote
abstract: LEAD: A second Haitian opposition leader was detained at the airport here this afternoon in what many Haitians and some Western diplomats said appeared to be a Government effort to divert attention from the presidential elections last Sunday.

headline: Lost Drivers Get Some Help
abstract: LEAD: When you're lost in the Silicon Valley, there's no need to do something so low tech as to look at a map. The Navigation Technologies Corporation, a start-up based in Sunnyvale, Calif., has created a small computer that tells you where to go and how to get there by the most efficient route.

headline: Bonn to Sell Stake in VW
abstract: LEAD: West Germany said today that it would sell its remaining shares in Volkswagenwerk A.G., after twice delaying its plans to privatize the Government's stake in the giant car company.

headline: Triangle Package Unit Hires Chip Executive
abstract: LEAD: William N. Sick, executive vice president of Texas Instruments Inc., switched yesterday to packaging from electronics, announcing that he had been named chief executive of the American National Can Company.

headline: 2 Europeans Seized in Lebanon
abstract: LEAD: Two Scandinavians working for the United Nations were reported kidnapped in southern Lebanon today. No group claimed responsibility, but the police here said the kidnappers were Palestinian guerrillas loyal to Abu Nidal.

headline: Butler Is Seeking Larger Bear Stake
abstract: LEAD: A group led by the New York-based Butler Capital Corporation, an investment banking firm, is asking Federal antitrust regulators for permission to increase its holdings in Big Bear Inc. to up to 25 percent from 8.8 percent. Butler has said previously that it was considering a merger with Big Bear.

headline: COMPANY BRIEFS
abstract: LEAD: * Alliant Computer Systems Corp., Littleton, Mass., said it was restructuring to add 50 new jobs in its international organization and to eliminate 40 positions at its headquarters.

headline: Singapore Plan for Vote Change Stirs Dispute
abstract: LEAD: The Government of Prime Minister Lee Kuan Yew, asserting that British-style parliamentary democracy is not adequate for the country's long-term needs, is proposing a new electoral system in which voters in some constituencies will choose teams of legislators rather than single candidates.

headline: Farmers Group Rejects Offer
abstract: LEAD: The Farmers Group Inc. today rejected a $4.2 billion takeover bid from the United States arm of the British tobacco conglomerate B.A.T. Industries P.L.C., saying the offer was inadequate and not in the best interests of shareholders.

headline: Canada Puts Neo-Nazi's Ideas on Trial, Again
abstract: LEAD: For weeks now, a district courtroom here has resounded with testimony about Nazi vans in Belgrade, the installations at Auschwitz and mass executions in the German-occupied Crimea as witnesses have taken the stand in to examine in minute detail the fate of European Jews during World War II.

headline: Federated Looks to Macy To Counter Campeau Offer
abstract: LEAD: Two days after receiving a new $6.6 billion takeover bid from the Campeau Corporation, Federated Department Stores Inc. said yesterday that it had entered into talks with R. H. Macy & Company on a possible higher offer.

headline: Gannett-Cowles
abstract: LEAD: The Gannett Company, the diversified media company that publishes USA Today, said it had sold its 640,492 shares of the Cowles Media Company back to Cowles for $200 a share, or $128 million. Gannett had acquired the shares of the Minneapolis-based concern in 1985 for about $83 million. Most of the stake had been acquired in connection with Gannett's acquisition of The Des Moines Register, The Jackson (Tenn.) Sun and two Iowa weeklies from The Register and Tribune Company.

headline: Mortgage Rates Down; Buyers Wary
abstract: LEAD: The recent steep decline in interest rates has pushed mortgage lending rates in most areas of the nation to their lowest levels in more than six months. Yet consumers seem to be reacting cautiously to the decline.

headline: For Syria, a Pivotal Role in Mideast
abstract: LEAD: As it celebrates the 25th anniversary of Baath Party rule this month, Syria appears to have recovered its ability to influence the Arab political agenda.

headline: Sikhs Are Blamed for Killing 10 Over 24 Hours in Punjab
abstract: LEAD: Sikh militants in Punjab state killed 10 people, one a senior member of Prime Minister Rajiv Gandhi's Congress Party, in attacks over a 24-hour period Sunday and today, the police and news organizations said.

headline: President 'Welcomes' Senators' Israel Note
abstract: LEAD: The White House spoke favorably today of the letter sent by 30 senators criticizing Prime Minister Yitzhak Shamir of Israel for opposing the trading of territory for peace.

headline: F.D.I.C. Faces a Texas-Size Drain
abstract: LEAD: The banking problems in the depressed Southwest have become so acute, banking experts say, that they could create the largest one-year drain in history on the Government agency that insures deposits at the nation's banks.

headline: SOVIET WON'T END AFGHAN ARMS AID
abstract: LEAD: A senior Soviet official declared today that Moscow would not cease arming the Kabul Government as part of an agreement for an Afghan cease-fire. The Reagan Administration has demanded an arms cutoff as part of any peace settlement.

headline: SANDINISTAS HALT AMNESTY MEETING
abstract: LEAD: Sandinista demonstrators attacked and broke up a meeting today at which speakers were demanding amnesty for prisoners.

headline: Sale of Stake In Kaisertech
abstract: LEAD: Jefferies & Company Inc. said today that it had agreed to sell 1.4 million shares of Kaisertech Ltd. stock to the Maxxam Group Inc. for $12 a share, or $16.8 million.

headline: Nunn Seeks Shield for Missiles Fired in Error
abstract: LEAD: Senator Sam Nunn said today that the United States should consider developing a limited anti-missile defense system to protect American territory from accidental missile launchings by other nations.

headline: Correction
abstract: LEAD: Because of an editing error, a Business Forum article by E. Norman Veasey on Feb. 7, about Delaware's new takeover law, omitted a phrase. The second sentence of the first paragraph should have read: ''This statute requires certain hostile bidders to obtain the approval of the disinterested stockholders - other than the bidder or management - in order for the takeover bidder's shares to have voting power.

headline: Israeli Army Steps Up Effort To Block Coverage of Unrest
abstract: LEAD: The Israeli Army effectively blocked foreign journalists from the occupied West Bank and Gaza Strip today, apparently in an effort to reduce coverage of Palestinian protests.

headline: SmithKline Bids for I.C.L.
abstract: LEAD: The SmithKline Beckman Corporation has offered $32 a share, or about $340 million, for International Clinical Laboratories Inc., which is $6 more a share than in an agreement reached recently with Corning Glass Works.

headline: Hunger Strike by Iran Dissidents Entangles Chirac Over Expulsions
abstract: LEAD: The deteriorating medical condition of several Iranian dissidents on a nearly month-old hunger strike to protest France's dealings with Iran is presenting Prime Minister Jacques Chirac's Government with new political difficulties.

headline: South Africa Delays Release Of the Movie 'Cry Freedom'
abstract: LEAD: The release in South Africa of ''Cry Freedom,'' Sir Richard Attenborough's apartheid film, has been 'postponed indefinitely,'' the distributors said tonight.

headline: Morong Journal; They Train to Become as American as They Look
abstract: LEAD: Chieu Hang Cuc Nguyen, whose American father left her behind in Vietnam when she was 3 years old, knows she will do well in the United States because, she said, she is bold and outspoken like an American, even though she still does not speak English.

headline: Chiat/Day Terminates Its Rockport Business
abstract: LEAD: Chiat/Day, New York, announced yesterday that by mutual agreement with its client, the Rockport Company, the two are splitting.

headline: Sandinista Denies Leaders Are Split
abstract: LEAD: Interior Minister Tomas Borge, who has been at the center of recent reports of dissent among Sandinista leaders, says differences on the nine-man National Directorate do exist, but do not threaten Government unity.

headline: Group Bids for Canadian Chain
abstract: LEAD: A group of Canadian companies has offered to buy Steinberg Inc., one of the country's largest supermarket chains, for $980 million in cash (Canadian), or $764 million (American). The group is Oxdon Investments Inc., which is owned by the Unicorp Canada Corporation, the Gordon Investments Corporation and the Oxford Development

headline: First-Run Syndicators Find Tight TV Market
abstract: LEAD: In recent years, the business of making programs for local television stations has been one of the fastest-growing segments of the entertainment industry, if also the least glamorous.

headline: U.S. Asks Italy to Take F-16 Jets That Spain Has Ordered Removed
abstract: LEAD: The United States has asked Italy if it would be willing to accept 72 F-16 jet fighters that must be withdrawn from Spain, Administration officials said today.

headline: Pepperell Tops a New Stevens Bid
abstract: LEAD: In the opening round of a takeover battle, a management group at J. P. Stevens & Company sweetened its buyout bid for the huge textile producer yesterday, only to see West Point-Pepperell Inc. emerge with an even higher offer.

headline: You Can't Stand the Noise? Get an Anti-Noise Machine
abstract: LEAD: HIGH school physics students learn that matter is composed of waves - light waves, electromagnetic waves, sound waves -and that if two trains of waves are exactly out of phase and collide head-on they can cancel each other. Engineers have toyed with the possibility of blanking out noise by bombarding offensive sound waves with their exact opposites, or anti-noise.

headline: FRENCH NAVY AIDS A FOREIGN TANKER
abstract: LEAD: France appears to have altered its rules of military engagement in the Persian Gulf, announcing today that one of its warships intervened to stop an Iranian attack on a non-French tanker flying a Liberian flag last weekend.

headline: B.B.D.O. Is Beginning Its First Pizza Hut Ads
abstract: LEAD: The first Pizza Hut advertising from Batten, Barton, Durstine & Osborn will begin to run on the three commercial TV networks tomorrow. You will certainly get familiar with it since the national budget is $70 million and additional millions will be spent on the same advertising by the franchisee advertising groups.

headline: Rig Count Off in Week
abstract: LEAD: The number of oil and gas rigs exploring for oil in the United States fell by 32 last week, to 946, Baker Hughes Inc. announced today. A year ago, the number stood at 761.

headline: Myerson & Kuhn Arises From Finley, Kumble
abstract: LEAD: Myerson & Kuhn is making its debut in New York City this week, arising from what was recently the nation's fourth-largest law firm.

headline: Soviet Withdrawal Offer Raises Stakes for an Afghan Compromise
abstract: LEAD: The Soviet offer to start withdrawing from Afghanistan in May is putting new pressure on the other parties in the civil war to reach a compromise peace settlement next month, according to officials involved in the United Nations effort for a settlement and other experts on the conflict.

headline: Economic Scene; Putting the Brakes On Easy Trading
abstract: LEAD: IS Wall Street drowning in a tide of trading? Complaints about the Street's casino mentality are treated as public relations headaches by the exchanges and the big brokerage houses. Nor are they taken seriously by most free market economists, who see rapid turnover as the welcome consequence of increased competition and computerization.

headline: G.E.-Martin Marietta Satellite Deal
abstract: LEAD: The Martin Marietta Corporation, announcing what is by far the largest contract yet for the nascent commercial space-launching business, said today that it had agreed to launch 15 communications satellites for the General Electric Company's Astro-Space division.

headline: Hong Kong Charges May Grow
abstract: LEAD: Ronald Li, the former chairman of the Hong Kong Stock Exchange who was charged Thursday with accepting $352,000 from a Japanese company in return for listing it on the exchange, could face further charges as the colony's Government continues its investigation, a prosecutor said today.

headline: Fed Backs Bank Merger
abstract: LEAD: The Federal Reserve Board has approved the proposed merger of the Shawmut Corporation of Boston and the Hartford National Corporation of Hartford. Shareholders of the two banks overwhelmingly approved the merger last November. The combined bank, to be called the Shawmut National Corporation, will have assets of about $25 billion.

headline: Noriega Calls for U.S. Military to Leave
abstract: LEAD: Gen. Manuel Antonio Noriega, the military ruler of Panama, said today that he wanted United States military headquarters in Latin America to be withdrawn from Panama.

headline: Contra Bases Called Target Of Managua
abstract: LEAD: The Nicaraguan attack along the Honduran border appears primarily aimed at rebel supply bases in Honduras that support anti-Government operations in northern Nicaragua, according to United States military officials.

headline: U.S. Cites Asian Piracy
abstract: LEAD: The United States is not satisfied with Asian efforts to end piracy of patents and other intellectual property rights, a senior State Department official said Friday.

headline: Patents; A Digital Watch
abstract: LEAD: A watch named Equium, manufactured by Equitime Inc. of Briarcliff Manor, N.Y., displays the hour numerically in the center of its face, with the number of minutes before or after the hour shown numerically at the left or right. Berj A. Terzian, president of the company, was awarded patent 4,720,823 this week for the push-pull, stem-controlled digital display, which avoids the push-buttons previously required.

abstract: LEAD:  General Assembly

headline: Bond Index Market Ends
abstract: LEAD: The Chicago Board of Trade has suspended trading in its five-month-old Corporate Bond Index futures contract because of a lack of volume. The contract is based on an index of bonds issued by 100 United States corporations. The Commodities Futures Trading Commission has approved ''dormant status'' for the contract, so the exchange could revive it later.

headline: EXILED IRANIANS PRESS A POLITICAL CAUSE FROM IRAQ
abstract: LEAD: With a softened ideology and assertions of battlefield prowess, Iran's principal exiled opposition movement, crushed during the Islamic revolution, is seeking to project itself as a new force in this region's conflicts.

headline: Frozen Food Unit For United Biscuit
abstract: LEAD: United Biscuits Holdings P.L.C., a leading cookie maker, which owns the Keebler Company of Elmhurst, Ill., agreed to buy a big British frozen foods business from Hanson TrustP.L.C. for $:335 million, or about $620 million. Hanson, a conglomerate with holdings in Britain and the United States, bought the frozen foods company, Ross Young's, in 1986 when it took over Imperial Group P.L

headline: GAF Shuns Takeover Law
abstract: LEAD: The GAF Corporation said yesterday that it had decided to exempt itself from the recently enacted Delaware law that limits hostile takeovers.

headline: WALDHEIM ASSAILS 'SLANDERS,' VOWS NOT TO STEP DOWN
abstract: LEAD: Despite the deepening divisions in Austria and growing calls for his resignation, President Kurt Waldheim told his nation today that he would ''not retreat in the face of slanders, hateful demonstrations and wholesale condemnations.''

headline: American Home Enters Limelight
abstract: LEAD: In an era when companies with new wonder drugs are the darlings of the investment world, the American Home Products Corporation has been something like a church deacon: solid and respectable but hardly flashy.

headline: France Frees Bomb Suspect, But Denies Deal for Hostages
abstract: LEAD: A man suspected of organizing a bombing campaign in Paris that killed 13 people and wounded more than 200 others in 1986 was released from detention today.

headline: Will He Run? Secret Is Kept By Mitterrand
abstract: LEAD: On a quiet curving street between the Pont d'Alma and the Eiffel Tower, President Francois Mitterrand's campaign headquarters is ready. A sign on the brick facade of 7 avenue Franco-Russe says that a school has moved from the four-story building to another address.

headline: Italian Doubles Offer for Belgique
abstract: LEAD: Carlo de Benedetti doubled his public offer tonight for Societe Generale de Belgique's shares, from 4,000 Belgian francs a share, or about $113, to 8,000 francs in an attack on the French-Belgian coalition that claims to have 52 percent of the vast holding company's capital.

headline: Beecham Drug: Positive Tests
abstract: LEAD: A study of Enimase, a drug made by Beecham Group P.L.C. of Britain to treat heart disease has shown positive results, the medical journal Lancet reported yesterday. But analysts said that sales of tissue plasminogen activator, or TPA, the genetically engineered drug made by Genentech Inc. for the treatment of heart attacks, are unlikely to be affected before 1990.

headline: Shultz to Press Eventual Goal of an Israeli Pullout
abstract: LEAD: Secretary of State George P. Shultz plans to seek agreement among Israelis and Arabs on a set of principles linking an interim plan for self-administration in the Israeli-occupied territories with the ultimate goal of territorial compromise, a well-placed State Department official said today.

headline: German Enthusiasm Builds For Volkswagen Stock Sale
abstract: LEAD: All of the West German Government's 4.8 million shares of Volkswagen A.G., which go on sale Thursday, are likely to be bought quickly, analysts predicted today.

headline: A Gorbachev Ally Calls Latest Changes 'Fiction'
abstract: LEAD: A member of Mikhail S. Gorbachev's economic brain trust today published an unusually strong critique of the country's latest economic innovations, saying the measures introduced throughout most of Soviet industry just four days ago were ''a fiction.''

headline: Report Sees Hope for Battered Environment
abstract: LEAD: The decline in the earth's environmental health can be reversed, but only with a substantial investment by the rich nations, according to the 1988 State of the World report published by the Worldwatch Institute.

headline: Grace's Profit At $50.1 Million
abstract: LEAD: Bolstered by strong performances by its specialty chemicals, energy and general business operations, W. R. Grace & Company reported yesterday that it had a net income of $50.1 million, or 59 cents a share, in the fourth quarter of 1987, in contrast to a loss of $559.9 million in the quarter a year earlier.

headline: Castro Defends Noriega on Drugs
abstract: LEAD: Calling portions of a former Panamanian official's Senate testimony ''lies and slanders,'' President Fidel Castro of Cuba said he would be willing to travel to Washington to rebut testimony against Gen. Manuel Antonio Noriega of Panama. But Mr. Castro said a visit to Washington would have to include discussion of other issues, which he did not specify.

headline: Airbus Gives U.S. Warning
abstract: LEAD: The president of Airbus Industrie, the European aircraft consortium, today threatened to bring trade actions against America's leading aircraft makers if they file trade suits against his company.

headline: Ortega to Ask Madrid Role 871
abstract: LEAD: President Ortega says that during his trip to Spain this week, he will ask the Madrid Government to become active in Central American peace efforts.

headline: Soviet Scraps a New Atomic Plant In Face of Protest Over Chernobyl
abstract: LEAD: The Soviet authorities have abandoned construction of a nuclear power plant near the Black Sea in the face of public opposition generated by the 1986 accident at the Chernobyl atomic power station, a Soviet newspaper reported today.

headline: Pennsylvania Power Offering
abstract: LEAD: The Pennsylvania Power and Light Company is offering $125 million of 9 1/4 percent first-mortgage bonds, due in 1998, at a price of 99.68 to yield 9.30 percent, through underwriters led by the First Boston Corporation.

headline: South Africa Reports Attack By Zimbabwe-Based Rebels
abstract: LEAD: Guerrillas attacked a white farmer's house with rockets and firearms early today, then fled across the border into Zimbabwe, the Government said.

headline: From Screen to Solid 3-D Model In a Matter of Minutes
abstract: LEAD: A GRADUATE student at the University of Texas has invented a device that builds three-dimensional models of objects only minutes after they have been designed on a screen using computer graphics. The inventor, Carl R. Deckard, likens the device to a three-dimensional laser printer that is capable of producing a solid object rather than a two-dimensional representation of the object.

headline: 6 Bids Cited For Unit of Federated
abstract: LEAD: Federated Department Stores has received six bids for its Ralphs Supermarkets division, its only food operation, the Campeau Corporation said in an amended offering statement yesterday.

headline: Four Experts Assess How Much You Can Reasonably Deduct
abstract: LEAD: While cautioning that everyone's return must be considered individually, four experts found the following deductions reasonable for the family situations described. This is not to warn taxpayers away from taking larger deductions if they are entitled to them and have adequate records. Nor should anyone with smaller actual deductions beef them up.

headline: Tokyo Stock Recovery Stirs Concern
abstract: LEAD: Less than five months after the collapse of the world's financial markets, the Tokyo Stock Exchange is fast approaching its pre-crash highs. The Nikkei Index of 225 selected stocks is now only 4.3 percent off its peak at a time when the Dow Jones industrial average is still about 25 percent below its high of 2,722,42.

headline: Debt
abstract: LEAD: Florida Department of Natural Resources is tentatively offering $25 million of tax-exempt ''Save Our Coast'' revenue bonds through underwriters led by Smith Barney, Harris Upham & Co. The bonds, insured by the Municipal Bond Investors Assurance Corporation, yield from 5.60 percent for an issue due in 1989 to 8 percent in 2012; they are rated triple A.

headline: Cocoa Prices At 5-Year Low
abstract: LEAD: World cocoa prices slipped to the lowest levels in more than five years Friday as the International Cocoa Organization reported little progress toward propping up prices in talks between producing and consuming nations.

headline: NORIEGA EXPECTED TO CLING TO POWER, PANAMANIANS SAY
abstract: LEAD: The indictment of Panama's military leader, Gen. Manuel Antonio Noriega, in the United States on drug charges has stiffened his resistance and makes the likelihood of his peaceful departure from power more remote, Panamanian civilians, military officers and foreign diplomats say.

headline: Eritrean Rebels Claim Big Victory Over Ethiopia
abstract: LEAD: Eritrean rebels fighting the Ethiopian authorities say they killed or captured 18,000 Government soldiers and seized three Soviet military advisers in an offensive that they said had ''broken the backbone of the Ethiopian Army'' in Eritrea.

headline: Mauritius Seeks to Regain Island With U.S. Base
abstract: LEAD: This island state still wishes it could regain sovereignty over the faraway island of Diego Garcia, which the United States has turned into a military base in the Indian Ocean.

headline: Telephones: Winners and Losers Might Change Places
abstract: LEAD: In the telephone industry the winners of recent years seem likely to lose their momentum in 1988, while losers of the recent past could be the companies to watch.

headline: New Sheen for the 'Welfare Banks'
abstract: LEAD: NATHAN SHANE licked his counting finger, scooped up a check and identification card from a rumpled, bent-over woman and began nimbly counting dollars.

headline: Advertising; A Captive Audience for Magazine

headline: Shift of Titles Atop Ogilvy
abstract: LEAD: William E. Phillips, the 58-year-old chairman and chief executive of the Ogilvy Group, said yesterday that he would relinquish his titles to Kenneth Roman, 57, the chairman of Ogilvy's largest operating company, Ogilvy & Mather Worldwide, at the firm's annual shareholder meeting on May 17.

headline: Stocks Gain Broadly; Dow Rises 47.58
abstract: LEAD: Stock prices moved strongly higher across a broad front yesterday, with the Dow Jones industrial average jumping 47.58 points, or 2.5 percent, to 1,962.04.

headline: Trustee Is Urged For Sharon Steel
abstract: LEAD: The Sharon Steel Corporation's creditors have asked a Federal bankruptcy judge to appoint a trustee to run the company since the chairman, Victor Posner, has failed to agree on restructuring the board of directors. headline: Chrysler in Europe
abstract: LEAD: The Chrysler Corporation's return to Europe after nine years' absence will begin in March with a program to sell cars in five nations, a spokesman said in Paris. Alexander Demuth said that Chrysler was initially planning to sell in West Germany, which is Europe's largest car market; Belgium; Switzerland; the Netherlands, and Austria.

headline: Texaco Said to Examine a Buyout
abstract: LEAD: Top executives of Texaco Inc. have taken a close look at a management-led buyout as one way to protect the company's independence, Wall Street sources disclosed yesterday.

abstract: LEAD: CIT Group Holdings Inc., a unit of the Manufacturers Hanover Corporation, is offering $500 million worth of floating-rate renewable notes with a final maturity in 1998 through underwriters led by Merrill Lynch Capital Markets.

headline: Soviet Arms Doctrine in Flux: An Emphasis on the Defense
abstract: LEAD: The Soviet Union is making fundamental changes in its strategic military doctrine, from one of offense to defense, American military experts and scholars agree.

headline: Advertising; Several Large Accounts Move to New Agencies
abstract: LEAD: A good number of agencies ended last week with new business assignments.

headline: Real Estate; Central Park Vista From New Tower
abstract: LEAD: WHILE debate continues over the future of the New York Coliseum building at the west side of Columbus Circle, another tower has been rising just south of the Coliseum. It is a 55-story square residential condominium called Central Park Place, and it is replacing the cluster of low-rise buildings that represented the

headline: Coca-Cola Unit To Buy Bottlers
abstract: LEAD: Coca-Cola Enterprises Inc., the bottling subsidiary created by the Coca-Cola Company in 1986, said it was buying several bottling operations from the large soft-drink manufacturer for $500 million. Last week, the parent company said it would reorganize its American subsidiary, Coca-Cola U.S.A., to respond to changes in its bottling operations.

headline: Switzerland Extradites Fugitive Italian Financier
abstract: LEAD: A financier accused of masterminding a web of criminal and political conspiracies involving many of the most powerful men in Italy was extradited from Switzerland today in a predawn police operation, officials said.

headline: Group Meets On Multifoods
abstract: LEAD: Bregman Partners, an investment group led by the Bregman and Belzberg families of Canada, has met with the International Multifoods Corporation to discuss buying ''certain operating divisions'' of the food processing company, based in Minneapolis. In a Securities and Exchange

headline: New Bid Made For Dyncorp
abstract: LEAD: Dyncorp, which had agreed to be acquired for $216 million by a group led by its chairman, Jorge E. Carnicero, said today that a separate management group had made a new takeover offer. Anaylsts said the new offer, from DME Holdings Inc., was worth $1 a share more than the Carnicero bid, or about $226 million in all.

headline: France Criticizes East German Chief on Arms
abstract: LEAD: On his first visit to a Western country responsible for the security of Berlin, Erich Honecker, the East German leader, met polite but firm disagreement here today on human rights and arms control.

headline: U.S. Informs China High-Tech Exports Could Be Widened
abstract: LEAD: The Reagan Administration is considering relaxing restrictions on the export of high technology to China after determining that China is no longer selling Silkworm missiles to Iran, Administration officials said today.

headline: Singer Backs Bid
abstract: LEAD: The Singer Company's board of directors approved a once-hostile $1.06 billion takeover bid by a group led by the Florida investor Paul A. Bilzerian, and it recommended shareholders tender their stock. The Montvale, N.J., military electronics company said in a statement that its board considered the $50-a-share offer ''fair and in the best interests of the company.

headline: Soviet Says It Used Troops to Quell Riots in South
abstract: LEAD: Military forces were called in to quell rioting in a southern Soviet city Sunday and have remained there to enforce a nighttime curfew, the Government said today.

headline: Moscow Journal; Armenian Forsakes the Liturgy to Tend His Flock
abstract: LEAD: For three Sundays running, the Rev. Tiran Guredzhian has been unable to conduct services at the little pink Church of the Sacred Assumption in Moscow.

headline: Prices Paid to Farmers Fell by 3% in December
abstract: LEAD: The prices that farmers received for raw products declined 3 percent in December, from the November average, the Agriculture Department said today.

headline: Savings Unit Note Offering
abstract: LEAD: Federal regulators for the savings and loan industry in the Southwest said today they would try to lower the cost of funds for savings institutions in the region by issuing up to $4 billion in notes backed by certificates of deposit guaranteed by the Federal Savings and Loan Insurance Corporation.

headline: Meese and the Pipeline: The Story So Far
abstract: LEAD:  1980: War breaks out between Iran and Iraq, and Iran shuts off Iraq's access to the Persian Gulf, through which Iraq had previously shipped most of its oil exports.  1982: Syria, sympathetic to Iran, shuts down an oil pipeline carrying Iraqi oil to the Mediterranean. Iraq, desperate for funds to finance its conflict with Iran, begins shipping its oil across Turkey and Jordan and negotiating with Turkey, Jordan and Saudi Arabia for rights to build permanent pipelines.

headline: Amendment Made To Carteret Offer
abstract: LEAD: The Home Group Inc., a New York insurance company, and Carteret Bancorp Inc., which owns the Carteret Savings Bank of Morristown, N.J., said they had amended the takeover agreement that was reached last August. Under the revised deal, Home Group's offer price was reduced to $19 a share in cash, or about $232 million, from $22.50 a share, or about $320 million.

headline: S.E.C. Sets Canada Pact
abstract: LEAD: The Securities and Exchange Commission and Canadian securities regulators plan to sign a joint agreement Thursday that will expand the cooperation between the two countries in securities fraud cases, the S.E.C. announced today.

headline: Plane Supplying Contras Crashes; 11 Believed Killed in Nicaragua
abstract: LEAD: A DC-6 cargo plane on a supply mission to contra guerrillas crashed inside Nicaragua Saturday night, apparently killing 11 Nicaraguan crewmen and cargo handlers.

headline: Brother of Korea's Ex-President Arrested
abstract: LEAD: Chun Kyung Hwan, the younger brother of former President Chun Doo Hwan, was arrested early today on charges of embezzlement and influence peddling.

headline: K Mart Net Increases 12.7%
abstract: LEAD: The K Mart Corporation reported yesterday that earnings in the fourth quarter of its latest fiscal year rose 12.7 percent on a 7.2 percent increase in sales.

headline: Article 081988 -- No Title
abstract: LEAD: The United States Government had a budget deficit of $23.9 billion in February, the fifth month of the current fiscal year, the Treasury Department said today.

headline: Why Managers Resist Machines
abstract: LEAD: WHEN Procter & Gamble decided five years ago to build a manufacturing plant, the plans included so much electronic monitoring equipment that executives at headquarters, 500 miles away, would have been able to check the plant's exact output at any time.

headline: Massachusetts Ratings Raised
abstract: LEAD: The bond ratings of Massachusetts were raised yesterday by Moody's Investors Service and the Standard & Poor's Corporation, just a few days before the commonwealth plans to sell $200 million of bonds.

headline: Intel to Market Micron's Chips
abstract: LEAD: As expected, the Intel Corporation and Micron Technology Inc. today announced an agreement under which Intel would sell Micron's computer memory chips under the Intel label.

headline: Villagers in the Golan Heights Battle Israeli Police
abstract: LEAD: Druse villagers in the Golan Heights, which Israel captured from Syria in 1967, battled the police today to protest Israeli rule over the area, as sporadic unrest continued in the Israeli-occupied West Bank and Gaza Strip.

headline: Determined Bidders for Federated; One Success After Another for Macy Head
abstract: LEAD: It remained unclear yesterday which of the two competing bids for Federated Department Stores Inc. would prevail. But investors seemed to agree that the newest offer, from R. H. Macy & Company, was no better than the one from the Campeau Corporation. Federated's stock rose only $1.25, to $67.75, in heavy trading yesterday.

abstract: LEAD: Fewer Americans are rushing to file their Federal income tax returns this year as they grapple with the new rules of the Tax Reform Act of 1986. Returns are due by April 15. headline: Pope Gives Ortega a Cool Reception
abstract: LEAD: Pope John Paul II offered President Daniel Ortega Saavedra of Nicaragua a markedly cool reception at the Vatican today and then sternly advised the Sandinista leader that respect for human rights and democracy was necessary to achieve peace in Central America, Vatican officials said.

headline: Advertising; Wide Range Of Efforts by Geer, DuBois
abstract: LEAD: DIVERSITY of interests is a quality that generally sets advertising people's workday apart from that of run-of-the-mill business types.

headline: 34 Die in Punjab in 2 Days Of Bombings and Ambushes
abstract: LEAD: At least 34 people have been killed in 24 hours in bombings and ambushes by Sikh separatists in Punjab, news reports said today.

headline: COMPANY BRIEFS
abstract: LEAD: * Allegheny International, Pittsburgh, said it had called a meeting of the holders of its $11.25 cumulative preferred stock for March 2 in Pittsburgh to elect two additional directors to the company's board as requested by a shareholder, Spear, Leeds & Kellogg.

headline: C.P.A. Role Under Study
abstract: LEAD: Congress will turn its attention again today to the system under which certified public accountants act as watchdogs over publicly held companies.

headline: Latin Loan Agency's New Chief
abstract: LEAD: Among the nearly three million Uruguayans the prevailing view is that an accident of birth is the only thing keeping Enrique Iglesias from being their next elected President.

headline: Botha Under Fire for Exonerating Soldiers Accused of Killing Black
abstract: LEAD: Lawyers and opposition politicians criticized President P. W. Botha today for intervening to prevent the trial of six soldiers charged with murdering a prominent black nationalist in South-West Africa, the South African-run territory also known as Namibia.

headline: Schmertz, Mobil's Warrior, Said to Plan Own Business
abstract: LEAD: Herbert Schmertz, whose combative responses to critics of the Mobil Corporation and the oil industry made him the nation's best-known corporate public relations executive during the 1970's, is said to be preparing to leave the company to set up his own business.

headline: Cement Maker Rejects Offer
abstract: LEAD: Moore McCormack Resources Inc. today rejected a $308.3 million tender offer by a rival cement maker, Southdown Inc., and said it was talking with unidentified third parties about a possible leveraged buyout.

headline: A Risky Role In Honduras; U.S. Show of Support Could Easily Escalate
abstract: LEAD: The Reagan Administration's decision to send more than 3,000 troops to Honduras is so far largely a symbolic gesture of support for Honduras after a Sandinista attack on contra bases along the border, according to diplomats in the region.

headline: U.S. Believes Plan to Ease Out Panama's Leader Is Still Alive
abstract: LEAD: The Reagan Administration believes that a Panamanian plan to move the military-backed Government of Gen. Antonio Manuel Noriega toward democracy remains a viable framework for negotiations despite a rift between the Panamanian leader and the plan's author, State Department officials said today.

headline: New President Picked By Columbia Savings
abstract: LEAD: Lawrence K. Fish found his calling as an international banker only after spending a year on a fellowship visiting 20 countries. Deciding, in effect, to become an expatriate, he forsook his training as a journalist and returned to Brazil, where he eventually went to work for the Bank of Boston.

headline: Colt to Go Private for $660 Million
abstract: LEAD: Colt Industries said yesterday that its directors had approved a $660 million buyout led by senior management and a Morgan Stanley & Company investor group.

headline: Saudis Behead Four
abstract: LEAD: Four Saudi citizens and a Sudanese expatriate, all convicted murderers, were beheaded Friday in Riyadh, the Interior Ministry said.

headline: Paine Webber Is Charged
abstract: LEAD: The E. F. Hutton Group Inc. and Shearson Lehman Brothers Inc. have begun criminal proceedings in Switzerland against Paine Webber Inc. and four of its employees on charges that include stealing client records and brokerage business from Hutton, the investment firms said yesterday.

headline: Arena Stampede Kills More Than 80 in Nepal
abstract: LEAD: More than 80 people were killed and hundreds were injured today when soccer fans were trampled in a stampede to get out of a hailstorm, witnesses and hospital sources said.

headline: Salant Will Buy Clothing Company
abstract: LEAD: Manhattan Industries agreed yesterday to be acquired by the Salant Corporation, another New York clothing company, for $100 million. Manhattan agreed to the merger after Salant raised its bid to $18.50 a share of common stock. Its initial, unsolicited offer, on Feb. 2, was $16 a share.

headline: VOWS BATTLE FOR ISLAMIC STATE
abstract: LEAD: The leader of a powerful Afghan guerrilla party and major recipient of covert American military assistance, whose aim is a ''pure'' Islamic state, consistently accuses the United States of conspiring with the Soviet Union against Afghanistan.

abstract: LEAD: It is back to the barricades for corporate America.
