headline: Kuwait-B.P. Link
abstract: LEAD: Kuwait has told Britain that it does not plan to use its big stake in the British Petroleum Company to control the oil giant. In a short statement, the British Treasury said, ''The Kuwaiti authorities have assured us that they have no ambitions to control British Petroleum, nor any interest in any management role, and that the Kuwait Investment Office holding in the company is intended as a long-term investment.

headline: Stake in Orion Up
abstract: LEAD: For the second time in less than a week, John W. Kluge, the chairman of the Metromedia Corporaiton, has increased his stake in the Orion Pictures Corporation. In a filing with the Securities and Exchange Commission, Mr. Kluge said he had raised his stake in Orion to 23 percent from 21.9 percent, purchasing 176,200 additional Orion shares in the open market for prices ranging from $12.125 to $12.875 a share.

headline: Japan Seeks Stake In American Tires
abstract: LEAD: Bridgestone Tire agreed to pay $1 billion for 75 percent of Firestone in what is believed to be the largest Japanese investment yet in an American manufacturer. Firestone is the nation's third-largest tire maker, with $2.6 billion of tire sales annually. But after the deal, its largest business will be 1,500 retail stores that sell tires and other automotive goods and services.

headline: SONY, IN A SHIFT, TO MAKE VHS UNITS
abstract: LEAD: The Sony Corporation, which popularized the home video cassette recorder with its Betamax in 1975, announced today that it would sell the rival VHS system that has come to dominate the market.

headline: Orion Pictures
abstract: LEAD: John W. Kluge, the chairman of Metromedia Inc., disclosed that he had increased his stake in the Orion Pictures Corporation. In a filing with the Securities and Exchange Commission, Mr. Kluge said he had raised his holdings in the motion picture and television production concern to 24 percent, from 23 percent.

headline: Citicorp Unit Cuts 85 Jobs in London
abstract: LEAD: Citicorp Investment Bank Ltd. said it would cut 85 jobs in its London securities division, or just under 4 percent of its staff. The investment bank has 2,200 employees. Citicorp, based in New York, has a total work force of 4,500 in Britain.

headline: Apple Buying Software Unit
abstract: LEAD: Apple Computer Inc. said today that it had agreed to acquire the Network Innovations Corporation, its first acquisition of another computer technology company.

headline: U.N. Chief Calls for Urgent Action By Council on Arab-Israel Accord
abstract: LEAD: Secretary General Javier Perez de Cuellar called on the Security Council today to begin an urgent effort to end the Arab-Israeli conflict, saying a political solution was the only way to insure the safety of Palestinians in the occupied West Bank.

headline: Korean Trade Surplus Soars
abstract: LEAD: South Korea's trade surplus more than doubled in 1987 to a record $6.55 billion, the Trade and Industry Ministry reported today.

headline: JAPAN MAY YIELD ON PUBLIC WORKS
abstract: LEAD: Prime Minister Noboru Takeshita of Japan will tell President Reagan this week that he is ready for negotiations to open some public works projects to foreign construction companies, Japanese officials said today.

headline: New Yorkers & Co.; A Real Estate Collector Seeks a Soapbox
abstract: LEAD: Philip Pilevsky thinks big thoughts, about international peace and brotherhood, about disarmament and terrorism, but as a collector of shopping centers he doesn't have much opportunity to exercise them. ''You don't need a Ph.D. to make money in real estate,'' he said.

headline: Treasury Bonds Rise Moderately
abstract: LEAD: Prices of Treasury notes and bonds posted moderate gains yesterday in trading marked by sharp changes in market sentiment throughout the day. Meanwhile, Treasury bill rates were slightly lower, reflecting a continued easing of short-term credit conditions.

headline: Reversal on 'Star Wars'; U.S. Adopts Moscow's View That the Issue Cannot Be Ignored in Strategic Arms Talks
abstract: LEAD: The United States is taking a new approach to strategic arms talks that stems from a worry that a new treaty could otherwise be a disturbing source of misunderstanding.

headline: Baker Proposes a 'Club' of Free-Trading Nations
abstract: LEAD: Treasury Secretary James A. Baker 3d threatened today to form a club of free-trading countries that would keep out nations that do not reduce their barriers to imports.

headline: Soviet Schools Sharply Faulted By Top Official
abstract: LEAD: A senior Soviet leader said today that the education system is afflicted with underfinancing, rigid central control and physical conditions so primitive that 40 percent of schools have no indoor toilets.

headline: Eastern Appeals Shuttle Decision
abstract: LEAD: Eastern Air Lines filed an appeal today of a Federal judge's rulings that barred the carrier from selling its East Coast air shuttle service and threatened hefty fines if the company proceeded with the deal. The airline asked United States District Judge John H. Pratt to reverse his own March 10 contempt finding against Eastern for trying to sell the shuttle, said John J.

headline: G.S.A. Is Extending Phone Contract Bids
abstract: LEAD: The General Services Administration said yesterday that it would extend the deadline for submitting bids for contracts to build the Government's new telecommunications system to allow the U S Sprint Communications Corporation more time to prepare its bid.

headline: Treasury Prices Increase Slightly
abstract: LEAD: Treasury note and bond prices rose slightly yesterday, after trading in a relatively narrow range before the barrage of economic statistics to be announced today.

headline: A Dependent Fed
abstract: LEAD: To the Editor:

headline: Prospects; How The Networks Line Up
abstract: LEAD: Television's broadcast networks are facing intense competition from cable TV, independent stations and each other. The Olympics and the Presidential elections should make 1988 a good year. But not all analysts agree. What will 1988 be like for the networks?   Daniel B. Burke  President and chief operating officer, Capital Cities/ABC Inc.

headline: Hyundai to Fight Canadian Ruling
abstract: LEAD: The Hyundai Corporation said it would continue to sell its cars in Canada despite a Canadian ruling that the auto maker was dumping its product by selling it at a lower price than it charged in South Korea. Hyundai officials also said the auto maker will finish an assembly plant, now under construction in Bremont,

headline: F.D.A. Petition By Nutrasweet
abstract: LEAD: Under pressure from Federal regulators, the Nutrasweet Company said today that it would submit for review its new fat substitute.

headline: Pakistani Aides Foil Attempt To Hijack a Domestic Flight
abstract: LEAD: Two provincial government officials traveling on a Pakistan International Airlines jet subdued a man who shot a guard and was trying to hijack the plane today, Pakistani officials and the national press agency reported.

headline: The Brady Report: Dissecting the Trading; 'Unsettling Signs,' Then a Sweeping Selloff, in October Stock Plunge
abstract: LEAD: Following is an excerpt from the report of the Presidential Task Force on Market Mechanisms, which spent two months studying the October stock market collapse:  A Ripple Effect

headline: The Expanding Microwave Galaxy
abstract: LEAD: Move over, microwave popcorn. The 30-second hot fudge sundae and many other new microwave food offerings are landing in supermarkets.

headline: Navistar Outlook
abstract: LEAD: The Navistar International Corporation, the truck manufacturer that returned to profitability in 1987 after a string of losses, said it hopes for a small increase in profits this year despite the rising cost of steel and labor. Neil Springer, chairman of the Navistar International Transportation Corporation, the Chicago-based company's chief operating unit, said plans were under way to expand its trucking and parts businesses with acquisitions in related industries.

headline: Caracas Journal; The Reconstructed Rebel He Fights by the Rules
abstract: LEAD: Young, middle-class, well-educated and unabashedly inspired by the Cuban revolution, Teodoro Petkoff Malec was one of the leaders of the guerrilla war begun by Venezuela's Communists in the early 1960's to overthrow the country's new democracy.

headline: HONDURAS PULLOUT SCHEDULED BY U.S.
abstract: LEAD: The Reagan Administration said today that American forces would start leaving Honduras on Monday, about 10 days after they were deployed in response to a Nicaraguan offensive against base camps of the contra rebels.

headline: Marimekko Changes Its Spots
abstract: LEAD: THERE was never any doubt about what the inside label would say. The clothes and fabrics, with their striking design and splashes of bold color, were clearly Marimekko. But for people of a certain generation - those who came of age in the 1960's - they represented more than just a brand name: They conjured up an image and an era.

headline: Leaner Japanese Manufacturers
abstract: LEAD: After capturing big shares of markets around the world, Japanese manufacturers are now showing that they can hold on to them and still make money in spite of the strong yen.

headline: Patents; A Computer System for Restaurants
abstract: LEAD: A COMPUTER system for restaurants that allows diners to order at a terminal and play video games while they await their food was patented this week by two brothers in New York.

headline: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
abstract: LEAD: * CRI Inc., Rockville, Md., a worldwide financial services and investment company, appointed Yvonne S. Distenfeld senior vice president, general counsel.

headline: Thousands Protest Outside Waldheim's Office
abstract: LEAD: Thousands of protesters gathered outside the offices of President Kurt Waldheim today, urging him to resign, as they invoked the memory of the victims of Nazism 50 years after Hitler's troops marched into Austria.

headline: Bell & Howell Sued
abstract: LEAD: The Bell & Howell Company faces seven shareholder lawsuits, contending that the company failed to negotiate fairly with all parties during the bidding that developed between the British publisher Robert Maxwell, the New York publishing company Macmillan Inc. and the Bass family of Texas. Bell & Howell, based in Skokie, Ill., accepted an offer of $64 a share, or $647 million, from the Bass group, which also included several Bell & Howell executives.

headline: S.E.C. Charges 2 as Insiders
abstract: LEAD: The Securities and Exchange Commission today charged two employees of a unit of Schlumberger Ltd., the giant oil services concern, with illegally purchasing the stock of the Texas International Company, while in the possession of confidential information about the discovery of a major oil field by Texas International in western Egypt in early 1985.

headline: Study of Plunge Due in a Month
abstract: LEAD: By early February, the Securities and Exchange Commission staff is expected to complete its study of the October stock market collapse, the commission's chairman, David S. Ruder, said today. S.E.C. officials had hoped to have the report ready in early January.

headline: Tidy City Is Paramount For Jakarta's Governor
abstract: LEAD: The new Governor of the city of Jakarta, a national capital territory that is a little (but only a little) like the District of Columbia, has spent most of his first six months in office getting the bad news.

headline: ABUSES OF RIGHTS DECLINE IN SOVIET
abstract: LEAD: The State Department said today that human rights abuses had eased somewhat in the Soviet Union in the last year despite continued violations that remained a central concern to the United States.

headline: Opposition Parties in Seoul Fail in Effort for Unification
abstract: LEAD: An effort to forge a united opposition to the Government of President Roh Tae Woo collapsed Wednesday.

headline: From California, a Helper for Mother Teresa
abstract: LEAD: The former Governor of California, Edmund G. Brown Jr., is spending three to four weeks in this impoverished city working with patients at Mother Teresa's Home for Dying Destitutes.

headline: Shultz Ends Mideast Tour Upbeat but Empty-Handed
abstract: LEAD: Secretary of State George P. Shultz ended his swing through the Middle East today without the general accord he had sought on principles of negotiation but with enough encouragement from the parties to lean toward a return trip at the end of the week.

headline: Data General Profits Up
abstract: LEAD: The Data General Corporation said today that its profits had soared in its fiscal first quarter as shipments rose and cost-cutting efforts took hold. The computer maker said its net income totaled $12.4 million in the quarter that ended last Dec. 26, compared with $3.3 million for the corresponding quarter in 1986.

headline: A New Twist in Offer For Giant in Belgium
abstract: LEAD: When Carlo de Benedetti, the Italian financier, began his attack from the south, Societe Generale de Belgique, Belgium's largest holding company, was forced to seek help from a neighbor to the north.

headline: EXECUTIVES
abstract: LEAD: * American Express Travel Related Services Co., appointed Bonnie Stedt senior vice president, human resources.

headline: Takeover Law In Ohio Upheld
abstract: LEAD: A Federal judge rejected a claim by an Italian tire maker that Ohio's anti-takeover law is unconsitutional.

headline: Japan Tourism Abroad
abstract: LEAD: The number of Japanese tourists going overseas rose by 23.3 percent, to 6.8 million, in 1987, mainly because of the strength of the yen, Japan Travel Bureau Inc., a leading Japanese travel agency, said today.

headline: Goldman, Sachs Ends Program Trading for Itself
abstract: LEAD: One day after the New York Stock Exchange announced new restrictions on program trading, Goldman, Sachs & Company said yesterday that it would no longer use the strategy to manage its own capital. However, the institutional firm will continue to execute such trades for its customers.

headline: Newest Headache for Hanoi: A 5,000-Dong Currency Note
abstract: LEAD: Warning that a strong black-market economy has the potential to sabotage the policies of the new Communist leadership, Vietnam has issued a new series of currency notes.

headline: Computers: A Potential Boom Faces Uncertainties
abstract: LEAD: Rarely has the computer industry entered a new year so uncertain whether it would soar or stagnate.

headline: BRIEFS
abstract: LEAD:  Debt

headline: Senate Panel Approves Banking Bill
abstract: LEAD: After a marathon negotiating session, the Senate Banking Committee overwhelmingly approved a compromise bill that would give banks large new powers to underwrite securities but would place limits on their further expansion into the sale of insurance.

headline: NASDAQ NATIONAL MARKET SYSTEM
U.S. Drops a Warrant In '85 Ship Hijacking
abstract: LEAD: The Justice Department has withdrawn the arrest warrant it issued two years ago for Mohammed Abbas, who also uses the name Abul Abbas, in connection with the hijacking in 1985 of the Italian cruise ship Achille Lauro and the murder of an American passenger, a department spokesman said today.

headline: Mitterrand, Dispelling Doubts, Stands for Re-election
abstract: LEAD: Ending months of speculation, President Francois Mitterrand, a 71-year-old Socialist, said tonight that he would seek a second seven-year presidential mandate.

headline: NEGLIGENCE IS SEEN IN PARTS OF CANAL CEDED TO PANAMA
abstract: LEAD: The Panamanian Government has been mismanaging sections of the former Panama Canal Zone and installations important to the canal that have already been handed over by the United States, according to Panamanian employees of the canal and shipping industry experts here.

headline: Advertising; Search Is Narrowed to 3 By United Jersey Banks
abstract: LEAD: United Jersey Banks, Princeton, N.J., has narrowed its search for an ad agency. Still in the running are three New York shops: Geer, DuBois plus Hill, Holliday, Connors, Cosmopulos and McCaffrey & McCall. The previous budget was estimated at more than $2 million.

headline: About Real Estate; Astoria Housing Features a River View
abstract: LEAD: Despite its broad view of Manhattan, the waterfront in Astoria, Queens, has not attracted much residential construction because of its industrial character.

headline: Japan Posts A Trade Deficit
abstract: LEAD: Japan posted a trade deficit for the first 20 days in January, but Government officials and economists said today that the unusual shortfall probably did not indicate a trend.

headline: G.M. Plans to Drop Two Small Autos
abstract: LEAD: The General Motors Corporation said it planned to discontinue two cars at the end of the current model year. The Cadillac Division will discontinue the Cimarron, a compact car introduced in 1981. The Oldsmobile Division will retire the Firenza subcompact, which was introduced in 1982. Sales of both cars have declined.

headline: U.S. and Lisbon to Negotiate On Air Base Treaty Problems
abstract: LEAD: Portugal and the United States agreed today to reopen talks on an agreement that allows the United States to use a military base in the Azores in exchange for military and economic aid.

headline: Airbus Suffers As Dollar Falls
abstract: LEAD: The steep fall of the dollar has created a catastrophic situation for Airbus Industrie, the European commercial aircraft consortium, the Foreign Trade Minister of France, Michel Noir, said in an interview published this week. Mr. Noir told the newspaper

headline: Islamic Nations End Meeting With Denunciations of Iran
abstract: LEAD: Moslem countries ended a conference today by denouncing Iran for riots in Mecca last July and for refusing to sign a cease-fire in its war with Iraq.

headline: Bethlehem Steel Bonus
abstract: LEAD: The Bethlehem Steel Corporation said Friday that it would distribute $48 million in cash and stock among 24,000 employees because their wage and benefit concessions helped Bethlehem record its first profitable year since 1981. By April 15, the workers are to receive cash payments averaging $500. Also, convertible preference stock worth an estimated $1,500 will be credited to each worker in an employee stock ownership trust.

headline: Kirin Buys Bottler
abstract: LEAD: Japan's leading brewer said its United States subsidiary had acquired the Coca-Cola Bottling Company of Northern New England. KW Inc., a Bedford, N.H., subsidiary of the Kirin Brewery Company, bought the remaining 75 percent of the bottling company's stock for $46.5 million earlier this month, Kirin said.

headline: West to Resume Farm Aid to Ethiopia
abstract: LEAD: The World Bank and several Western nations will resume agricultural development aid to Ethiopia, which has agreed to create new incentives for food production to combat a famine, United Nations officials and diplomats say.

headline: Thatcher Uses Muscle to Retain Secrets Law
abstract: LEAD: Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher used personal lobbying and parliamentary tactics today to defeat the latest effort to rewrite Britain's Official Secrets Act.

headline: Advertising; MONY Financial Unit Chooses Korey, Kay
abstract: LEAD: MONY Financial Services, which began an agency search last summer, ended it yesterday with the announcement that it had selected Korey, Kay & Partners. The former agency was Lowe Marschalk, one of the Interpublic Group of Companies.

headline: 2 Soviet Families Defect
abstract: LEAD: Two Soviet families asked for political asylum in Turkey last week, a Foreign Ministry official said today. The spokesman, Inal Batu, said the Government was reviewing the requests and had not made a decision.

headline: FCB/Leber Establishes A Specialized Division
abstract: LEAD: FCB/Leber Katz Partners has set up the Targeted Communications Group at 101 Park Avenue with Jon Adams as its president, a staff of 80, and $60 million in billings.

headline: Advertising; Meredith Is Planning To Acquire Craftways
abstract: LEAD: The Meredith Corporation, a multi-media communications conglomerate whose flagship publication is Better Homes and Gardens, has announced its intention to acquire the Craftways Corporation of Richmond, Calif.

headline: BUSINESS DIGEST: MONDAY, MARCH 28, 1988
abstract: LEAD: THE ECONOMY  Interest rates seem unlikely to move much from recent levels, although the credit markets may be stimulated in the short term by the drop in stock prices. There is little evidence that either the economy or inflation will shoot up, analysts say. They predict that yields on the Treasury's 30-year bond are likely to remain within a range of 8.50 percent to 8.75 percent for a few weeks.

headline: In Mexico, a Fight for the Mantle of Revolution
abstract: LEAD: Mobilized by Mexico's governing party, tens of thousands of workers, peasants and civil servants gathered in front of the National Palace here Friday to hear President Miguel de la Madrid honor the memory of President Lazaro Cardenas, who, 50 years earlier, ordered the takeover of foreign oil companies.

headline: Carteret Bancorp's Merger Agreement
abstract: LEAD: Home Group Inc. said that, despite its merger agreement with Carteret Bancorp, it would allow the Delaware-based savings and loan holding company to look for a new merger partner until mid-February.

headline: NASA Challenge: Space Station Power
abstract: LEAD: ENGINEERS designing the National Aeronautics and Space Administration's permanent space station are planning for the most part to use already developed, ''off the shelf'' technology to create the station, which will be assembled in earth orbit in the mid-1990's. But one of their more demanding challenges will be supplying electricity to the station - 15 times more power than an

headline: Power Agency To Seek Ruling
abstract: LEAD: The Bonneville Power Administration said this week that it intended to file a lawsuit in Federal District Court to determine whether it can terminate two partly constructed nuclear power plants without defaulting on the plants' $3.7 billion in bonds.

headline: Continental's First Class Offered for Full Coach Fare
abstract: LEAD: Continental Airlines struck a blow at the concept of first-class service yesterday, announcing that passengers who belong to its frequent-flier program and pay the full coach fare could get first-class seats on most flights by making reservations on a first-come, first-serve basis.

headline: Gorbachev Delays Meeting With U.S. Business Leaders
abstract: LEAD: The Soviet leader Mikhail S. Gorbachev has asked to postpone a long-scheduled meeting in Moscow this month in which possible business deals were to be discussed with more than 500 American corporate leaders and Commerce Secretary C. William Verity Jr., according to American and Soviet officials. It was unclear when the meeting might be rescheduled.

headline: Apple in Pact With Digital
abstract: LEAD: Apple Computer Inc. and the Digital Equipment Corporation, as expected, formally announced a joint development effort aimed at developing products to connect Apple Macintosh machines and Digital VAX computers.

headline: C.F.T.C. Head Is Confirmed
abstract: LEAD: The Senate today approved the nomination of Wendy Lee Gramm as the next chairman of the Commodity Futures Trading Commission.

headline: PLOT TO SUBVERT REGIME IS CHARGED; Arabs Pledge Support
abstract: LEAD: Arab foreign ministers today pledged moral and financial support to Palestinians who for nearly two months have been violently protesting the Israeli occupation of the Gaza Strip and the West Bank.

headline: Whirlpool Opposes G.E.-Roper Talks
abstract: LEAD: The Whirlpool Corporation has continued to oppose a meeting between the Roper Corporation, the appliance manufacturer that has accepted its acquisition offer of $37.50 a share, and the General Electric Company, which has since offered a counterbid of $45 a share. According to a Securities and Exchange Commission filing last week, Roper asked to meet with G.E., which said any exchange of information could occur only after

headline: U.S. Petroleum Data
abstract: LEAD: In millions of barrels except refinery utilization      $      Mar 25   Mar 18   Mar 27          1988   1988   1987       Gasoline production, daily   6.8   6.8   6.4        Distillate production, daily   2.7   2.7   2.4        Gasoline stocks   230.0   234.2   245.6        Distillate stocks   93.7   98.3   106.3        Crude imports, daily   4.1   4.9   3.6        Product imports, daily   1.7   2.0   1.7        Crude stocks   344.5   344.1   329.2        Crude production, daily   8.1   8.1   8.3        Refinery utilization (%)   85.5   84.3   78.3

headline: Determined Bidders for Federated; Canada Rebuff Led Campeau Chief to U.S.
abstract: LEAD: It remained unclear yesterday which of the two competing bids for Federated Department Stores Inc. would prevail. But investors seemed to agree that the newest offer, from R. H. Macy & Company, was no better than the one from the Campeau Corporation. Federated's stock rose only $1.25, to $67.75, in heavy trading yesterday.

headline: Afghan Hints at a Soviet Reconciliation Policy
abstract: LEAD: Afghanistan's party leader, Najibullah, has suggested in recent speeches in Hanoi and Phnom Penh that the Soviet Union may be moving toward a broad policy for trying to end conflicts bleeding some of its allies in the developing world.

headline: New Support for Stronger GATT
abstract: LEAD: An international consensus is emerging in favor of strengthening the General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade, giving the organization that regulates world trade new authority to review national trade policies.

headline: Decker Raises Standard Bid
abstract: LEAD: Unwilling to abandon its effort to acquire American Standard Inc., the Black & Decker Corporation today raised its bid to $77 a share, or about $2.5 billion, from $73 a share, or $2.3 billion.

headline: TROUBLED ENTREPRENEUR: Stuart Karl; From Fonda and Hart To Flops and Hot Water
abstract: LEAD: AS he walked into the Beverly Hills Hotel one day in January 1984, Stuart Karl surely felt on top of the world.

headline: FINANCE BRIEFS
abstract: LEAD: * American Medical International Inc. is issuing 100 million Swiss francs of 5 percent Eurobonds, due in 1996, at 101, through Goldman, Sachs Finance A.G.

headline: Apple Sues Microsoft And Hewlett-Packard
abstract: LEAD: Hoping to protect a key selling point of its Macintosh, Apple Computer Inc. filed a copyright-infringement suit against the Microsoft Corporation and the Hewlett-Packard Company.

headline: Koch on Israeli Strife: Kick Out TV Crews
abstract: LEAD: Mayor Edward I. Koch of New York wrote in an Israeli newspaper today that television cameras should be barred from the occupied territories.

headline: Fox Sneakers In Agency Shift
abstract: LEAD: Travel Fox sneakers, which created quite a stir last year by running an ad featuring a male and female clad only in sweat socks and the product, have been switched to another agency.

headline: Strike in Panama Halts Most Activity in Capital
abstract: LEAD: Normal activity was paralyzed here today in the third day of a general strike called by opponents of this country's de facto ruler, Gen. Manuel Antonio Noriega. Scattered outbreaks of violence were reported.

headline: Reporter's Notebook; In Panama's Cash Crisis, Gambling Spirit Wanes
abstract: LEAD: Presidents come and presidents go, but one thing has always remained constant here. For Panamanians, the National Lottery could always be counted on to stay immune to the vicissitudes of politics and daily life.

headline: A Shift in Third World Funds' Flow
abstract: LEAD: The world's poorest and most indebted countries are beginning to get less in combined aid each year from the World Bank and the International Monetary Fund than they are paying in interest and principal on outstanding debt to the two organizations, an analysis has disclosed.

headline: Brazil Leader's Move to Rule Longer Spurs a Crisis
abstract: LEAD: In a last-ditch effort to prolong his term in office, President Jose Sarney has mounted a series of fierce attacks on a Constitutional Assembly that is preparing to call Brazil's first direct Presidential elections in almost three decades.

headline: Soviet Halts Jamming of Broadcasts to Poland
abstract: LEAD: For the first time in six years, the Soviet Union today stopped jamming broadcasts to Poland by the Voice of America and Radio Free Europe, the director of the Voice of America said.

headline: Editor Joins Revlon Unit
abstract: LEAD: Andrea Robinson, beauty editor of Vogue magazine for eight years, has resigned to become president of Ultima II, a division of Revlon Inc. Ultima II markets cosmetics treatment products and fragrances. Ms. Robinson will report to Robert A. Neilson, chairman and president of Revlon's fashion and designer group.

headline: La Prensa: Gadfly of the Sandinista Regime
abstract: LEAD: Early every afternoon, as the first copies of the opposition newspaper La Prensa roll off the presses, Nicaraguans are treated to a new round of vitriol aimed at the Sandinista Government.

headline: Tax-Exempt Market Active With Three Large Offerings
abstract: LEAD: Activity in the tax-exempt market rebounded yesterday with three new issues of more than $120 million each.

headline: Israeli Army Tries New Tactic To Break Strike by Merchants
abstract: LEAD: The Israeli Army tried to break compliance with a Palestinian strike and bulldozed an olive grove today as part of its newest measures to curb a 14-week-old revolt in the occupied territories.

headline: American's Filing
abstract: LEAD: American Airlines has filed a com-plaint with the Department of Trans-portation seeking sanction against British Airways P.L.C. for maintain-ing ''a virtual monopoly'' on its flight schedule system in Great Britian. The complaints has asked the Govern-ment to ''eliminate several unfair air-line computerized reservation sys-tem practices of British Airways.

headline: WAR AND DROUGHT INFLICTING FAMINE IN SUDAN
abstract: LEAD: Mass starvation is threatening refugees in Equatoria, a southern province of the Sudan, as rebels mine roads and prevent food convoys from reaching there.

headline: More Mexican Prices 'Dollarized'
abstract: LEAD: People here have long been fond of saying that ''no one in Mexico has ever lost money betting on the dollar.'' But the latest downturn in this nation's six-year economic crisis has given a new and added cogency to that adage.

headline: About Real Estate; New Life for Jersey Garden Apartments
abstract: LEAD: In the center of Teaneck, N.J, stands a cluster of rundown three-story brick apartment buildings optimistically called Teaneck Gardens. It is typical of hundreds of similar garden apartment developments that went up in a hurry in New Jersey shortly after World War II and by now are on the verge of decay.

headline: INDONESIAN LEADER SEEKS TO BAR VOTE
abstract: LEAD: President Suharto, who was elected to a fifth five-year term in office Thursday, has asked that a vote for Vice President be canceled.

headline: Israeli Payments Plan Cited in Memo to Meese
abstract: LEAD: Planned payments to the Government of Israel and the Israeli Labor Party were mentioned in a 1985 memo to Attorney General Edwin Meese 3d describing a proposed $1 billion Iraqi pipeline project that never was brought to fruition, according to a Swiss businessman who was a partner in the plan.

headline: An Influx of New Money Revs Up the Market
abstract: LEAD: At least 300,000 people in the United States collect old cars for love or money or both. And while the number of collectors is increasing by 5 to 10 percent a year, the real growth in the collectible car market is measured in dollars. This year, participants estimate that up to $500 million will change hands at auctions and private sales.

headline: A Surprise Resignation At Hanover
abstract: LEAD: In a move that stunned the banking world, John R. Torell 3d resigned yesterday as president of the Manufacturers Hanover Corporation. The 48-year-old executive has been with the banking company for 27 years and was widely assumed to be the heir apparent to John F. McGillicuddy, chairman and chief executive.

headline: Article 247788 -- No Title
abstract: LEAD: The World Food Program said today that it would provide food worth $36.6 million for drought victims and refugees in seven countries, the bulk of it to Ethiopia and Mozambique. The Rome-based agency said about a million people in Ethiopia and Mozambique would receive emergency supplies worth more than $24 million.

headline: Colombian Voting Marred by Political Killings
abstract: LEAD: Planned as a way of enticing leftist guerrillas to abandon decades of insurgency and accept the rules of democracy, Colombia's first municipal elections have instead been overshadowed by extremist violence and marked by abstentionism.

headline: Article 655788 -- No Title
abstract: LEAD: The failure of a leading mortgage insurer to meet its obligations has led banks and savings and loan associations to declare nearly $500 million in home mortgages in the Southwest in default.

headline: Advertising; People
abstract: LEAD: * Edward Haymes will join J. Walter Thompson later this month as executive vice president for finance and administration.

headline: American Given Life in I.R.A. Case in London
abstract: LEAD: An American, the first member of the Irish Republican Army to be extradited from the United States, was convicted today of killing a London policeman in 1975 and sentenced to life in prison.

headline: Portuguese Voice Dismay Over U.S. Aid Cut
abstract: LEAD: A Reagan Administration decision to cut aid to Portugal is creating political problems for Prime Minister Anibal Cavaco Silva, who has threatened in the past to scrap a treaty that allows American use of a base in the Azores Islands.

headline: Europe Research Plan
abstract: LEAD: The European Community said it was willing to spend 550 million European Currency Units, or about $670 million, to co-finance research projects in advanced telecommunications to help companies enter a world market estimated to be worth more than $600 billion. The projects involve transmitting voice, data and images quickly and cheaply.

headline: Executives
abstract: LEAD: * Air Midwest Inc., Wichita, Kan., elected as chairman Gary M. Adamson. Robert L. Priddy was named to succeed Mr. Adamson as president and chief executive.

headline: ENTIRE GAZA STRIP PUT UNDER CURFEW
abstract: LEAD: The Israeli authorities imposed a nightly curfew on the entire Gaza Strip tonight after the resignation of hundreds of Palestinian policemen there.

headline: Erie Lackawanna Files Suit on Taxes
abstract: LEAD: The president of Erie Lackawanna Inc. said that he hoped that the filing of a suit in Federal Claims Court this week would speed up a $42.5 million refund the company hopes to obtain from the Internal Revenue Service. Harry A. Zilli Jr., who is in charge of what is left of the former railroad concern, said company lawyers had been frustrated by a lack of progress through the I.R.S.

headline: Prospects
abstract: LEAD:  Global Competition

headline: Venture Capital
abstract: LEAD: When Congress eliminated the favorable treatment of capital gains in 1986, many thought it would hurt venture capital companies' ability to raise money. The Oct. 19 stock market collapse also caused alarm. But venture capital funds have more money than ever. What is the outlook for this industry?

headline: Legend Buying Fund Manager
abstract: LEAD: Legend Capital L.P., a private investment partnership, agreed this week to acquire the Delaware Management Company, a closely held money-management firm in Philadelphia with $18 billion in assets under management. The price is more than $200 million.

headline: Advertising; Philadelphia Agency Publishes Its Prices
abstract: LEAD: In an unusual move, a small Philadelphia agency has announced that it has published a price list of its services. Harris-Edward Communications is 12 years old, bills about $11.5 million and serves both business-to-business and consumer accounts.

headline: Price Limits On Futures
abstract: LEAD: The Chicago Board of Trade set permanent daily price limits on its stock index futures today, becoming the first futures market to attempt to reduce the trading volatility that some experts have blamed for worsening the October market collapse.

headline: Advertising; Accounts
abstract: LEAD: * Benjamin Franklin Savings, Houston, to the Hively Agency, also in Houston.

headline: Viacom Owner Acts on Orion
abstract: LEAD: A group led by Sumner M. Redstone, the owner of Viacom International Inc., said yesterday that it had asked Federal antitrust regulators for clearance to increase its stake in the Orion Pictures Corporation. If approved, the Redstone group said, it would increase its holdings to 36 percent of Orion's stock, from 26.8 percent.

headline: U.S. Vows Action to Close P.L.O. Mission
abstract: LEAD: United States Attorney Rudolph W. Giuliani will take legal action to force the Palestine Liberation Organization to close its observer mission to the United Nations if the P.L.O. does not do so voluntarily, a Justice Department spokesman said today.

headline: Dow Loses 27.52 to Close at 1,936.34
abstract: LEAD: Stock prices fell in moderate trading yesterday.

headline: Cheap Dollars
abstract: LEAD: To the Editor:

headline: Profit Up 14.1% At McDonald's
abstract: LEAD: The McDonald's Corporation said today that its profit for the fourth quarter of 1987 rose 14.1 percent over the period a year earlier.

headline: Southland to Sell Unit
abstract: LEAD: The Southland Corporation has agreed to sell its Dairies Group to Morningstar Foods Inc. for an undisclosed amount. Morningstar, an affiliate of the Houston-based investment firm of Duncan, Cook & Company, will buy 10 regional dairies throughout the United States, along with 25 plants and distribution points.

headline: Lilly Rejects British Fund
abstract: LEAD: Eli Lilly & Company rejected on Tuesday a demand by British lawmakers that the pharmaceutical giant set up a trust fund for victims of a discontinued anti-arthritis medication. The demand was made Monday by 100 British lawmakers who signed a letter to Richard D. Wood, Lilly chairman and chief executive officer.

headline: Surge in Platinum Sparks A Rally in Precious Metals
abstract: LEAD: Precious metals futures soared yesterday after a dramatic late rally caused frenzied buying among the large number of traders who had been betting on a decline in the prices of gold, silver and especially platinum in recent weeks.

headline: Retailers Seek to Use Scanners More
abstract: LEAD: For a dozen years, general retailers and apparel and textile manufacturers have envied the supermarket industry's black-and-white bar code, which has helped speed customers through checkouts. But the vast number of general merchandise items -in many different sizes and shapes -had seemed to be an obstacle to wider use of bar-code scanners.

headline: Truce in Border Fight By Thais and Laotians
abstract: LEAD: Thailand and Laos agreed today to a truce and disengagement in a disputed, sparsely populated border area where hundreds of their soldiers have been killed since November.

headline: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
abstract: LEAD: Best Foods Affiliates Group, Englewood Cliffs, N.J., a unit of CPC International Inc., appointed Raymond B. Rudy president.

headline: SHAMIR FOILS VOTE ON U.S. PEACE PLAN
abstract: LEAD: Prime Minister Yitzhak Shamir today blocked an attempt by his rival, Foreign Minister Shimon Peres, to force a Cabinet vote on the new peace initiative brought by Secretary of State George P. Shultz.

headline: Plan Offered In Debt Crisis
abstract: LEAD: An important business leader today called for an international agency to buy $250 billion of debt from 17 debtor countries at a discount.

headline: A Coming Filipino Vote Divides Aquino Family
abstract: LEAD: Trucks stacked high with newly harvested sugar cane on the plantation of President Corazon C. Aquino have been flying tiny banners supporting the gubernatorial candidacy of her family's choice, Candido Guiam.

headline: KEYNESIAN CRUSADER: Robert Eisner; Why Not a Bigger Budget Deficit?
abstract: LEAD: AMONG economists, Robert Eisner stands out as the man who loves the Federal budget deficit.

headline: 39.96 Rise Puts Dow At 1,956.07
abstract: LEAD: Stock prices surged broadly yesterday after the Government reported that the trade deficit in November fell substantially, driven by record exports.

headline: Corrections
abstract: LEAD: An article last Sunday about fast food restaurants misstated the time period for Kentucky Fried Chicken's financial turnaround. The company was financially sound by 1980, and in good shape when Pepsico bought it in 1986. No cash infusions were needed.

headline: ANTISMOKING CRUSADER: Richard A. Daynard; Using Liability Law To Put Tobacco On Trial
abstract: LEAD: WHEN rumors hit Wall Street in late November that Richard A. Daynard, professor of law at Northeastern University, was about to disclose something embarrassing to the cigarette industry, it was enough to send the stocks of tobacco companies down 4 percent.

headline: Oil Prices Rise After OPEC Sets a Committee Meeting
abstract: LEAD: The pricing committee of the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries will meet in Vienna in early April to review its audit of oil production, OPEC's president, Rilwanu Lukman, said today.

headline: Patents; Invent America! Project Starts Its Second Year
abstract: LEAD: The Invent America! program, which encourages student creativity, is beginning its second year, under the sponsorship of the United States Patent Model Foundation. A conference of educators is being held this weekend at the Hilton Hotel in Washington.

headline: 50 Years After His Execution, Soviet Panel Clears Bukharin
abstract: LEAD: A Communist Party commission reviewing the purge trials of the 1930's announced today that Nikolai I. Bukharin, among the most prominent victims of Stalin's terror, was wrongly convicted and executed.

headline: India's Fading Airlines Stir First-Class Hopes
abstract: LEAD: In an effort to polish the image of India's Government-controlled airlines and prepare for an anticipated surge in tourists and traffic, a band of ambitious technocrats and officials is beginning a sweeping overhaul of two big carriers.

headline: Advertising; Over All, '88 Forecasts Are Bullish
abstract: LEAD: AMONG the upper echelons of Madison Avenue there is more optimism about the immediate future than you're likely to find among the mighty of Wall Street.

headline: Unlocking Contra Aid: 4 Men Called Key
abstract: LEAD: After six years of firm commitment to the Nicaraguan rebels, the Reagan Administration is now in the position of saying that, in the end, their fate rests in the hands of four Central American Presidents who have all said the contra program is a bad idea.

headline: Shamir Defends Expulsion Move, Terming the 9 Arabs 'Incorrigible'
abstract: LEAD: Prime Minister Yitzhak Shamir today defended the army's decision to order nine Palestinian nationalists deported, saying the Gaza Strip and West Bank residents being thrown out were ''incorrigible.''

headline: Former Connecticut Banker Indicted on Insider Charges
abstract: LEAD: Two Federal grand juries, one in Boston and the other in New Haven, indicted the former chairman of a Connecticut savings bank today on charges of insider trading, perjury and other offenses in connection with a stock trading investigation of the bank's merger with a Maine savings bank in 1986.

headline: 23 Die as Missiles Hit Iraq and Iran Capitals
abstract: LEAD: Iran and Iraq fired missiles into each other's capital today, and Teheran warned it would deploy chemical bombs if the United Nations did not punish Iraq for using such weapons.

headline: F.D.I.C. to Sell Bad Loans
abstract: LEAD: The Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation plans to sell $1.8 billion in bad loans it absorbed from the 1984 bailout of the Continental Illinois National Bank and Trust Company, an agency spokesman said today.

headline: CREDIT MARKETS U.S. Note and Bond Prices Down
abstract: LEAD: Treasury note and bond prices declined modestly yesterday as securities dealers digested the $27 billion of new issues auctioned last week.

headline: Home Sales Down 3.8%
abstract: LEAD: Sales of existing single-family homes dropped 3.8 percent in December, the National Association of Realtors said today. It was the second consecutive monthly decline.

headline: Suit Challenges Auditing Plan
abstract: LEAD: A group of small and mid-sized accounting firms filed suit jointly in New York State Supreme Court yesterday seeking to block the American Institute of Certified Public Accountants from counting the votes on a member referendum that would introduce sweeping changes in the accounting profession. The judge postponed a ruling until Jan.

abstract: LEAD: Batten, Barton, Durstine & Osborn, Chicago, which became an agency of the James B. Beam Distilling Company, Deerfield, Ill., last fall, has now been assigned its Windsor Canadian whisky, which bills an estimated $6 million.

headline: I.B.M. to Add Sales Agents
abstract: LEAD: The International Business Machines Corporation, seeking to revitalize sluggish sales of mid-sized computers, said today that it would recruit more independent companies to sell those machines. The program is aimed at reaching the 4.5 million businesses that have fewer than 5,000 employees. Even I.B.M.

headline: Digital, Wang Halt Bids
abstract: LEAD: The Digital Equipment Corporation and Wang Laboratories Inc. said yesterday that they had withdrawn from the bidding for a $4.5 billion contract to supply the Air Force with more than 20,000 minicomputers.

headline: Trade Record In Germany
abstract: LEAD: West Germany, under international pressure to buy more foreign goods and sell fewer abroad, reported a record trade surplus last year, according to early official figures published today.

headline: Banks File $83 Million Suit Charging Finley, Kumble
abstract: LEAD: Four major United States banks filed suit in Manhattan Supreme Court yesterday seeking more than $83 million from the law firm of Finley, Kumble, which dissolved Jan. 4.

headline: Concessions Insufficient, Nicaragua Cleric Says
abstract: LEAD: Miguel Cardinal Obando y Bravo, who has been serving as a mediator in Nicaragua's civil conflict, said today that political concessions made by the Sandinista Government this weekend were encouraging but insufficient.

headline: WHAT'S NEW IN COMPENSATION
abstract: LEAD: IN January, corporations traditionally add the final sweetening to employee compensation packages, signing off on year-end bonuses and incentive awards. At the same time, personnel administrators re-examine compensation policies, reshaping them to meet changing company needs.

headline: DOW RISES 5.64, to 2, 023.21, IN DULL SESSION
abstract: LEAD: Stock prices traded in a narrow range yesterday, and the Dow Jones industrial average closed at 2,023.21, for a gain of 5.64 points.

headline: Advertising Account Is Lost Over Responses to Feminist
abstract: LEAD: As a direct result of its flippant responses to a complaint from a feminist, one of the nation's hottest advertising agencies has lost an account billing about $10 million annually.

headline: Shultz Expected to See Sakharov in Moscow
abstract: LEAD: To dramatize the Reagan Administration's campaign for improvement in the Soviet human-rights record, Secretary of State George P. Shultz plans to meet with Andrei D. Sakharov and other rights campaigners when he visits Moscow early next week, a senior Administration official said today.

headline: New Ban on Activity of Foes Has '60 Root
abstract: LEAD: The South African Government's crackdown this week on anti-apartheid groups is in many ways a logical progression of the process that began with the outright banning of the African National Congress and the Pan Africanist Congress in 1960.

headline: In Kabul, Military Prowess on Parade
abstract: LEAD: Helicopter gunships and jet fighters roared overhead today and dozens of armored vehicles and other weapons rumbled through the streets as the Afghan military staged a show of force in the capital.

headline: The Military Budget Helps the Economy
abstract: LEAD: Stan C. Pace, chairman and chief executive officer of the General Dynamics Corporation, the nation's second largest defense contractor, recently spoke with Business Forum editor Joel Kurtzman about spending on the military and America's industrial competitiveness. The following are excerpts from that conversation.

headline: Xtra Plans to Sell Container Business
abstract: LEAD: The Xtra Corporation said it would sell its marine cargo container operations in two separate transactions worth a total of about $180 million. The larger acquisition is by the Itel Corporation of Chicago, which will pay $130 million for 80,000 steel containers and leases on some of the containers.

headline: Mattel Closes Two Plants
abstract: LEAD: Mattel Inc. said today that it had closed two plants in the Philippines where its Barbie doll production was slowed by labor strife and that it had dismissed 4,000 workers. Doll making was transferred to the company's other plants in Asia and Mexico.

headline: A War Within the Sri Lankan War
abstract: LEAD: A brutal struggle for demographics is under way in eastern Sri Lanka, where ethnic Tamil guerrillas are slaughtering Sinhalese villagers and the Sri Lankan Army is sending the villagers back, sometimes against their wills, when they flee.

headline: INVESTING; Choosing Cyclicals Over Growth Stocks
abstract: LEAD: INVESTORS find themselves in some strange places these days. G. Kenneth Heebner, who invests $2 billion in mutual fund and pension assets at Loomis, Sayles & Co. in Boston, for example, usually buys growth stocks. And he rarely holds cash or short-term securities, in any of the five mutual funds he manages.

headline: Key Sections of Conspiracy Indictment in Iran-Contra Affair
abstract: LEAD: Following are key sections of the indictment returned by a Federal grand jury today against Rear Adm. John M. Poindexter, Lieut. Col. Oliver L. North, Richard V. Secord and Albert Hakim in the Iran-contra case.  COUNT ONE  The Conspiracy And Its Objects

headline: Early Trades For Futures
abstract: LEAD: Having provided investors in the Far East a futures trading arena with its evening session, the Chicago Board of Trade may soon seek to overlap with part of the European trading day.

headline: S.E.C. Hints At Big Cases
abstract: LEAD: David S. Ruder, chairman of the Securities and Exchange Commission, said today that his agency's staff might be required to litigate ''large fraud cases'' this year and might need more money than the agency sought in its fiscal year 1989 budget request.

headline: Mexico's Inflation Rate
abstract: LEAD: Consumer prices in Mexico soared by a record 159.2 percent last year, the Bank of Mexico announced. The bank said on Thursday that consumer prices rose by 14.8 percent in December alone, the highest one-month increase since the Government began collecting such statistics in 1968. Consumer prices rose 105.7 percent in 1986, which had been the previous record level.

headline: Czechoslovak Catholics Appealing for Rights
abstract: LEAD: More than 300,000 Czechoslovak Catholics have signed an appeal to their Government to guarantee the Roman Catholic Church fundamental rights, after the church leader threw the weight of his authority behind the petition.

headline: U.S. Denies Shift on Soviet
abstract: LEAD: The White House, the Treasury and the State Department said today that the Administration's policy opposing Soviet membership in the major international economic organizations ''remains unchanged.'' The comments came in response to an article in The New York Times on Wednesday that gave an account of the President's annual National Security

headline: Market Place; Book Publishers In the Spotlight
abstract: LEAD: TAKEOVER fever struck the dwindling band of independent book publishers after Monday's announcement that Pearson P.L.C., a British conglomerate, would acquire the Addison-Wesley Publishing Company for $283 million.

headline: Iranian Said To Link Hostage Release Gulf War
abstract: LEAD: Iran has informed Lebanon that all foreign hostages held by extremists loyal to Teheran will be released once the war in the Persian Gulf ends, Lebanese Government officials said this week.

headline: 120,000 Blacks Saved From Homeland Status
abstract: LEAD: South Africa's highest court today struck down a 1985 decision by the Government to forcibly incorporate a black community of 120,000 people into KwaNdebele, a tribal homeland.

headline: Apple Price Cuts
abstract: LEAD: Apple Computer Inc. said that the suggested retail price of its entry-level Macintosh Plus personal computer has been reduced to $1,799 from $2,199, effective immediately. Apple also reduced prices on three hard disk drives: the HD 20 SC is reduced to $1,099 from $1,299; the HD 40SC to $1,699 from $1,999, and the HD 80SC to $2,799 from $3,199.

headline: German Finance Official to Visit U.S.
abstract: LEAD: With the dollar stable and their disputes of last fall apparently settled for now, Treasury Secretary James A. Baker 3d and the West German Finance Minister, Gerhard Stoltenberg, will meet here next week to discuss trade, third-world debt and closer international coordination of economic policies.

headline: Advertising; Accounts
abstract: LEAD: * Charcuterie Tour Eiffel, which sells pates and delicatessen meats to supermarkets and specialty stores, to Image Concepts, Paramus, N.J.

headline: Plane With 137 Aboard Crashes In Mountainous Part of Colombia
abstract: LEAD: A Colombian Avianca airliner with 137 people on board crashed today minutes after taking off on a domestic flight from the northeastern town of Cucuta near the Venezuelan border, the airline reported. Officials said there was no immediate sign of survivors but at least one report said there were survivors.

headline: Advertising; Hill & Knowlton Wins Three Silver Anvils
abstract: LEAD: The Public Relations Society of America has announced the winners of its Silver Anvil Awards, the most respected prize in the field.

headline: Sale of Real Estate By First Interstate
abstract: LEAD: A subsidiary of First Interstate Bancorp said it had put up for sale $165 million worth of property, or about 24 percent of its portfolio of nonperforming real estate assets. The accelerated asset sale is part of a restructuring begun by the Los Angeles-based bank holding company last year.

headline: RIGHTIST WINNERS IN SALVADOR VOTE VOW TO SEEK UNITY
abstract: LEAD: Salvadoran rightists, victorious in national elections, said today that they would seek compromise with President Jose Napoleon Duarte, but diplomats and political analysts said they were uncertain about prospects for cooperation.

headline: HONG KONG
abstract: LEAD: In Hong Kong, the stock market underwent a devastating collapse in October that seriously harmed confidence. The market's Hang Seng index started the year at 2,568.30 and finished at 2,302.75, down about 10 percent. Its high for the year was 3,944.24 on Oct. 1.

headline: Power-Sharing Plan Falters In a South African Province
abstract: LEAD: Since white settlers began arriving here 150 years ago, Natal has been known for its magnificent beaches and mountains, its sugar cane and a brand of racial politics as conservative as any in South Africa. Now some of its leading citizens are promoting a plan for a multiracial government in the province, hoping that it will head off demands for black majority rule.

headline: Jakarta Journal; A Colonial Legacy Comes Back, but Not to Haunt
abstract: LEAD: In Southeast Asia, where Western empires once collided in the race for spices and straits, most independent nations seem perenially sensitive about their colonial legacies.

headline: Computer Trade Curb Cheers Some Investors
abstract: LEAD: For the fifth time since early February, stock prices yesterday came close to setting off the automatic ban on computerized stock trading at the New York Stock Exchange. But once again the computers were left alone as program traders backed off voluntarily.

headline: The Monthly Announcement That Makes Wall St. Sweat
abstract: LEAD: At 8:30 A.M. Friday, or a split second later, a number representing the deficit in the nation's trade for November will flash across news-service terminals from Wall Street to Tokyo. While other Government statistics have had their heyday, the trade figure is clearly the number to watch these days.

headline: North's Testimony on Casey Is Made Public
abstract: LEAD: Lieut. Col. Oliver L. North testified that he discussed specific plans with William J. Casey for covert operations that would have been financed with profits from the Iran arms sales, according to testimony made public today by the Senate Iran-contra committee.

headline: BUSINESS PEOPLE; New Chief of Cuisinarts Banking on Its Cachet
abstract: LEAD: Cachet, the elusive quality that sells perfumes and sports cars, rarely settles on utilitarian products, but when it does, investors like George K. Barnes take notice.

headline: CARLUCCI FAVORS SHIFT IN MX BASING
abstract: LEAD: Defense Secretary Frank C. Carlucci told Congress today that he was uncomfortable with the current deployment of MX long-range missiles in silos that are potentially vulnerable to Soviet attack.

headline: ARCO-Tricentrol
abstract: LEAD: ARCO said it was starting a tender offer for all American depositary receipts of Tricentrol P.L.C. at $7.10 each. The company said the offer was not conditioned on the receipt of any minimum number of A.D.R.'s, each of which represents two Tricentrol ordinary shares. ARCO said the offer was part of its previously announced plan to acquire all shares of Tricentrol, a small British oil company.

headline: E-11 UNDAUNTED BY BID FROM AMERICAN BRANDS
abstract: LEAD: E-II Holdings Inc. made it clear today that American Brands' ''Pac-Man''' ploy had not dissuaded it from trying to take over the tobacco and consumer goods giant.

headline: Advertising; Private 18-to-34 Survey Widens NBC Audience
abstract: LEAD: Like undocumented aliens who go uncounted in the census, viewers who watch television in public places like pubs and college dorms are not recorded by A. C. Nielsen, the great enumerator of audiences.

headline: Big Arbitrager Still in Custody
abstract: LEAD: Despite efforts by lawyers for John A. Mulheren to transfer him to a hospital, he remained yesterday in the Monmouth County Correctional Institution in New Jersey, according to his lawyers.

abstract: LEAD: It looks like a cross between a frog and a camel, and it is about as aerodynamic as an aardvark, but Citroen's Deux Chevaux model has long been treasured by French car lovers.

headline: STRIKE IN PANAMA HAS WIDE EFFECT
abstract: LEAD: Commerce remained at a standstill in much of Panama today on the third day of a strike called to protest the rule of Gen. Manuel Antonio Noriega.

headline: In the Occupied West Bank, Another Day of Bloodshed
abstract: LEAD: The battle started at about 1 P.M. with an obscene gesture from an Israeli soldier, and rocks hurled by Palestinians brandishing their flag.

headline: French Concern Plans To Buy CSX Oil Unit
abstract: LEAD: The CSX Corporation, a diversified transportation company, agreed to sell its oil and gas subsidiary, the CSX Oil and Gas Corporation, to the North American unit of a leading French energy concern, Total Compagnie Francaise des Petroles, for $612 million in cash.

headline: Bechtel Faces Lack of Big Projects
abstract: LEAD: The low-profile Bechtel Group has found itself in the limelight in recent weeks because of its role in an ill-fated proposal to build an oil pipeline through Iraq and Jordan.

headline: One Killed and 20 Injured by Bombs in Strikes in Bangladesh
abstract: LEAD: Hundreds of small bombs exploded across the capital of Bangladesh today, killing one man and injuring 20 at the start of the latest in a series of general strikes, the police and witnesses said.

headline: Market Place; Money Managers Still on Sidelines
abstract: LEAD: ALTHOUGH the Dow Jones industrial average was a steady gainer in February and climbed nearly 50 points on Monday, investors say they are not about to jump back into the stock market. And that sentiment, some strategists assert, is what is needed for the rally to continue.

headline: Yugoslav's Data Link Waldheim to Atrocities
abstract: LEAD: A Yugoslav adviser to an international commission investigating Kurt Waldheim said today that he had seen documents implicating the Austrian President in war crimes.

headline: Korean Oil Imports
abstract: LEAD: South Korea's crude oil imports this year are expected to drop 6.6 percent from last year, to 215 million barrels, the Energy and Resources Ministry said today.

headline: Seven Are Reported Detained in Poland as Solidarity Tries to Meet
abstract: LEAD: The police have detained at least seven opposition leaders, apparently in an effort to prevent the outlawed trade union Solidarity from convening a meeting this weekend, opposition spokesmen said today.

headline: Advertising; Franchising World Now Available to Public
abstract: LEAD: Franchising World, the year-old publication of the Washington-based International Franchise Association, is making itself available to the public on a limited number of newsstands and bookstores beginning with its January-February issue.

headline: Colombian Chief Signs An Antiterrorist Decree
abstract: LEAD: President Virgilio Barco Vargas signed an emergency antiterrorist decree today, strengthening security forces and offering rewards to informers to counter rising violence by drug traffickers and left-wing rebels.

headline: Producer Prices Up In January
abstract: LEAD: Prices at the producer level rose a surprising four-tenths of 1 percent in January, as higher food costs more than offset declines in energy prices, the Labor Department said yesterday.

headline: WHEN PROTEST IS TOO CLOSE TO EAST BERLIN
abstract: LEAD: When demonstrators in East Berlin disrupted a march last month in memory of German revolutionaries, the head of East Germany's PEN club, Heinz Kamnitzer, called the action ''as reprehensible as blasphemy.''

headline: Damascus Has Both Praise And Criticism for U.S. Effort
abstract: LEAD: The Syrian Government, in its first official comment on the Middle East peace proposals submitted by Secretary of State George P. Shultz on Friday, said today that Washington was trying to put ''an American stamp'' on what is meant to be an international effort.

headline: Kaolack Journal; Where Western-Style Politics Thrives in Africa
abstract: LEAD: Ouza and the Ouzettes, a big-time band from Dakar, had just struck up a dance tune when the candidate appeared, resplendent in an electric-blue caftan.

headline: Central Bank Is Urged for Europe
abstract: LEAD: Despite widespread skepticism and strong opposition from West Germany, the Finance Minister of France, Edouard Balladur, has been talking up the idea of forming a European central bank, in the hope of putting the matter on Western Europe's economic and political agenda.

abstract: LEAD: Leonard Samuel Skaggs Jr., chairman of the American Stores Company, may run the nation's third-largest supermarket and drugstore chain, but few know him outside his industry.

abstract: LEAD: The Federal Farm Credit Banks Funding Corporation has canceled an offering of intermediate-term bonds that was expected later this month, it announced yesterday.

headline: Europe Meat Ban Voided
abstract: LEAD: The European Court of Justice today voided a 1985 European Community law banning the marketing of hormone-treated meat in the 12-nation trade bloc.

headline: Southern Africa Diplomacy Seen at Impasse
abstract: LEAD: A major diplomatic effort by the Reagan Administration involving Angola and South Africa appears at an impasse, according to several diplomats and Government officials.

headline: Meier & Frank Officer Is Back
abstract: LEAD: Judith Hofer is returning to a former post - president and chief executive officer of Meier & Frank, the eight-store chain of department stores in Oregon - from her present position as president and chief executive of Famous-Barr, the St. Louis-based department store group.

headline: BOND PRICES ADVANCE MODERATELY
abstract: LEAD: Bond prices moved moderately higher in subdued trading yesterday as investors turned from a declining stock market to the relative stability of Government securities.

abstract: LEAD:       $      Net Income   Percent        Oct.-Dec.   Change        1987   From '86       Amoco Corp.   $377,000,000   +128.5        Black & Decker Corp.   31,100,000   +38.8        Boeing Co.   141,000,000   -26.2        Browning-Ferris Industries   50,800,000   +31.9        Consolidated Freightways   20,600,000   -8.4          Corning Glass Works   59,000,000   +72.0        Crane Co.

headline: REBUKES TO ISRAEL ARE MUTED BY U.S.
abstract: LEAD: The State Department has decided to refrain from further strong public criticism of Israel's handling of Palestinian protesters, a well-placed Administration official said today.

headline: Dangerous Paris-Dakar Race Is Endangered
abstract: LEAD: More than a month after the first cars and motorcycles roared out of the Sahara to complete the 10th Paris-to-Dakar rally, the dust has yet to settle on the world's longest and toughest motor race.

headline: British Banks Lift Rates
abstract: LEAD: Three big British banks raised their basic interest rates by half a point today, to 9 percent, after the Bank of England increased its money market rate. The central bank's move came as a surprise, but Barclays, Midland and National Westminister actrd quickly.

headline: P.L.O. 'Exodus' Ferry Faces a Sea of Trouble
abstract: LEAD: The Sol Phryne lay at rest today, a ship of a certain age and an opaque past. A sign on the gaping mouth of the ferry's car deck announced, belatedly, ''No visitors.''

headline: Muller Jordan Adds Blair Entertainment
abstract: LEAD: John Blair Communications is made up of Blair Television, a national advertising representative for a number of stations, and Blair Entertainment, which produces and syndicates TV programming.

headline: Salomon Loses $74 Million in Quarter
abstract: LEAD: Salomon Inc., the parent of one of Wall Street's largest securities firms, announced late yesterday that it lost $74 million in the fourth quarter because of trading losses stemming from the stock market collapse and a series of moves to restructure its troubled operations.

headline: Utility Stock Sale
abstract: LEAD: The Western Massachusetts Electric Company, a subsidiary of Northeast Utilities, is offering $53.5 million in preferred stock through Salomon Brothers Inc. The financing is part of a program to help lower the utility's borrowing costs. The initial annual dividend rate on the preferred stock is 6.375 percent and is effective for 62 days.

headline: Advertising; Wall Street Journal Hails I.B.M.'s Insert
abstract: LEAD: The Wall Street Journal was so pleased about the 16-page I.B.M. advertising insert it carried Friday that it heralded its coming with both print and radio ads.

headline: Armenians and Glasnost; Soviet Press Debate on Regional Discord Underlines Party Split on Democratization
abstract: LEAD: From the chaos of mass protest, strikes and ethnic violence that have rocked two southern Soviet republics, a sharp new debate has begun to emerge about what ''democracy'' means in Mikhail S. Gorbachev's Soviet Union.

headline: Israel Keeps Its Troops On Guard for Protests
abstract: LEAD: The Israeli Army kept a heavy guard on the occupied West Bank and Gaza Strip today and only minor disturbances were reported.

headline: For Women in India Prisons, a 'Grim Picture'
abstract: LEAD: An official study of women in Indian prisons says many of them are beaten, sexually molested or otherwise harassed in jail.

headline: Japan Confirms It Will Continue U.S. Quota of 2.3 Million Cars
abstract: LEAD: Japan's trade minister confirmed today that the nation would continue its quotas on automobile exports to the United States for another year, at the current level of 2.3 million cars.

headline: Hospitals Fault Limit On Heart Drug Funds
abstract: LEAD: The Reagan Administration's decision to deny Medicare payments for use of a heart attack drug that costs more than $2,000 a treatment is a form of health-care rationing, industry spokesmen asserted yesterday.

headline: 10,000, Crying 'Democracy,' March in Budapest
abstract: LEAD: More than 10,000 people chanting ''democracy'' and demanding new freedoms marched through Budapest today in the biggest anti-Government demonstration since the 1956 uprising.

headline: Iraqi's Death in Sudan Linked to Iran Faction
abstract: LEAD: A prominent Iraqi dissident was shot to death in a Sudanese hotel last weekend, and Arab diplomats in Lebanon linked his death to a plan by opponents of the Baghdad Government to establish a rival government backed by Iran.

headline: Advertising; Ritz Thrift's Long-Lived Commercial
abstract: LEAD: IF someone ever decides that commercials can be granted landmark status our first vote would be for that single enduring spot for the Ritz Thrift Shop.

headline: Sale in West by Soviet Bank Is Called the First of Its Kind
abstract: LEAD: Soviet bank said today that it was issuing 100 million Swiss francs ($75 million) of 5 percent bonds, a move bankers said was apparently the first of its kind by an enterprise incorporated in the Soviet Union.

headline: Nicaragua Reports Offensive
abstract: LEAD: Nicaragua said tonight that it had mounted a major offensive against rebel forces in northern Nicaragua.

headline: Tourism Rises in Britain
abstract: LEAD: A record number of foreign tourists, 15.6 million, spent a record amount of money, about $11 billion, in Britain last year, the Government said today.

headline: Contras Say They'll Free Captured American
abstract: LEAD: Nicaraguan rebels who have held an American volunteer for eight days say they are ready to release him, but will continue to capture foreigners they find in war zones.

headline: Business and the Law; New Wrangles In Texaco Case
abstract: LEAD: THE lawyers for Texaco Inc., after a victory in a key battle in bankruptcy court last Friday, are gearing up for a new round of legal wrangling this week, this time over a disclosure statement that is intended to provide the details on how the company plans to restructure.

headline: Cuba Economy Shrank in 1987
abstract: LEAD: Cuba's economy shrank 3.5 percent in 1987 after expanding an average 7.2 percent a year during the 1981-85 period, according to a confidential report by the central bank. It grew 1.4 percent in 1986.  The decline of Cuba's gross social product (the Communist equivalent of gross national product) confirmed that 1987 was a very difficult year for the Cuban economy.

headline: Pact in Spain to Form Nation's Biggest Bank
abstract: LEAD: Two leading Spanish banks, Banco de Bilbao and Banco de Vizcaya, have stunned the financial community here by announcing plans to merge their operations and create Spain's largest bank.

headline: COLOMBIANS GROW WEARY OF WAGING THE WAR ON DRUGS
abstract: LEAD: Shaken by the murder of the country's Attorney General last Monday, many influential Colombians have begun arguing that this country is paying too high a price for combating powerful drug traffickers.

headline: Ski Inflation
abstract: LEAD: To the Editor:

headline: News Cut Off as Armenian Protests Continue
abstract: LEAD: Armenian nationalist protests continued today in two southern Soviet republics as the authorities in Moscow moved to limit the flow of information from the area.

headline: INVESTING; Have Bonds Advanced Too Quickly?
abstract: LEAD: AFTER a dismal 1987, fixed-income securities have rebounded in a powerful rally. Prices of the key 30-year Treasury bonds, for example, have jumped 5 percent in less than a month.

headline: VLSI Names A President
abstract: LEAD: VLSI Technology Inc., a semiconductor manufacturer based in San Jose, Calif., said today that James R. Fiebiger had been named president and chief operating officer, effective Feb. 1. He succeeds Henri Jarrat, who announced his resignation last month. Experienced in the semiconductor industry, Mr.

headline: Taiwan Imprisons 2 Backing Independence
abstract: LEAD: A Taiwanese court today imposed long prison terms on two dissidents who were convicted of sedition for advocating Taiwan's independence from China.

headline: Portfolio Insurers Reject Blame
abstract: LEAD: Facing renewed criticism that they were to blame for the October market collapse, money managers offering portfolio insurance are instead pointing the finger at other market players.

headline: U.S. Asking China's Help on Burmese Drugs
abstract: LEAD: The United States has asked China for help in curbing opium and heroin production in Burma, where the Communist Party is now thought to be the major supplier of narcotics, according to a group of Western officials briefing reporters here today.

headline: April Retirement Is Set For Chairman of Centel
abstract: LEAD: Robert P. Reuss, one of the telephone executives who moved early and fast to diversify at the onset of deregulation, is retiring as chairman of the Centel Corporation, effective April 1.

headline: Tricentrol Fight
abstract: LEAD: The British oil group Tricentrol P.L.C. said it might seek the aid of a friendly company to fight a hostile bid by the French oil giant Elf Aquitaine. But Tricentrol's chairman, James Longcroft, who has urged shareholders to reject Elf's offer of $:134.7 million, or about $240 million, said a friendly suitor was not now under consideration.

headline: Iraqis and Iranians Continue Missile Attacks on Capitals
abstract: LEAD: Missiles exploded in Baghdad and Teheran today, the 10th day of missile attacks on civilian targets in Iran and Iraq that have killed or wounded hundreds of people.
