headline: Extension Is Seen on Campeau Bid
abstract: LEAD: The Campeau Corporation will extend its tender offer for about 70.5 million shares of Federated Department Stores Inc. to Friday at midnight, individuals close to Campeau said yesterday. They said the move would take the pressure off a Federal judge who is scheduled to hear arguments today on issues in the complex takeover struggle.

headline: U.S. INSISTS SOVIET STOP SENDING ARMS TO AFGHAN REGIME
abstract: LEAD: The United States said today that it would not end aid to the Afghan guerrillas unless Moscow agreed to stop sending military supplies to the Afghan Government.

headline: Ex-Pan Am Executive Gets Continental Post
abstract: LEAD: Martin R. Shugrue Jr., who was ousted two weeks ago as vice chairman of the Pan Am Corporation, yesterday was elected president of Continental Airlines Inc. For much of the last year, Continental has been seeking to solve service problems that brought a flood of customer complaints.

headline: A Pizza Magnate And His Mansion
abstract: LEAD: RUNNING the length of the original wing of Stapleford Park, a stately home near this Leiscestershire village, is an inscription that reads: ''William Lord Sherard, Baron of Letrym, Repayred this Building, Anno Domini 1633.''

headline: Real Estate; Architectural Double Role In Manhattan
abstract: LEAD: EVEN among the high-rise structures now going up in the west midtown section of Manhattan, the 55-story residential structure nearing completion on Eighth Avenue at 57th Street is a standout.

headline: South Africa, Invoking Curbs, Shuts Black Paper
abstract: LEAD: The South African Government closed a leading anti-apartheid newspaper for three months today after declaring that it was bent on stimulating revolution.

headline: Careers; How to Help Out-of-Work Managers
abstract: LEAD: NO man is an island, the poet John Donne wrote years ago, and out-of-work middle managers surely appreciate the importance of networking.

headline: A Settlement In Silver Case
abstract: LEAD: A company accused of cornering the silver market with the Hunt brothers of Texas in 1980 has agreed to pay a Peruvian company $3.65 million in an out-of-court settlement, a lawyer for Minpeco S.A. said today.

headline: Israelis Said to Kill 3 Guerrillas
abstract: LEAD: Israeli troops killed three Palestinian guerrillas early today, moments after the guerrillas cut a security fence on the northern border and slipped into Israel, apparently to mount an attack.

headline: YOUR MONEY; Financial Plans For New Parents
abstract: LEAD: Couples should overhaul their finances when they start their families so that they can meet the costs of rearing children, financial planners say.

headline: Canada Jobless Rate Off
abstract: LEAD: Canada's unemployment rate fell to 8.1 percent in December, the lowest level in more than six years, the Government agency Statistics Canada said today. The November rate had been 8.2 percent. The average unemployment rate for 1987 was 8.9 percent, down from 9.4 percent in the previous year.

headline: Taking a 'Normal' Step, Squibb Names Officers
abstract: LEAD: The Squibb Corporation made two major executive appointments yesterday, naming Jan Leschly president and chief operating officer and Dr. Charles A. Sanders vice chairman.

headline: Panama Strongman Fights Back Against U.S.
abstract: LEAD: American servicemen and government civilians arriving in Panama are given a printed ''fact sheet'' by the United States Embassy warning them of civil unrest and providing a radio frequency to tune to for information and instructions in case of trouble.

headline: Shoney's South Has Higher Bid
abstract: LEAD: A management group led by Citicorp Capital Investors Ltd., a venture capital unit of Citicorp, has raised its offer to take Shoney's South Inc. private in a leveraged buyout for $14 a share, or about $95.2 million. In a letter dated Friday to

headline: You Needn't Face It Alone: A Guide to the Tax Guides
abstract: LEAD: Taking control of your tax situation involves a lot more than filling out the forms, or gathering up folders of last year's records to drop by the accountant's office. Actually, financial planning is an ongoing, year-round affair, and for those who spend an hour or two a week monitoring their finances - checking whether their portfolios are meeting expectations and how their household budgets are shaping up - income-tax preparation is a relatively effortless exercise.

headline: Bid Made for Kansas City Southern
abstract: LEAD: An investor group led by a New York real estate developer today offered $60 a share to acquire Kansas City Southern Industries, the railroad, data-processing and financial-services concern.

headline: Citicorp Rates Fall
abstract: LEAD: Interest rates fell at Citicorp's regular weekly auction of commercial paper. The bank holding company sold $50 million of 91-day paper at an average rate of 6.61 percent, down from 6.7916 percent last week. Another $50 million of 182-day paper sold at an average rate of 6.635 percent, down from 6.879 percent.

headline: Big Board Weighs Curbs
abstract: LEAD: The New York Stock Exchange is considering new rules to halt trading if the market rises or falls more than a certain amount in one day, John J. Phelan Jr., the exchange's chairman, said.

headline: Market Place; Why Hoffmann Wants Sterling
abstract: LEAD: SOME analysts say there was a lot of ego behind the decision of F. Hoffmann-La Roche & Company to offer $72 a share, or $4.2 billion, to buy Sterling Drug Inc.

headline: BUSINESS DIGEST: WEDNESDAY, MARCH 9, 1988
abstract: LEAD:  International

headline: Apartheid Foe At University Bridges a Gap
abstract: LEAD: A red and yellow poster advertising a campus symposium on the 70th anniversary of the Russian Revolution last November is the only decoration on the dark-wood panels of Jakes Gerwel's office.

headline: Irving Protecting Its Pension Fund
abstract: LEAD: The board of directors of the Irving Bank Corporation has moved to make the assets of its employee pension plan invulnerable in the face of a hostile $1.08 million takeover offer by the Bank of New York Company. Under amendments to the plans approved by Irving's board on Jan. 19, the bank's surplus pension assets ''can only be used to provide for existing medical and life insurance benefits of retirees and employees eligible to retire within five years of the change of control,'' acccording to company documents filed with the Securities and Exchange

headline: IN QUOTES
abstract: LEAD: ''Something had to snap. If it didn't happen in October, it would have happened soon thereafter. The immediate cause of the break was incidental.'' - Alan Greenspan, chairman of the Federal Reserve, in Congressional testimony about regulating the markets.

headline: VOTE APPEARS LOW
abstract: LEAD: Haiti's army-dominated Government held its presidential elections today, but voting appeared to be light, and irregularities, from multiple voting to voting by youths under the minimum age of 18, appeared widespread.

headline: Advertising; Heineken to Go To Warwick
abstract: LEAD: After April 1 Heineken Beer, as well as Amstel Light Bier and Grizzly Canadian Lager, will have their advertising done by Warwick Advertising.

headline: Farley Considers a Bid For Montgomery Ward
abstract: LEAD: Farley Inc., the controlling shareholder of Fruit of the Loom Inc., said today that it was exploring the possibility of buying the Montgomery Ward & Company subsidiary of the Mobil Corporation.

headline: German Jobless Rate Up
abstract: LEAD: West Germany's unemployment rate rose to 9.2 percent in December from 8.5 percent in November as the number of jobless grew by 175,200, to more than 2 million, the Government reported today.

headline: PAPAL ENCYCLICAL SAYS SUPERPOWERS HURT THIRD WORLD
abstract: LEAD: Pope John Paul II today issued an encyclical letter charging that the ideological rivalry between East and West was subjecting poor nations to imperialistic ''structures of sin'' that deny them freedom and development.

headline: Macy's Bid for Federated Has a Clear Lead
abstract: LEAD: After two months, the $6.3 billion takeover war for Federated Department Stores Inc. has reached a critical stage, with R.H. Macy & Company taking a clear lead over rival bidder the Campeau Corporation.

headline: Chevron in Talks On Soviet Venture
abstract: LEAD: The Chevron Corporation is talking with the Soviet Union about creating a joint venture in the petroleum business, a Chevron spokesman said. Chevron officials have repeatedly visited the Soviet Union in recent months to discuss business opportunities. On Friday, Nikolai Lemayev, the Soviet Minister of Petroleum Refining and Petrochemical Industries, had discussions with Chevron officials in San

headline: Argentine Troops Storm Garrison And Put Down Colonel's Mutiny
abstract: LEAD: About 2,000 soldiers loyal to the civilian Government stormed an army compound today and forced the surrender of a rebellious colonel who had held the camp for three days with the support of about 100 followers, officials said.

headline: Cold Sends Oil Contracts Up Despite Late Profit Taking
abstract: LEAD: Severe winter weather over much of the nation bolstered heating and crude oil futures yesterday. Despite a late burst of profit taking, the spot February heating oil contract closed up 0.31 cent a gallon, at 53.79 cents, after soaring to an intraday high of 54.40 cents.

headline: I.R.S. Review Of Penalties
abstract: LEAD: The Commissioner of the Internal Revenue Service said today that the agency was reviewing its tax penalties to try to make them fairer and less complicated.

headline: Honduras Says It Asked for Troops
abstract: LEAD: United States and Honduran officials asserted today that the request for American combat troops to be sent to Honduras this week was initiated by the Honduran Government.

headline: Drexel Sees No Quick Resolution
abstract: LEAD: Drexel Burnham Lambert Inc., the investment house that for more than a year has been the subject of two extensive Federal investigations, said yesterday that it did not expect any issues arising from those investigations to be resolved for several months.

headline: 2 Belfast Men Appear in Court in Killing of Soldiers
abstract: LEAD: Two men appeared in court today on charges that they murdered two British soldiers during a funeral for an Irish Republican Army member in which the soldiers were beaten, stripped and then shot.

headline: Food Units for Sale
abstract: LEAD: Rowntree-Mackintosh P.L.C., a confectionery company, said it wanted to sell its British and American snack-food units for at least the $:155 million, or $277 million in United States currency, it paid for them. The company said that both the Tom's Foods Inc. unit in the United States and the Rowntree Snack Foods Ltd.

headline: Eastern Air Penalty Planned
abstract: LEAD: The legal problems of Eastern Air Lines and its parent, the Texas Air Corporation, mounted yesterday when a Federal judge said that he would penalize Eastern on Monday for its attempts to transfer its shuttle operation to a newly formed subsidiary of Texas Air.

headline: Carte Blanche Loses Plea
abstract: LEAD: An arbitration panel has awarded $10 million to the Carte Blanche franchises in Malaysia and Singapore after finding that Carte Blanche International, the parent company, had breached an agreement to support the franchises.

headline: Let the Computer Do the Walking
abstract: LEAD: COMPUTERS are showing up in the outplacement business in the form of sophisticated job data bases.

headline: Calfed Sets Merger With Florida Unit
abstract: LEAD: To solidify its market share in Florida, Calfed Inc. said that it would merge with the Duval Federal Savings and Loan Association, an unprofitable savings institution in Jacksonville, Fla., with $1.3 billion in assets and 36 branches. The terms are to be disclosed after regulatory approval is obtained, a

headline: Israelis Detain 10 Palestinians Termed Moderates
abstract: LEAD: The Israeli authorities detained 10 Palestinians, most regarded as members of the moderate Arab establishment, in a continuing crackdown today as scattered disturbances continued in the occupied territories.

headline: BUSINESS PEOPLE; A Medium-Size Raider Turns Sights on Dravo
abstract: LEAD: Arthur M. Goldberg has a reputation as medium-size corporate raider. Not a Carl C. Icahn or a T. Boone Pickens, but he is nonetheless a raider with an eye for the hidden value in smaller companies in trouble.

headline: Bonn Cabinet Backs Plan for Tax Changes
abstract: LEAD: The West German Cabinet today approved a much-debated tax-change plan that is designed to reduce the nation's net tax bill by 20.7 billion marks, or more than $12 billion, starting in 1990.

headline: Farley Industries Offering $500 Million in Debentures
abstract: LEAD: Farley Industries is offering $500 million in speculative-grade debentures, accompanied by warrants entitling holders to buy another $250 million in debentures, through underwriters led by Drexel Burnham Lambert Inc.

headline: Stocks Mixed as Caution Persists
abstract: LEAD: Stock prices were mixed yesterday in a desultory session, as investors again showed caution before today's release of the nation's trade-deficit figures.

headline: B.P. Plans Name Change
abstract: LEAD: The British Petroleum Company plans to change its name by midyear to reflect its trans-Atlantic operations, a senior executive said today. E. John P. Browne, executive vice president of B.P.'s Cleveland-based BP America Inc. unit, did not say what the new name would be. The company's name has been changed several times since incorporation in 1909 as the Anglo-Persian Oil Company.

headline: BOTH SIDES OFFER NICARAGUAN STEPS FOR A CEASE-FIRE
abstract: LEAD: Leaders of the Sandinista Government and Nicaraguan contras offered differing proposals today for a cease-fire when they met for their second day of talks at this southern border outpost.

headline: Market Place; The Stock Impact Of Aspirin Report
abstract: LEAD: THE news announcement yesterday that an aspirin every other day may sharply reduce the risk of heart attacks in men is expected to have a far bigger impact on American consumers than investors. The aspirin market is dominated by the Bristol-Myers Company, the American Home Products Corporation, and the Sterling Drug

headline: U.S. Files Suit Against P.L.O. to Shut U.N. Mission
abstract: LEAD: The United States filed a lawsuit in Federal court in Manhattan today in an attempt to force the Palestine Liberation Organization to shut its observer mission to the United Nations.

headline: FINANCE/NEW ISSUES;
abstract: LEAD: New-issue activity was relatively light in the tax-exempt market yesterday, except for the Maryland Health and Higher Educational Facilities Authority, which tentatively offered $210.9 million of refunding revenue bonds for Johns Hopkins University. The bonds have a maximum yield of 7.54 percent for an issue due in 2020 through underwriters led by Alex.

headline: Court Rules In Belgium
abstract: LEAD: A Brussels appeals court today approved Societe Generale de Belgique's plan to increase its capital by 40 percent to weaken the stake of the Italian financier Carlo de Benedetti, but left it to a higher court to give the final word on the issue.

headline: Farmers Group Bid Backed at B.A.T.
abstract: LEAD: The shareholders of the British conglomerate B.A.T. Industries approved a hostile $4.2 billion effort by the group's American subsidiary for Farmers Group Inc., the seventh-largest United States insurer.

headline: Stocks Mixed as Dow Drops by 1.17 Points
abstract: LEAD: Stock prices were mixed yesterday. The blue-chip Dow Jones industrial average fell 1.17 points to close at 2,039.12, but many issues moved higher.

headline: BUSINESS DIGEST: FRIDAY, FEBRUARY 5, 1988
abstract: LEAD:  Markets

headline: U.S. Demand on Afghan Arms Aid Seen as Last Big Obstacle to Pact
abstract: LEAD: The disagreement between the United States and the Soviet Union over the Reagan Administration's demand for a halt in Soviet weapon supplies to the Afghan Government has emerged as the only important obstacle to an accord on a Soviet troop withdrawal, American officials and Asian diplomats said today.

headline: Chile's Growing Trans-Pacific Ties
abstract: LEAD: A new cartoon character has shown up in Chilean newspapers in the past year: a cowboy-hatted kangaroo, its pouch stuffed with dollars, telephones and the documents of complicated financial deals.

headline: Vietnam's Party Chief Says Capitalism Can Be a Guide
abstract: LEAD: The head of the Vietnamese Communist Party suggested today that Vietnam, ''a backward agricultural country,'' could learn lessons from the capitalist world.

headline: Business and Health; H.M.O. Troubles With Medicare
abstract: LEAD: THE Reagan Administration's program to persuade elderly Americans to join prepaid health plans is gaining momentum, but nearly 20 percent of the health maintenance organizations, or H.M.O.'s, that signed up for the program have dropped out, displacing 80,000 people.

headline: First Executive
abstract: LEAD: The First Executive Corporation said two of its shareholders had filed a lawsuit seeking to block the completion of a tender offer from the ICH Corporation and to overturn a standstill agreement. ICH, a Louisville, Ky., insurance holding company, began a $134.4 million tender offer last month for 11.2 million shares of First Executive at $12 a share.

headline: Banker Seen as a Contender For Vacancy on Fed Board
abstract: LEAD: Wendell Wilkie Gunn, a banking consultant and a former special assistant to President Reagan, is a leading candidate to fill a vacant seat on the Federal Reserve Board, Administration and Congressional officials said today.

headline: VNU Sets Acquisition Of Media Records
abstract: LEAD: VNU, the United States subsidiary of a Dutch publishing company, has acquired Media Records, a company that keeps track of the advertising content of newspapers, and will add it to its Marketing Services division. Since the division already operates Leading National Advertisers, a major media-measuring service, it means a more complete service for the industry.

headline: Advertising; People
abstract: LEAD: * Roger Feuerman, Robert Tabor, Doreen Fox, Stephanie Pierson and Tino Pelino have been named senior vice presidents at Backer Spielvogel Bates, part of Backer Spielvogel Bates Worldwide Inc.

headline: A State Department Official Meets President of Paname Special to The New York Times
abstract: LEAD: William G. Walker, Deputy Assistant Secretary of State for Central America, made an un-announced trip to New York today to meet with Panama's civillian Presi-dent, Eric Arturo Delvalle, State De-partment officials and senior Latin American diplomats said.

headline: Hijacking Confession 'Illegal'
abstract: LEAD: A Federal judge ruled today that the Federal Bureau of Investigation illegally obtained a Lebanese Shiite Moslem's confession to leading a 1985 plane hijacking during ''relentless interrogation'' that violated his rights.

headline: 800 in Tel Aviv Hear Appeals for Talks
abstract: LEAD: A dozen Israeli playwrights, poets and other intellectuals made an urgent appeal to the Government tonight to ''talk peace with the Palestinians.''

headline: How Five Studies Viewed The Market Collapse
abstract: LEAD:  Securities and Exchange Commission: New computer-assisted trading techniques that link the stock and futures markets fueled last October's wild swings in stock prices. The danger of extreme volatility persists, it said. Also found that many market-makers did not do enough to cushion the plunge in prices.

headline: U.S. Embassy to Colombia Is Attacked With Grenades
abstract: LEAD: Two attackers thought to be leftist guerrillas fired rocket-propelled grenades at the United States Embassy here Wednesday night. An embassy spokesman said no one was hurt.

headline: NATO SHIFTS STAND ON ARMS IN EUROPE
abstract: LEAD: A summit gathering of the North Atlantic Treaty Organization approved a new approach today to conventional arms negotiations, calling on the Warsaw Pact to make huge reductions in its tanks and artillery.

headline: Texaco Appears Close To Ending Bankruptcy
abstract: LEAD: Texaco appeared close yesterday to clearing away the remaining major obstacles to emerging from bankruptcy.

headline: Advertising; Addendum
abstract: LEAD: Earle Palmer Brown's Atlanta office, Burton-Campbell/EPB, has been renamed Earle Palmer Brown/ Atlanta.

headline: COMPANY BRIEFS
abstract: LEAD: * Allegis Corp., Chicago, parent of United Airlines, said it had started its tender offer to buy up to 35.5 million common shares at $80 a share.

headline: General Strike Fails to Take Hold in Armenia
abstract: LEAD: Yerevan was peaceful today, with no sign of the confrontation feared by authorities or the mass stay-at-home strike called by protest leaders, according to residents of the Armenian capital reached by telephone.

headline: Advertising; WPP Refinancing
abstract: LEAD: WPP Group, London, reported that it had signed its previously announced refinancing agreement for its acquisition of the JWT Group, which occurred last July. WPP said the new package includes a seven-year, $160 million loan set up by S. G. Warburg & Company, with the Morgan Guaranty Trust Company of New York acting as agent and lead manager.

headline: Superior Industries
abstract: LEAD: The Vista Group Ltd. said it and Prudential-Bache Securities Inc. had made a $16-a-share, $96 million offer to cquire Superior Industries of Van Nuys, Calif., in a leveraged buyout. Superior, a manufacturer of aluminum and custom-made auto wheels said it was uninterested in holding talks. Superior said in a statement that the offer to discuss such a transaction had come from both companies.

headline: Bond Prices Retain Early Gains
abstract: LEAD: Bond prices moved narrowly higher in light trading yesterday despite small gains in commodity prices and a big jump in the stock market, developments that have made credit market participants edgy in the past.

headline: Subpoenas Said to Aim At Drexel
abstract: LEAD: The United States Attorney's office in Manhattan has sent out a new series of subpoenas focusing on several takeover transactions involving Drexel Burnham Lambert Inc., according to several people with knowledge of the Government's investigation.

headline: Shell Chief to Retire; Successor Is Named
abstract: LEAD: John F. Bookout will retire as president and chief executive of the Shell Oil Company on June 30, to be replaced by Frank H. Richardson, executive vice president, products, the company announced yesterday.

headline: Brazil's Trade Surplus
abstract: LEAD: Brazil had a trade surplus of $11.15 billion in 1987, with exports totaling $26.21 billion, the second highest ever, the Government said today. Imports came to $15.06 billion. The surplus was 33.8 percent higher than the 1986 figure of $8.33 billion.

headline: Kluge Lifts Stake In Orion Pictures
abstract: LEAD: John W. Kluge, the chairman of the Metromedia Company, has increased his stake in the Orion Pictures Company for the second consecutive day. In a Securities and Exchange Commission filing, Mr. Kluge said he had raised his holdings to 26.7 percent from 25.6 percent, through purchases of an additional 221,400 Orion shares on Tuesday at an average price of $17.02 each.

headline: Ortega Says Congress Hurt the Contras
abstract: LEAD: President Daniel Ortega Saavedra says he thinks contra leaders will come to the negotiating table this month in ''a position of weakness'' because of the recent Congressional vote cutting off aid to their movement.

headline: On Finding the U.S.P.
abstract: LEAD: When the 10 members of the newly created international management committee of Backer Spielvogel Bates, including David Beecroft from far-off Hong Kong, come to town on May 16 for their first meeting, they will hear from a fellow member, William M. Backer, deputy chairman and worldwide creative head, who will instruct them on how to judge advertising and how to find the unique selling proposition, or U.S.P., according to Mr.

headline: Disqualified Haitian Candidates Expected to Fight Panel's Action
abstract: LEAD: Many Haitians and Western diplomats said today that they expected former associates of the deposed Duvalier dictatorship to appeal the rejection of their candidacies for the presidential election scheduled for Jan. 17.

headline: Exchanges Play Down S.E.C. Plan
abstract: LEAD: Trying to ward off cumbersome new regulations, the heads of two Chicago futures exchanges and two major stock exchanges today criticized a proposal to give the Securities and Exchange Commission broad powers to regulate stock-index futures.

headline: NOVICE REGULATOR: David S. Ruder; Seeking Tighter Control Over the Financial Markets
abstract: LEAD: DAVID S. RUDER was tapped to be a good caretaker.

headline: Mentor to Acquire Tektronix Division Special to The New York Times
abstract: LEAD: The Mentor Graphics Corporation said it would acquire the computer-aided engineering and computer-aided software engineering business of Tektronix Inc. for $5 million in cash, a small fraction of the price Tektronix paid for the company two years ago. The two companies, both based in Beaverton, Ore., also said they would form a strategic alliance to link Mentor's electronic design business with

headline: ISRAEL JAILS ARABS WITHOUT A TRIAL
abstract: LEAD: Israeli officials said today that dozens of Palestinians had been jailed in the last few days under a procedure allowing them to be held without trial for up to six months.

headline: Iran Seeking OPEC Talks
abstract: LEAD: Iran wants OPEC's president, Rilwanu Lukman of Nigeria, to call an urgent meeting of the organization's monitoring committee because oil prices are falling. But a Nigerian official said Thursday that such a meeting would be premature.

headline: Global Investing More Complex as Markets End Wild Year
abstract: LEAD: What a year.

headline: New Seven-Up Soft Drinks
abstract: LEAD: The Seven-Up Company announced today that it would introduce two new soft drinks - 7-Up Gold and Diet 7-Up Gold. They will be amber in color and have a spice flavor and will be marketed to appeal particularly to men between the ages of 18 and 34.

headline: The Wealth Effect
abstract: LEAD: To The Editor:

headline: Cablevision-SCI Talks
abstract: LEAD: The Cablevision Corporation, the Long Island-based cable company, is in preliminary negotiations to acquire the cable assets of SCI Holdings, according to several well-placed industry sources. Cablevision executives declined to comment. It was not clear Friday how such a deal would be financed and whether it might ultimately involve other companies.

headline: FILLING OUT THE FORMS
abstract: LEAD: Whether you plan to have your return prepared professionally or to do it yourself, walking through a return prepared by top professionals can be helpful, both in terms of getting records organized for this year's filing and in planning tax strategies for future years. Pamela Pecarich, tax partner, and Steven Woolf, Robin Cornelius and Jeffrey Hillier, tax managers for Coopers & Lybrand in Washington, prepared a sample return for a two-income New York couple.

headline: 9 Seized on a Ship Off Beirut Reported Released by Militia
abstract: LEAD: Eight seamen and a teen-age boy who were seized by Lebanon's main Christian militia seven weeks ago were freed today, militia figures and Lebanese officials said.

headline: Help From the 'Hidden Persuaders'
abstract: LEAD: THE year was 1956. The movie was ''Picnic.'' And at a New Jersey drive-in theater, according to legend, an invisible message flashed across the silver screen every 32 seconds: ''Eat popcorn. Drink Coke.'' The concession stand reportedly filled with hungry patrons, and subliminal messages were declared a box-office success.

headline: Foster Wheeler
abstract: LEAD: The Foster Wheeler Corporation said its president, Louis E. Azzato, was prepared to meet with Asher B. Edelman, but not to discuss his proposal to pay $16.50 a share, or almost $575 million in cash, for the company's stock. Mr. Edelman, who holds about 11.5 percent of Foster Wheeler's common stock outstanding, proposed last week that the company create a recapitalization plan or, as an alternative, accept his buyout offer.

headline: French Trade Deficit
abstract: LEAD: The French current account balance of payments swung back into a deficit in 1987 after achieving its first surplus for seven years in 1986, the Finance Ministry said today. The current account, which measures not only trade in goods and services but also such invisible items as bank transfers, fell to a deficit of 27.2 billion francs, or about $4.9 billion, in 1987 from a surplus of 20.2 billion francs the previous year.

headline: Advertising; USA Weekend To Offer Scent
abstract: LEAD: Ramon Gaulke, president of USA Weekend, the Gannett Company supplement that appears in 293 newspapers with a circulation of 14.6 million, reports that there is something in the wind.

headline: Dart Withdraws Stop and Shop Bid
abstract: LEAD: The Dart Group Corporation said it would not extend its $37-a-share offer to purchase the Stop and Shop Companies, which owns supermarkets, discount stores and other retail outlets in the Northeast. Stop and Shop accepted a $44-a-share offer, worth a total of $1.2 billion, from Kohlberg, Kravis, Roberts & Company, the big New

headline: Four Arrests In Taiwan
abstract: LEAD: Four officials of a leading stock brokerage house have been arrested in connection with illegal margin loans that led to a default on payment of $750 million (Taiwan), or $26.3 million (United States) by a stock investor, police said.

headline: Dow Rises 1.49; Focus on Takeover Stocks
abstract: LEAD: As Wall Street's attention focused mostly on takeover-related stocks, blue-chip issues ended with a small gain yesterday.

headline: VATICAN EXPECTS RECORD '88 DEFICIT
abstract: LEAD: The Vatican said today that it expects a record budget deficit of $61.8 million this year, although income from contributions has increased.

headline: Article 824188 -- No Title
abstract: LEAD: The Dun & Bradstreet Corporation announced yesterday that it had agreed to acquire I.M.S. International for $1.77 billion in stock.

headline: Times to Introduce A Television Weekly
abstract: LEAD: The New York Times will introduce a new guide to broadcast and cable television programs on March 6. The magazine, called Television, will offer four-color advertising and will be printed by rotogravure on premium calendered paper, 8 1/4 by 11 inches, press-stitched and trimmed.

headline: U.S. Official Says New Pressures Against Noriega Are Considered
abstract: LEAD: The Reagan Administration has miscalculated the ability of Panama's military leader, Gen. Manuel Antonio Noriega, to withstand American economic pressure aimed at forcing his ouster and is now considering further moves against him, a senior State Department official said today.

headline: Advertising; Magazine Ad Growth
abstract: LEAD: The Publishers Information Bureau reported that its member magazines were up 10.3 percent in ad pages, to 13,772, in February, compared with the same month last year, while revenues gained 19.9 percent, to $486.5 million.

headline: Money Managers Still in Shock
abstract: LEAD: Even though four months have passed since the stock market collapsed, professional money managers are still acting as if it happened yesterday. Stunned by the experience, they prefer to hold billions of dollars in cash instead of buying now-cheaper stocks.

headline: Two Texas Issues Total $313 Million
abstract: LEAD: Two issues of double A-rated tax-exempt bonds totaling $313 million were offered by issuers from Texas yesterday.

headline: BRIEFS
abstract: LEAD: * B.A.T. Industries, Britain, a tobacco-based conglomerate, said it believes it can satisfy United States regulatory requirements in its bid to take over Farmers Group Inc.

headline: Alien Footprints on Sydney's Sands
abstract: LEAD: Joan McDonald, who has been renting out deck chairs at Bondi beach for more than 50 years, recently added a sun blocking agent to the popular tanning oil she sprays from a hose.

headline: Advertising; Network and Spot TV Ads for 'Platoon' Video
abstract: LEAD: You'll be seeing it soon on network and spot TV. The screen will be full of action-packed scenes from ''Platoon,'' the hit film of the war in Vietnam, when across the bottom of the tube will crawl one of those print bands that is usually the station or network's way of announcing real news. It will say: ''America.

headline: Adams-Millis
abstract: LEAD: The Adams-Millis Corporation said it had agreed to be acquired by the Sara Lee Corporation in a stock swap worth at least $13 a share, or about $61 million. Adams-Millis said that amount might be raised to $16 a share, depending on its cash flow for 1988. Adams-Millis is an apparel maker that produces Hanes brand socks under license from Sara Lee.

headline: INQUIRY INTO BUSH SEEN ON IRAN SALES
abstract: LEAD: The special prosecutor in the Iran-contra affair is expected to submit questions to Vice President Bush about his role in the sale of American weapons to Iran and is considering requesting an interview with Mr. Bush, according to Reagan Administration officials.

headline: Ahold Purchase
abstract: LEAD: Ahold N.V., a leading Dutch food retailer, said it had bought an 80 percent stake in First National Supermarkets, a chain of 122 supermarkets across the United States, for an undisclosed amount of cash. The Dutch company, which also owns the BI-LO and Giant Food Store chains in the United States, said the present management would continue to direct First National, which is based in Cleveland.

headline: WHAT'S NEW IN EXECUTIVE SECURITY
abstract: LEAD: ''YEARS ago, security was at the bottom of the totem pole,'' said Michael Goodrich, general manager of Spectra Audio Research Inc., which makes electronic security devices. Now, he went on, executives are quietly investing in bodyguards, bulletproof vests, automatic vehicle locators to trace a missing car and other high-tech gear.

headline: Investors Keep B.P. Shares
abstract: LEAD: A Government offer to buy back stock in the British Petroleum Company closed this week with most investors apparently hanging on to their shares, according to official figures released today.

headline: KEY RATES
abstract: LEAD:       $         Previous   Year     In percent   Yesterday   Day   Ago              PRIME RATE   8.75   8.75   7.50        DISCOUNT RATE   6.00   6.00   5.50        FEDERAL FUNDS   6.83   6.72   6.01        3-MO. TREAS. BILLS   5.86   5.78   5.36        6-MO. TREAS. BILLS   6.27   6.28   5.40        7-YR. TREAS. NOTES   8.65   8.67   6.91        30-YR.

headline: Panama's Plan to Sell Seized Flour Provokes Anger
abstract: LEAD: Outrage over the seizure by troops of thousands of sacks of flour from the country's two largest mills deepened today after the military Government announced that it planned to sell all 1.3 million pounds to the baking industry.

headline: Lull in Weekly Note and Bond Sales
abstract: LEAD: The only Treasury auctions scheduled this week are today's regular sales of three- and six-month bills.

headline: Defending Morgan
abstract: LEAD: To the Editor:

headline: Bristol-Myers Net Up 14.8%
abstract: LEAD: The Bristol-Myers Company, citing a strong rise in profit and in domestic and international sales, reported yesterday that it fourth-quarter earnings rose 14.8 percent on a 13.3 percent increase in sales.

headline: Florence Journal; The City's of Two Minds on Digging Up the Past
abstract: LEAD: ''This city is like a very beautiful woman who gets nausea everytime someone takes a long look at her.'' That alarming diagnosis came from a man who is single-handedly giving Florence a prolonged case of upset stomach, Francesco Nicosia, Tuscany's Superintendent of Archeology.

headline: The Cost of Caring for Elderly Parents
abstract: LEAD: AS the baby-boom generation grows older, more children are contributing to the support of their aging parents and looking to basic tax devices to reduce their costs.

headline: Strike and Boycott Are Urged in Haiti
abstract: LEAD: Four leading Haitian politicians called today for a national strike on Saturday and repeated their appeal for a boycott of the election that the army-dominated Government has scheduled for Sunday.

headline: The U.N. Today
abstract: LEAD:  General Assembly  MEETING OF STATES PARTIES TO CONVENTION ON ELIMINATION OF DISCRIMINATION AGAINST WOMEN - 10:30 A.M. and 3 P.M.  Economic and Social Council  SPECIAL COMMISSION ON U.N. STRUCTURE IN SOCIAL AND ECONOMIC FIELDS - 10 A.M.  WORKING GROUP ON INTERNATIONAL STANDARDS OF ACCOUNTING AND REPORTING - 10:30 A.M.

headline: U.S. Vetoes U.N. Move
abstract: LEAD: The United States vetoed a Security Council resolution today that criticized Israel for its recent military attacks and other moves in southern Lebanon. Washington said the resolution lacked balance and showed insufficent concern for Israel's security needs.

headline: Super Bowl's Ratings Spur Questions About Ad Costs
abstract: LEAD: To the dismay of some advertisers who bought spots during this year's Super Bowl, the match between the Washington Redskins and the Denver Broncos received the lowest Nielsen ratings in 14 years.

headline: Court Bars Legal-Fee Award For Iran-Contra Case Figure
abstract: LEAD: The special court that appointed an independent counsel to investigate the Iran-contra affair refused today to award legal fees to a retired Air Force officer who received immunity in the inquiry.

headline: Grow Your Own In-House Lobbyists
abstract: LEAD: THERE'S plenty of help available to businesses that want to encourage employees or customers to register and vote, or to participate more actively in the political process.

headline: SITUATION UNCLEAR
abstract: LEAD: Panama's civilian President announced yesterday the dismissal of Gen. Manuel Antonio Noriega, the country's principal leader, as commander of the Defense Forces.

headline: ABORTION DEBATE REVIVED IN CANADA
abstract: LEAD: After an uneasy political truce that lasted nearly 20 years, Canada has been thrust anew into a bitter dispute over its abortion laws.

headline: INVESTING; New Fund Offerings Stage a Rebound
abstract: LEAD: NEW mutual fund offerings are on the rise again, but individual investors should basically avoid them, professionals who analyze these funds say. The number of new funds dropped sharply after the October stock collapse, but lately the number of funds in registration has been creeping back to pre-crash levels.

headline: Economic Scene; Learning Caution The Hard Way
abstract: LEAD: ALTHOUGH the London stock market remains ''jittery and skittish,'' as one highly placed Government economist put it yesterday, there is a growing belief on London's Wall Street that the danger of another market crash is receding. That belief was strengthened by the ability of equity markets here and around the world to withstand the shock of last Friday's plunge in the New York stock market, when the

headline: Japan Warned to End Beef and Citrus Curbs
abstract: LEAD: Two Cabinet officers warned Japan today that failure to end its curbs on imports of beef and citrus products by the end of this month would provoke punitive action by the United States within the General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade.

headline: Brazil Finance Chief Shakes Up Economic Team
abstract: LEAD: Brazil's new finance minister, Mailson Ferreira da Nobrega, announced today a shake-up in his top economic team, including a new chief negotiator for this country's foreign debt.

headline: U.S. and Spain Announce a Limited Military Accord
abstract: LEAD: The United States and Spain announced new military arrangements today that would sharply curtail the American presence here and terminate American aid to Spain under the existing 35-year-old treaty between the two countries.

headline: Publisher Sells Control of U.P.I. to WNW Group
abstract: LEAD: Mario Vazquez-Rana, the Mexican newspaper publisher, announced last night that he had sold control of United Press International Inc. and that the former president of the Financial News Network Inc. will take over direct operational control of the company.

headline: U.S. Officials Praised Drug Effort by Noriega
abstract: LEAD: Letters of praise for Gen. Manuel Antonio Noriega, the miltary ruler of Panama, have come back to haunt the United States Drug Enforcement Administration and the Justice Department.

headline: Economic Scene; Election Year's Monetary Drama
abstract: LEAD: THE conflict between the Federal Reserve and the Reagan Administration over what monetary policy should be and whose monetary policy is it, anyway, can easily be turned into a morality play.

headline: FINANCE BRIEFS
abstract: LEAD: * Federal National Mortgage Association is offering $100 million of real estate mortgage investment conduit securities in four tranches through Shearson Lehman Hutton. Yields on the Fannie Mae offering range from 8.45 percent to 9.40 percent. The securities were obtained from Transohio Savings Bank of Cleveland.

headline: P.I.P. May Accept $66 Million Offer
abstract: LEAD: Postal Instant Press said it was considering a $17-a-share, or $66 million, buyout offer from an investor group that includes some of its managers and a Chicago leveraged-buyout firm. P.I.P., which franchises quick-printing outlets, also said it had adopted a plan to curb hostile takeovers, to be triggered if a shareholder obtained at least 20 percent of the company's stock.

headline: Talking Deals; For Sale or Not? The Courts' View
abstract: LEAD: ONE of the first things executives say when they come under takeover attack is that they want to remain independent.

headline: Ethiopia Rebuts Atrocity Report
abstract: LEAD: The Government said today that a report that troops killed at least 20 civilians at a drought relief camp was an ''outright lie,'' and it accused foreign news organizations of a disinformation campaign.

headline: U.S. Plans No Stiff Sanctions on Panama
abstract: LEAD: President Reagan will not impose the maximum economic sanctions against Panama when he declares Tuesday that it and several other countries have failed to take adequate steps to control drug trafficking, senior Administration officials said today.

headline: BUSINESS DIGEST: THURSDAY, FEBRUARY 25, 1988
abstract: LEAD:  THE ECONOMY

headline: Foreign Cars Gain in Japan
abstract: LEAD: The cash-rich Japanese bought a record number of foreign cars last year, particularly luxury models from West Germany.

headline: Covering Cars
abstract: LEAD: To the Editor:

headline: Young & Rubicam Discloses Lengthy Talks on Lord Deal
abstract: LEAD: Soon after WPP Group acquired Lord, Geller, Federico, Einstein last July, Richard J. Lord, the agency's chairman and chief executive, approached Young & Rubicam about buying his firm or providing financing so that its managers could buy it, according to papers filed yesterday in State Supreme Court.

headline: Fed in Shift On Reporting M-2 and M-3
abstract: LEAD: The Federal Reserve surprised economists yesterday by announcing that it would report weekly, rather than monthly, changes in the broadly defined M-2 and M-3 money supply measures.

headline: A Confidant Turns Against Noriega, but Why?
abstract: LEAD: For two days, Jose I. Blandon has transfixed Capitol Hill with vivid accounts of wrongdoing by his former boss, Gen. Manuel Antonio Noriega, Panama's military leader. But it is still unclear why a man many Panamanian exile leaders in Miami and Costa Rica denounce as General Noriega's confidant in unsavory operations over the years would suddenly switch sides.

headline: Primerica Will Sell 81% Musicland Stake
abstract: LEAD: The Primerica Corporation agreed today to sell its 81 percent stake in Musicland Group Inc. for about $330 million in a move to reduce the debt from its takeover of Smith Barney, Harris Upham & Company last year.

headline: NATIONS' WARNINGS LIFT DOLLAR MORE
abstract: LEAD: Central bankers, who acted dramatically to bolster the dollar's value earlier this week, backed up those deeds with strong words yesterday, and nervous currency traders responded by pushing the dollar higher for the fourth straight day.

headline: Dyncorp Board Meets on New Bid
abstract: LEAD: Directors of Dyncorp, a diversified technology company based in McLean, Va., have met to consider dropping one merger agreement for a sweeter rival proposal. A company spokesman said a decision was expected to be announced today.

headline: Aircraft Talks Falter Again
abstract: LEAD: Another round of United States-European talks aimed at settling a dispute over government aid to civil aircraft makers ended today without success.

headline: G.M. Job Cuts May Be Eased
abstract: LEAD: Slow sales of Pontiac Firebirds and Chevrolet Camaros have prompted the General Motors Corporation to elminate 1,900 jobs at a California assembly plant, but a new plan may save workers from permanent layoff, the nation's largest auto maker said today.

headline: McDonnell to Retire
abstract: LEAD: Sanford N. McDonnell, the chairman and chief executive of the McDonnell Douglas Corporation, said he would retire in March. Mr. McDonnell, 65 years old, has headed the company since 1980. He said he would be replaced by his cousin, John F. McDonnell. John McDonnell, 49, is the president of the St.

headline: Foreign Stocks Rise Slightly
abstract: LEAD: Stocks edged higher in most overseas markets today. The financial markets in the United States were closed to observe Washington's Birthday.

headline: Advertising; St. Gillian Fashion To Burkhardt & Christy
abstract: LEAD: Burkhardt & Christy Advertising has been named to do advertising for the St. Gillian Fashion Group. The client promises a budget of ''several'' million dollars.

headline: Advertising; Ad Clutter: Even in Restrooms Now
abstract: LEAD: Studies show that the typical consumer is bombarded by 5,000 advertising messages a day, and the number of ads is expected to increase steadily. That trend has many executives in the industry worried about the growing advertising clutter.

headline: 2 Suitors May Unite in Belgian Battle
abstract: LEAD: Andre Leysen of Belgium and Carlo de Benedetti of Italy announced tonight that they were considering joining forces for the ''effective management'' of Societe Generale de Belgique, providing a new twist in the three-week wrangle for control of Belgium's largest and most important company.

headline: BUSINESS DIGEST: FRIDAY, JANUARY 15, 1988
abstract: LEAD:  MARKETS  The New York Stock Exchange will curb program trading in a six-day experiment. Reacting to criticism that the enormous computerized trades were a major factor in October's stock market collapse, the exchange asked the firms that engage in it to refrain from using the exchange's computer system on any day when the Dow Jones industrial average climbs or falls by 75 points or more.

headline: First China Stock Firm
abstract: LEAD: China has set up its first domestic securities firm, the official China News Service said. It is in the Shenzhen special economic zone. The agency, monitored in Hong Kong today, said the firm, in the Shenzhen special economic zone, would trade stocks and bonds and help underwrite shares issued by Chinese companies.

headline: Bethlehem Steel's Debt Rating Lifted
abstract: LEAD: The Bethlehem Steel Corporation's senior debt rating was raised to B from CCC+, Standard & Poor's announced yesterday. The steelmaker's subordinated debt was raised to CCC+ from CCC-.

headline: 5 Anti-Apartheid Journals Are Warned by Pretoria
abstract: LEAD: Four months after adopting emergency powers enabling it to censor or close publications it deems subversive, the South African Government has warned that it may use the powers against five of the country's most forthright anti-apartheid journals.

headline: Investor Seeking A Chicken Chain
abstract: LEAD: Francis J. Spillman, a Dallas investor, has offered to purchase all of the shares of the Winners Corporation that he does not already control for $4.25 a share in cash, or about $15.4 million. In a telephone interview, Mr. Spillman said that he had had ''preliminary discussions with another chicken chain'' about the possible takeover of Winners.

headline: 2.8% Decline In Orders For Durables
abstract: LEAD: Orders to United States factories for ''big ticket'' durable goods fell 2.8 percent in January, the biggest decline in a year, reflecting sharp drops in demand for aircraft and primary metals, the Government reported today.

headline: GORBACHEV URGES ARMENIANS TO END NATIONALIST FUROR
abstract: LEAD: Mikhail S. Gorbachev, faced with one of his most difficult challenges since taking office, called on Armenians today to end nationalist protests that have disrupted two Soviet southern republics.

headline: Congress Seeks Trade Bill Soon
abstract: LEAD: Striving to find compromises that will enable Congress to pass a trade bill this week, leaders of the House and the Senate began a major effort today to sort out their differences.

headline: Germans Open Terror Trial Against Lebanese
abstract: LEAD: Abbas Ali Hamadei, a dual Lebanese-West German citizen, went on trial here today on kidnapping and other charges.

headline: Merger of 7-Up And Dr Pepper
abstract: LEAD: The boards at holding companies for Dr Pepper and Seven-Up have tentatively agreed to merge the privately held soft-drink companies, it was announced today. Terms were not disclosed.

headline: Coup Attempt in Sao Tome In West Africa Is Put Down
abstract: LEAD: Authorities in the West African island nation of Sao Tome and Principe crushed an attempted coup today, killing 2 of the 40 insurgents who tried to seize the police headquarters, a Portuguese radio station reported.

headline: Advocate of Independence Wins in Gibraltar
abstract: LEAD: Joe Bossano, leader of the Gibraltar Socialist Labor Party and an advocate of independence for this British colony, was declared the victor today in local elections.

headline: General Is Named to Head Arms Control Agency
abstract: LEAD: President Reagan has chosen Maj. Gen. William F. Burns as director of the Arms Control and Disarmament Agency, the White House announced today.

headline: Gain in Dow Is Cut to 1.33 After Plunge in Bond Prices
abstract: LEAD: Stock prices closed mixed yesterday after a seesaw session marked by index-arbitrage-related program trading, a ''triple witching hour'' and heavy volume.

headline: PANEL'S CONCERN: POWER, NOT PANIC
abstract: LEAD: The idea that less than 10 large financial institutions could bring the financial system to its knees through their unrelenting selling of stocks and financial instruments that set off the selling of stocks is a terrifying prospect. But that in essence is what the Presidential commission on the stock collapse concluded.

headline: EX-HBO VIDEO CHIEF HEADING REEBOK UNIT
abstract: LEAD: Frank J. O'Connell, who has been chief executive of HBO Video, has signed on with Reebok International Ltd. as president of the Reebok brands, which include the Reebok footwear and apparel divisions in North America.

headline: Both Sides on Contra Aid See Vote Shifting Their Way
abstract: LEAD: White House officials and Congressional Democrats asserted today that their latest counts showed the undecided votes in Congress on renewed aid to the contras were turning their way, but neither side was openly confident of victory.

headline: Prudential Bonds Backed By Life Insurance Loans
abstract: LEAD: The Prudential Insurance Company and its subsidiary, Prudential-Bache Securities, yesterday disclosed an innovative $445.6 million sale of bonds backed by loans to life insurance policyholders.

headline: Rapid Rate Drop Seen Slowing
abstract: LEAD: Interest rates are still far lower than a month ago, but as the Treasury concluded three consecutive days of note and bond auctions totaling $27 billion yesterday, there were signs that the rapid decline in rates had leveled off.

headline: Talking Business; with Cooney of the N.A.M.; Takeover Curbs On Foreigners
abstract: LEAD: As part of a sweeping trade bill expected to be concluded this week, Congressional and Administration negotiators have agreed to give the President authority to block foreign acquisitions of American companies if national security is believed to be threatened.

headline: Retail Sales Gain of 5.8% Seen for 1988
abstract: LEAD: The chief economist for Sears, Roebuck & Company predicted yesterday that sales of general merchandise would increase 5.8 percent in 1988, compared with a 5.2 percent rise last year.

headline: Reservoir Bursts in Soviet
abstract: LEAD: A sewage reservoir burst in Soviet Kazakhstan on Friday, releasing a towering wave of stagnant water and gravel that destroyed two bridges and caused deaths, the Communist Party newspaper Pravda reported today. Without giving a casualty toll, Pravda said people were killed when the mud slide destroyed a bridge on the road between Kapchagai and Alma-Ata, capital of the Soviet republic in Central Asia.

headline: Bulgarian Free Zones
abstract: LEAD: Bulgaria has established two duty-free zones to ''encourage economic cooperation'' between Bulgarian and foreign companies, the state-run press agency reported today. It said the zones had been set up in Rousse and Vidin to offer areas where ''economic activities can be carried out'' without duties or taxes.

headline: Addendum
abstract: LEAD: * Middleberg Middleton has changed its name to Middleberg Middleton Picower, for its third partner, Mary Gendron Picower.

headline: In Japan, Wondering About a Capital
abstract: LEAD: For 1,074 years Japan sank its imperial roots in Kyoto, a city of graceful temples and soothing gardens. Then, in 1868, the national center was moved to Tokyo.

headline: Bridgestone's New U.S. Challenge
abstract: LEAD: If the Bridgestone Corporation of Japan can perform the kind of magic at the Firestone Tire and Rubber Company's tire plants that it has performed at its own plant here, one thing appears certain: The American tire business will become even more competitive.

headline: Retail Sales Rose 0.5% In January
abstract: LEAD: In a report that many economists found reassuring, the Government said today that retail sales throughout the country climbed five-tenths of 1 percent in January and that December's sales, upon revision, were considerably higher than first estimated.

headline: Britain Names New Regulator
abstract: LEAD: Britain has replaced the chairman of its financial regulatory agency, the Securities and Investment Board.

headline: Snag at European Talks
abstract: LEAD: European Community ministers today resumed their struggle to agree on strict curbs on farm spending that could clear the way for a revamping of the near-bankrupt group's finances. Diplomats said differences remained unresolved after three days of talks last week and a session that lasted more than 10 hours on Saturday.

headline: 'New Breeze' Is Noted as the Sandinistas, With Eye on the U.S., Cast Aside Old Rules
abstract: LEAD: On Sunday morning, as about 2,000 anti-Government protesters made their way through Managua's dusty streets, a young man broke away from the march, ran toward the sidewalk and produced a can of spray paint.

headline: The 'Uprising' Fires Palestinian Pride
abstract: LEAD: ''It's miserable,'' said Asmaa Khroob, summing up life in the Balata refugee district, a grim warren of dirt streets, open sewers and low concrete-block houses.

headline: A Wild West Not Far From the Khyber Pass
abstract: LEAD: Local residents tell a visitor not to worry about the repeated bursts of automatic firing heard in this isolated settlement, the administrative center of Bajaur Agency, a district on the mountainous Afghan border. ''This is our Wild West,'' one said, showing perverse pride.

headline: Proxmire Fear On Bribe Law
abstract: LEAD: Senator William Proxmire, the Wisconsin Democrat who is chairman of the Banking Committee, today assailed a proposed compromise that he said would weaken the Foreign Corrupt Practices Act.

headline: New Chief Is Chosen At Burson-Marsteller
abstract: LEAD: Burson-Marsteller, whose revenues make it the largest public relations firm in the world, announced a top management change yesterday. James H. Dowling became the second chief executive in the company's 35-year history, succeeding Harold Burson, a co-founder.

headline: Societe Generale
abstract: LEAD: Societe Generale de Belgique, the giant Belgian conglomerate at the center of a takeover battle, said it would hold an extraordinary meeting of its shareholders on April 14. The gathering promises a showdown between the Italian financier Carlo de Benedetti and a rival alliance of French and Belgian companies unless the two camps can settle a two-month battle for control of Societe Generale de Belgique before then.

headline: Patents; Westinghouse Patents On Nuclear Equipment
abstract: LEAD: The Westinghouse Electric Corporation received eight patents this week relating to nuclear power equipment that it is producing for the world market.

headline: A Haitian Opposition Leader Is Seized After Tour Abroad
abstract: LEAD: With Haitians awaiting an announcement on the results of the flawed presidential election three days ago, the authorities detained a prominent opposition leader today as he returned home from an anti-Government campaign abroad.

headline: Stop and Shop To Study Offer
abstract: LEAD: The Stop and Shop Companies, responding to an $834 million cash offer from the Dart Group Corporation, was noncommittal yesterday but said it would review the proposal. The Haft family of Landover, Md., which controls Dart, has long been rumored to be interested in acquiring Stop and Shop, and the Boston-based retailer has taken defensive measures.

headline: A Smokestack in Poland Emits Odor of Indecision
abstract: LEAD: The Delta knitwear factory would simply be closed down, the article said, because environmental officials were tired of waiting for the company's management to put in chimney filters that stop soot.

headline: BRITAIN
abstract: LEAD: It was also a year of extremes in London. The Financial Times 100-share index closed the year at 1,712.14, up 2 percent from its opening for 1987 at 1,679. But in between, the market soared to new heights.

headline: Henley Drops Its Santa Fe Bid
abstract: LEAD: The Henley Group Inc. said today that it was dropping its threatened proxy fight for control of the Santa Fe Southern Pacific Corporation. In a Securities and Exchange

headline: DiFranza Williamson Acquired by Ketchum
abstract: LEAD: DiFranza Williamson Inc., a 32-year-old New York sales promotion agency, has been acquired by Ketchum Communications, a Pittsburgh-based advertising and public relations company.

headline: SOUTH AFRICA FIRM ON HANGING OF SIX
abstract: LEAD: President P. W. Botha has come under intense domestic and international pressure to spare the lives of six blacks who are scheduled to be hanged Friday for the killing of a black councilman by a mob in 1984. But hopes for a stay of executions faded tonight.

headline: Black & Decker Increases Bid for American Standard
abstract: LEAD: The Black & Decker Corporation announced yesterday that it was increasing its all-cash offer for American Standard Inc. by $9 a share, to $65 a share, or about $2 billion, for the New York-based producer of plumbing fixtures, air-conditioning units and transportation products.

headline: Government Gives Private Sector A Chance to Run Medicare Plans
abstract: LEAD: Thousands of retired clothing workers will participate in an experimental program in which their union's welfare fund will manage the retirees' health care using Medicare funds.

headline: Bell Atlantic Rebuts Panel In Inquiry on G.S.A. Bids
abstract: LEAD: The Bell Atlantic Corporation yesterday rebutted a Senate committee's accusations that one of its officials had admitted receiving confidential bid information from a Government employee about a telephone-switching contract.

headline: USX Expects Charge Tied to Oil Price Drop
abstract: LEAD: The USX Corporation said today that it expects to take a charge against fourth-quarter earnings to reflect the decline in value of oil inventories at its Marathon Oil Company subsidiary.

headline: Advertising; Equimark, in Search, Names Four Finalists
abstract: LEAD: The Equimark Corporation, a Pittsburgh-based financial holding company, has not only announced it is searching for a new agency but also the names of the four finalists, all in New York.

headline: Europe's Inflation Rate
abstract: LEAD: Consumer prices in the 12 member countries of the European Community edged up a tenth of a percent in December to an average of 3.2 percent for 1987, Eurostat, the community's statistical service, reported today.

headline: Mexico City Journal; Economists' Day Dawns; Twilight for Lawyers?
abstract: LEAD: An old Mexican saying has it that every student who enrolls at the law school of the National Autonomous University of Mexico here does so ''dreaming of someday wearing the presidential sash across his chest.''

headline: A New 'Fast Lane' in Computers
abstract: LEAD: When Andreas V. Bechtolsheim, a Stanford University graduate student, could not find a computer that would satisfy his needs, he built his own, a machine that used standard microprocessors and software and easily connected to other computers.

headline: Austria Asks: Accomplice of Nazis, or Victim?
abstract: LEAD: At the center of an exhibition that opens Thursday in the Vienna City hall is a wooden platform that the contemporary Austrian is encouraged to mount to look out over a broad tree-lined lane leading to the ornate Burgtheater.

headline: Ford to Overhaul 2 Plants in Ohio
abstract: LEAD: The Ford Motor Company said it would invest $320 million in two Ohio plants that are to manufacture a new-generation Ford Thunderbird and Mercury Cougar.

headline: A Costly Surprise From Mutual Funds
abstract: LEAD: THOUSANDS of investors who thought they had outsmarted the tax collector by year-end selling of mutual funds in which they had big losses received an unpleasant surprise during the last few weeks. Large capital gains distributions from the funds, paid in 1988 but taxable in 1987, have upset their careful tax-planning maneuvers.

headline: Note and Bond Prices in Retreat
abstract: LEAD: Treasury note and bond prices fell modestly yesterday as securities dealers absorbed $9 billion of new 10-year notes and prepared to bid today for $8.75 billion of new 30-year bonds.

headline: Australia Is Investigating 200 for Nazi Crimes
abstract: LEAD: More than 200 immigrants to Australia are under ''active investigation'' as possible Nazi war criminals and could face trial here, a special prosecutor said today.

headline: U.S. to Compensate Defector
abstract: LEAD: Administration officials said tonight that the Nicaraguan military official who defected last fall, Roger Miranda Bengoechea, would get an unusually large payment from the United States Government.

headline: Sallie Mae Notes
abstract: LEAD: The Student Loan Marketing Association offered $500 million of 8.20 percent notes, due in 1993, through various securities dealers. The Sallie Mae notes, due in five years and two months, were offered at a price of 100 and yield about 37-hundredths of a percentage point more than five-year Treasury notes.

headline: Officials Call Border Dispute An Obstacle in Afghan Talks
abstract: LEAD: A border dispute between Afghanistan and Pakistan has emerged as a new obstacle to a treaty ending the Afghan civil war and allowing the withdrawal of Soviet troops, according to officials close to the negotiations.

headline: Advertising; A Shuffle at the Top Of McCaffrey & McCall
abstract: LEAD: Robert H. Cherins, the 47-year-old chief executive of Saatchi & Saatchi's McCaffrey & McCall, is stepping up to chairman, as the founder, David B. McCall, shifts to chairman of the executive committee. That leaves the president's title void but only for a trice, for into it leaps the former vice chairman, Gary D.

headline: Airbus Urged to Press Its McDonnell Talks
abstract: LEAD: The transportation ministers of France, West Germany, Britain and Spain today called on Airbus Industrie, the European airplane consortium, to step up its discussions with the McDonnell Douglas Corporation to help establish a cooperative agreement between the two rivals.

headline: October's Specter Lurks Over '88
abstract: LEAD: The stock market opens the New Year under a shadow. The trauma of October has reintroduced the fear of losing money.

headline: Mexico City Journal; Forget the Alamo! Look at the Sins of the Yankees
abstract: LEAD: At the entrance stands Uncle Sam, his ax raised triumphantly over a prostrate Mexico. But inside the National Museum of Intervention, the tables are turned, and it is the United States that comes under unrelenting attack.

headline: Vance and Rogers Press for Arms Treaty
abstract: LEAD: Two former Secretaries of State, one a Republican and one a Democrat, warned the Senate today that failure to approve a new treaty eliminating medium- and shorter-range missiles would have ''devastating'' consequences for the United States and its NATO partners.

headline: Hutton's Demise
abstract: LEAD: To the Editor:

headline: A Captain's Ideals Lead Him to Jail
abstract: LEAD: Meir Amor, a captain in the Israeli reserve army, has just completed a 21-day jail sentence for refusing an order to serve in the occupied territories.

headline: Iraq Denies That It Requested Guarantees for Pipeline Plan
abstract: LEAD: Iraq said today that it had not sought ''political guarantees'' from Israel or other parties in negotiations in 1984 over a projected oil pipeline to Jordan.

headline: Broker in Winans Case Is Sentenced
abstract: LEAD: Peter N. Brant, a former stockbroker who was a major prosecution witness in the R. Foster Winans case, was sentenced yesterday to eight months in prison for trading stocks using inside information about forthcoming articles in The Wall Street Journal.

headline: Dividend Meetings
abstract: LEAD: Following is a partial list of dividend meetings for the week of Jan. 10, 1988:  MONDAY  La-Z-Boy Chair Co...Phillips Petroleum  Oxford Indus  TUESDAY  Diversified Energies...TECO Energy  Procter & Gamble  WEDNESDAY  Bard (CR)...Walgreen Co  Pacificorp...Wisconsin Pwr & Lt  Transco Energy...Woolworth (FW) Co  USLIFE Inc Fd

headline: 2 Savings Units Acquired
abstract: LEAD: Two failed Oklahoma savings and loan associations with assets totaling $168 million were taken over by Midwest Federal Savings and Loan Association of Minneapolis, the Federal Home Loan Bank Board said Friday. The action is expected to cost the Federal Savings and Loan Insurance Corporation $76 million, the bank board said.

headline: A Debate Over the Impact Of Delaware Takeover Law
abstract: LEAD: The rules governing many corporate takeovers are about to change dramatically, all with the stroke of a pen in Wilmington, Del. The state's Governor, Michael N. Castle, is expected to sign tomorrow a bill that makes unfriendly takeovers harder.

headline: More Gains Foreseen for Bonds
abstract: LEAD: Long-simmering hopes that interest rates will decline boiled over Friday after Government statistics showed a large drop in the nation's trade deficit and lower-than-expected inflation.

headline: A Vital Shadow Society: East Bloc Breadwinner
abstract: LEAD: Across Eastern Europe a shadow society has sprung up outside of the control of the ruling Communist parties, tolerated because the authorities have neither the money nor the ability to fulfill Marxism-Leninism's promise to build a better life for working people.

headline: Trade Deficit $159.2 Billion
abstract: LEAD: The United States foreign trade deficit was a seasonally adjusted $40.17 billion in October through December, bringing the total deficit to a record $159.2 billion in 1987, the Commerce Department said today.

headline: Hungary, Suzuki Discuss Venture
abstract: LEAD: Hungary is holding talks with the Suzuki Motor Company and other Japanese companies to set up its first car assembly plant in a joint venture worth 10 billion forints, or about $210 million, the Hungarian press agency said. The assembly of 50,000 Suzuki Alto mini-cars annually could begin in two years, the press agency said.

headline: U.S. and Britain Veto U.N. Move To Impose Penalties on Pretoria
abstract: LEAD: The United States and Britain vetoed a Security Council resolution today that would have imposed an oil embargo and other sanctions against South Africa for its imposition of restrictions on 17 anti-apartheid groups.

headline: Orion Stake Raised
abstract: LEAD: Sumner M. Redstone, the chairman of Viacom International Inc., has increased his stake in the Orion Pictures Corporation to 26.1 percent from 25.1 percent. Analysts said Mr. Redstone was interested in acquiring Orion's motion picture and television production operations to augment Viacom's cable and movie theater businesses.

headline: Citadel Makes Bid
abstract: LEAD: The Citadel Holding Corporation said it had made a $18.50-a-share, or $107.3 million, offer to buy Valley Federal Savings and Loan Association, the first hostile takeover attempt in California's thrift industry. Valley Federal, based in Van Nuys, Calif., has $3.1 billion in assets and 47 offices. Valley Federal, trying to avert a takeover by Citadel, is talking with other potential merger partners.

headline: Personal Income Gains; Consumer Outlays Rise
abstract: LEAD: Americans' personal incomes rose in February at the fastest pace in four months while consumer spending was propelled upward by a rebound in car sales.

headline: Trade Deficit a Bit Bigger Over All But Improves by 18% With Japan
abstract: LEAD: The nation's deficit in foreign trade widened slightly in January, to $12.4 billion, a $200 million increase over December's total. But the deficit showed significant improvement with major trading partners like Japan and the countries of Western Europe, the Commerce Department reported today.

headline: BULGARIAN REJECTS POLITICAL OPENING
abstract: LEAD: A top Communist Party official today defended Bulgaria's lack of eagerness to accompany its program of restructuring economic and administrative life with a parallel emphasis on greater openness.

headline: PILLSBURY RESTAURANT CUTBACKS SET
abstract: LEAD: The Pillsbury Company said yesterday that it planned to sell or close about 103 of its fast-food and full-service restaurants to improve sagging corporate profits.

headline: Seagram to Buy Tropicana Products
abstract: LEAD: Faced with a steady cooling in America's love affair with Scotch whisky and other so-called brown goods, the Seagram Company Ltd. said yesterday that it would buy Tropicana Products Inc., makers of Tropicana orange juice, for $1.2 billion from the Beatrice Company.

headline: Gorbachev Puts Blame for Strife On Predecessors
abstract: LEAD: Arriving in a nation that has long experienced intense ethnic friction, Mikhail S. Gorbachev today attributed the strife in the southern Soviet republics to years of neglect by earlier Soviet leaders.

headline: Emhart's Plans For Stanadyne
abstract: LEAD: The Emhart Corporation said it would consider selling all of Stanadyne Inc.'s non-plumbing businesses if its $40-a-share hostile tender offer is successful. In a filing with the Securities and Exchange Commission, Emhart also said that it had received a commitment for $600 million to complete the takeover from a syndicate of banks led by the Bankers Trust Company.

headline: Output in 1987 Up 5.2%, Biggest Gain Since 1984
abstract: LEAD: The nation's industrial output climbed 5.2 percent in 1987, almost five times the previous year's gain and the best showing for American industry since 1984, the Government reported today.

headline: Reagan Denies Meese Impropriety, Seeing a 'Lynch Mob Atmosphere'
abstract: LEAD: President Reagan defended Attorney General Edwin Meese 3d tonight against accusations of impropriety and said his opponents had created ''a kind of lynch mob atmosphere'' that unfairly charged members of his Administration with ethical misconduct.

headline: The Targets of Pretoria
abstract: LEAD: In its crackdown today, the Government restricted the activities of 17 anti-apartheid organizations and one labor federation. Here are the names and descriptions of the groups: Azanian People's Organization (Azapo).

headline: Armenian Hopes Are Dashed As Soviet Condemns Unrest
abstract: LEAD: The Soviet national press and television opened a sharp attack today on the campaign that drew hundreds of thousands of Armenians into the streets last month, sending a clear signal that the protesters' demands will not be met.

headline: Billions Are in Play Today in Mexico's Bond Sale
abstract: LEAD: Bankers were playing a guessing game yesterday, trying to gauge how many banks around the world will bid for the novel Mexican bonds being offered today at a special auction and the prices at which they might be offered.

headline: Israeli Army Reinforces Troops in Gaza
abstract: LEAD: The Israeli Army poured reinforcements into the Gaza Strip today but failed to quell continued violence as two more Palestinians died of army gunshot wounds.

headline: TOP CONTENDERS IN HAITI DECLARE BOYCOTT OF VOTE
abstract: LEAD: Less than two weeks before the presidential election scheduled by Haiti's army-dominated Government, the four leading candidates have carried out their threat to call a boycott and the field is dominated by seven former associates of the deposed Duvalier dictatorship.

headline: BUSINESS DIGEST: SATURDAY, JANUARY 9, 1988
abstract: LEAD:  Markets

headline: Charm Fades for Americans Living in Canal Zone
abstract: LEAD: With tensions here running high, the Administrator of the Panama Canal met last week with American residents of the former Canal Zone to discuss emergency evacuation plans. But the meeting had to be adjourned after the headquarters of the Canal Commission received a bomb threat.

headline: BUSINESS DIGEST: MONDAY, FEBRUARY 22, 1988
abstract: LEAD:  Companies

headline: The U.N. Today
abstract: LEAD: General Assembly  Meets at 10 A.M. and 3 P.M.  COMMITTEE ON ELIMINATION OF DISCRIMINATION AGAINST WOMEN - 10 A.M. and 3 P.M.  SPECIAL COMMITTEE ON CHARTER - 10:30 A.M. and 3 P.M.

headline: Iran and Iraq Call a Halt to Missile Strikes on Cities
abstract: LEAD: After 12 days and hundreds of casualties, Iran and Iraq stopped missile attacks on each other's cities this afternoon. But each side threatened to resume the strikes if the other broke the unofficial truce.

headline: TEXACO WILL PAY $1.2 BILLION TO U.S. FOR OVERCHARGES
abstract: LEAD: Texaco Inc. agreed yesterday to pay the Energy Department $1.25 billion to settle a complaint that it had overcharged customers for crude oil and refined oil products between 1973 and 1981, when Federal price controls were in effect.

headline: Advertising; Scott Paper Narrows Search to 5 Agencies
abstract: LEAD: The Scott Paper Company, which announced March 2 that it would be looking for at least one new ad agency, reported Friday that it had narrowed the list of contenders to five.

headline: Patents; Fees Not Paid, 150 Patents Expire
abstract: LEAD: This week's Official Gazette of the Patent and Trademark Office includes a list of 150 patents that expired on Jan. 3 because maintenance fees were not paid.
