headline: Black & Decker Discloses Proposal
abstract: LEAD: The Black & Decker Corporation disclosed that it had offered American Standard Inc. ''major concessions,'' including a possible higher price than its current bid of $65 a share, if the big plumbing supplier would agree to a friendly business combination. In a filing with the Securities and Exchange Commission, Black & Decker said that Nolan D.

headline: Contra Forces Reported on Verge of 3-Way Split
abstract: LEAD: The commander of United States forces in Latin America has said that the Nicaraguan rebels are on the verge of a three-way split that will erode and possibly destroy their military strength.

headline: Regionals Rise in Bank Ranking
abstract: LEAD: As giant banks flounder and regional banks flourish, the turmoil churning the nation's banking system is beginning to show up in the rankings of the nation's largest banking companies.

headline: Violence Erupts Again in Bangladesh Vote
abstract: LEAD: Election-related violence broke out in three cities near the capital today, a day after similar violence left at least 80 people dead, officials said.

headline: Stake in Christie's Bought by Phillips
abstract: LEAD: Phillips Son & Neale, a London auction house, said it had acquired a 5 percent stake in the much larger Christie's. The auction house bought 1.6 million shares from a Kuwaiti investor, the Al Futtooh Investment Company.

headline: BRIEFS
abstract: LEAD: * British Petroleum Co., London, said it had received 79.8 percent of Britoil P.L.C.'s shares and that it was extending the closing date of its $:2.5 billion offer to next Wednesday.

headline: Firefighters Strike in Dublin
abstract: LEAD: Firefighters went on strike here today for the first time in 20 years, and 300 soldiers trained for firefighting and emergency services handled emergency calls. Talks between the 800 firefighters and the city broke down early today. The dispute is over staffing, training and what the firefighters' unions say are breaches of wage agreements.

headline: U.S. General Tells of 'Shady' Dealings by Noriega
abstract: LEAD: The former commanding general of the United State Southern Command, based in Panama, said today that although Gen. Manuel Antonio Noriega of Panama was a ''venal'' politician, American Embassy officials described him as extremely cooperative in helping the United States crack down on drug trafficking.

headline: PROSPECTS
abstract: LEAD:  Investment Boom?

headline: Plum Resumes Bidding for Holly
abstract: LEAD: The New York investor group Plum Associates, which appeared to have lost a takeover bid for the Holly Sugar Corporation to the Imperial Sugar Company, re-emerged as a suitor. In its third proposal in two weeks, Plum Associates, a group headed by Peter R. Harvey of Illinois, is now offering to acquire 60 percent of the company's stock at $92.50 a share, or $61.5 million, instead of the previous cash price of $85 a share, or $56.5 million.

headline: Market Place; Analysts Favor Tobacco Stocks
abstract: LEAD: PRODUCT liability lawsuits involving the effects of cigarette smoking have in recent years created a cloud over tobacco stocks. But a number of Wall Street analysts believe that investor fears on this score are overblown.

headline: Congressmen See Confrontation Over Contra Aid
abstract: LEAD: Congressional leaders said today that President Reagan's request in his State of the Union message for renewed aid to the Nicaraguan rebels had placed the Administration squarely in confrontation with Congress at the start of the new legislative year.

headline: ISRAEL SAYS ARABS UNDER DETENTION NOW NUMBER 3,000
abstract: LEAD: Israel said today that it was detaining 3,000 Palestinians in connection with the protests in the occupied territories, including 700 arrested in the last week alone.

headline: Carlucci Calls for New Tactical Missiles
abstract: LEAD: Secretary of Defense Frank C. Carlucci and ranking American legislators called upon West Germany and other European allies today to fulfill a five-year-old alliance commitment to modernize short-range nuclear weapons.

headline: Bid for USG Stalls
abstract: LEAD: Two wealthy Texas oilmen, Cyril Wagner Jr. and Jack E. Brown, said they had been unable to obtain financing for a hostile takeover of the USG Corporation. In a Securities and Exchange Commission filing, the men's investor group, called Desert Partners, said that it had been advised by an unidentified investment banking firm that subordinated debt financing for a hostile bid of USG was impossible ''under current market conditions.

headline: Market Place; Buying Laggards Of Previous Year
abstract: LEAD: THE worst performers in the Dow Jones industrial average sometimes turn into winners the following year. This laggard approach to investing is of more than passing interest on Wall Street, where any theory that pans out even once in a while - dart-throwing comes to mind - engenders a certain respect.

headline: French Inflation Down
abstract: LEAD: French consumer price inflation fell sharply, to an annual rate of 2.4 percent last month from 3.1 percent in December, the National Statistics Institute said today. It attributed the fall mostly to exceptionally high price rises recorded in January 1987, which had an inflation rate of nine-tenths of 1 percent.

headline: Korea Tariff Cut Praised
abstract: LEAD: United States Government officials today applauded an announcement by South Korea that it would lower import tariffs on cars and more than 400 other products next month. The Ministry of Finance said the move was intended to curb inflation and reduce the country's trade surplus.

headline: Business and Health; Corporations Join Efforts on AIDS
abstract: LEAD: AFTER KPIX-TV in San Francisco became the first television station to cover AIDS aggressively in 1983, representatives of the station discussed a nationwide television education effort with the parent company, the Westinghouse Broadcasting Corporation.

headline: NICARAGUA AGREES TO TALK DIRECTLY WITH THE CONTRAS
abstract: LEAD: In a last-minute concession after two days of difficult bargaining, President Daniel Ortega Saavedra of Nicaragua agreed today to open direct talks with rebel leaders and to suspend a state of emergency in Nicaragua.

headline: Israeli General Describes Charges Of Brutal Beatings as 'Just Stories'
abstract: LEAD: A top Israeli general said today that beatings of Palestinian civilians by troops were ''exceptions'' to Government policy and that many of the widespread complaints of brutality were rooted in ''imagination.''

headline: Case Heard on Death of an I.B.M. Official
abstract: LEAD: In a small Federal courtroom in lower Manhattan, six jurors are trying to put a price on the life of a man who, some say, might have become chairman of the International Business Machines Corporation.

headline: British Jobless Rate Dips
abstract: LEAD: Unemployment in Britain fell to a seasonally adjusted 9.1 percent in February from 9.2 percent in January, the Government said today. The figure stood at 11 percent in February 1987, the Department of Employment said.

headline: Litton Chief Expected To Add Chairman Post
abstract: LEAD: Orion L. Hoch, a physicist and electrical engineer who left Litton Industries to revive an ailing semiconductor company, is expected to be elected Litton's chairman on March 31.

headline: 18 Youths Seized in Moscow After a Fierce Street Battle
abstract: LEAD: Hundreds of Moscow youths battled each other with sticks and iron bars in a street fight last month and 18 people were arrested, the police said today.

headline: U.S. Petroleum Data
abstract: LEAD: In millions of barrels except refinery utilization      $      Feb. 26   Feb. 19   Feb. 27        1988   1988   1987       Gasoline production, daily   6.6   6.6   6.6        Distillate production, daily   2.5   2.6   2.5        Gasoline stocks   238.9   240.3   252.9        Distillate stocks   110.2   112.6   127.1        Crude imports, daily   4.7   4.2   4.0        Product imports, daily   1.8   2.3   2.4        Crude stocks   338.9   333.4   329.4        Crude production, daily   8.2   8.2   8.3        Refinery utilization (%)   81.3   81.4   78.1

headline: G.E. Seen In the Lead For Ward
abstract: LEAD: The General Electric Company has emerged as the leading candidate to buy Montgomery Ward or lead a leveraged buyout of the revitalized, 315-store chain, investment bankers said yesterday.

headline: Palestinians Turn Ire on Collaborators
abstract: LEAD: Bicharra Qumsaya kneaded the black worry beads in his right hand as he scanned the faces of his neighbors crowded into the Greek Orthodox Church. He wore a well-tailored dark suit and the traditional white Arab headdress, held in place with a double black band.

headline: U.S. Cites Aid to Manila
abstract: LEAD: The United States is committed to helping the Philippine economic recovery by stepping up investments, keeping its doors open to imports and maintaining aid flows, United States Ambassador Nicholas Platt said today. He told a meeting of American business executives that the Philippines had a trade surplus of $640 million with the United States in 1987 compared with a surplus of $461 million in 1986.

headline: Top Specialist Gives Up Role in Morgan Stock
abstract: LEAD: In the first of what is expected to be a series of sanctions resulting from the stock market crash, the New York Stock Exchange said yesterday that the largest specialist firm on the exchange was giving up its right to make a market in an important stock, that of J.P. Morgan & Company.

headline: Armenian Leaders Call Off Rally Planned for Saturday
abstract: LEAD: Organizers of the protests that brought a sea of people into Yerevan's streets last month have called off plans to resume protests Saturday in the Armenian capital, according to a Yerevan resident reached by telephone tonight.

headline: Calcutta Journal; A Communist Who's Gone Far, but Not Far Left
abstract: LEAD: For as long as anyone can remember, this crowded and squalid old city has danced to the rhythm of labor strikes, political agitations and Marxist theorizing.

headline: At NATO Parley, Reagan Reassures
abstract: LEAD: Asserting that military resolve had produced a treaty to dismantle medium-range missiles, President Reagan declared today that the United States would never sacrifice allied interests to get an arms accord with the Soviet Union.

headline: Shamir Resists Shultz on Parts Of Peace Plan
abstract: LEAD: Secretary of State George P. Shultz was reported to have met resistance today from Prime Minister Yitzhak Shamir to at least two key elements of American proposals aimed at starting Arab-Israeli peace talks.

headline: WHAT'S NEW IN CONSUMER ELECTRONICS
abstract: LEAD: IN the annals of consumer electronics, 1987 will go down as the year in which sales of video cassette recorders stopped growing. Now, beset by the falling dollar and shrinking profit margins, the industry is looking for its next blockbuster product.

headline: SAUDIS CANCEL TAX AFTER COMPLAINTS
abstract: LEAD: Saudi Arabia rescinded a sweeping package of income taxes on foreigners today following protests from foreign workers and Saudi businessmen. The taxes had been instituted by royal decree only a few days ago.

headline: Kluge Files to Buy More Orion Shares
abstract: LEAD: John W. Kluge, the chairman of the Metromedia Company, is seeking Federal antitrust clearance to raise his stake in the Orion Pictures Company to as much as 50 percent. In a Securities and Exchange Commission filing, Mr. Kluge said that the purchases of shares in the New York-based motion picture and television company would be for investment purposes.

headline: Israel Says Troops in Arab Areas Will Be More Closely Supervised
abstract: LEAD: The Israeli Army, concerned about reports of excessive brutality and beatings of Palestinians by Israeli soldiers, said today it would take steps to increase supervision of soldiers in the field.

headline: Fidelity Investments to Lay Off 800
abstract: LEAD: Fidelity Investments announced today that it was laying off about 800 people, or 10.5 percent of its employees, as a result of declining mutual fund sales and lower sales of Individual Retirement Accounts.

headline: Business and Health; Early Retirement: A Surprising Cost
abstract: LEAD: COST-CONSCIOUS corporations that seek to induce employees to take early retirement by offering them continued health-care benefits as part of a compensation package are discovering that the health care can become unexpectedly expensive over time.

headline: After Chernobyl, Africans Ask if Food Is Hot
abstract: LEAD: ''Chernobyl in Banjul?'' read a recent headline in an African magazine.

headline: The Pentagon Needs Less High Tech
abstract: LEAD: America spends too much for its military and receives too little for its money. The military consumes 6.7 percent of gross national product and 32 percent of America's research and development expenditures. Germany spends 3.1 percent of G.N.P. and employs 6 percent of its R.&D. talent in the service of its defense; Japan spends even less.

headline: Japan Car Imports Rise
abstract: LEAD: Sales of foreign cars in Japan rose 42.9 percent in January, to 5,957, the Japan Automobile Importers Association said today.

headline: LATIN PEACE HOPES SEEM TO BE BLEAK BEFORE KEY TALKS
abstract: LEAD: The prospects for peace in Central America appear bleak as the region's leaders prepare to meet next week to judge the results of the peace plan they signed five months ago.

headline: Japanese Fight Invading Sea For Priceless Speck of Land
abstract: LEAD: Japan, always a bit self-conscious about its limited size, has taken a giant step to keep itself from shrinking.

headline: About Real Estate; Brooklyn School Converted to Housing
abstract: LEAD: Two years ago, when Norman Kirscher, a Brooklyn developer and president of Blanner Realty, was shown Cathedral Prep School, an ornate stone and brick cluster of buildings in the Clinton-Fort Greene section, he saw immediately that it fit his formula for producing middle-class housing.

headline: Hutton's End
abstract: LEAD: To the Editor:

headline: U.S. Charges 9 In Mexico Death Of a Drug Agent
abstract: LEAD: Nine men, including three former Mexican police officials, were indicted today in connection with the torture and murder of a Drug Enforcement Administration agent in Mexico in 1985, the Justice Department announced.

headline: Capital Rise Expected To Gain in World Bank
abstract: LEAD: The 151 member governments of the World Bank are expected to agree this week to a $75 billion increase in capital, but Congressional leaders warned that it would be unusually difficult to persuade Congress to approve United States participation in this election year.

headline: FINANCE/NEW ISSUES;
abstract: LEAD: The Williams Companies is offering $200 million of notes in two parts through a group of underwriters led by the First Boston Corporation.

headline: Short Sales Outstanding Rise by 19.8% on Nasdaq
abstract: LEAD: The National Association of Securities Dealers reported yesterday that the over-the-counter market's ''short interest'' position -the number of shares sold short and not yet covered -in the month ended Feb. 12 soared by 34.7 million shares, or 19.8 percent.

headline: Don't Make Bets on the Predictions
abstract: LEAD: THE recent upheaval in the stock market proves once again how unpredictable the world is. Few forecasters had spotted the timing and extent of the fall; fewer still had foreseen the prolonged rise.

headline: Campeau Raises Its Offer Again
abstract: LEAD: Seeking a knockout blow in its battle to win Federated Department Stores, the Campeau Corporation made higher offers to both Federated's shareholders and board yesterday.

headline: PROSPECTS
abstract: LEAD:  Mexico's Debt Plan, Will It Work?

headline: Saudis Deny Their Missiles Will Have Nuclear Warheads
abstract: LEAD: Saudi Arabia confirmed Saturday that is is buying Chinese intermediate-range missiles, but said they would not be armed with nuclear warheads.

headline: Stocks Rise After Report On Trade
abstract: LEAD: Stock prices moved higher yesterday in what traders said was a subdued response to the better-than-expected drop in the United States trade deficit.

headline: Shultz Rebuts Asian Official
abstract: LEAD: An Asian official's public attack on a recent United States trade decision sparked a face-to-face confrontation rarely seen in a diplomatic setting and a toughly worded lecture today from Secretary of State George P. Shultz.

headline: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
abstract: LEAD: * AFA Financial, Cleveland, an investment manager, elected James M. Mendell president and chief executive.

headline: What to Do With Worthless Options
abstract: LEAD: STOCK options took a bath in the October stock plunge, forcing corporate boards to wrestle with two problems: First, should they make up the losses for executives whose profits from options were wiped out by the collapse? Second, given the market's volatility, how could options be tailored to provide a buffer against a repeat performance?

headline: Will TV's and Stereos Cost More?
abstract: LEAD: Consumers long accustomed to a deluge of sophisticated electronic products that have continually declined in price might be in for a rude awakening this year. For the first time in years, prices of televisions, stereos, compact disk players and video cassette recorders appear to be going up.

headline: Japan News Cuts Treasury Prices
abstract: LEAD: Prices for short- and long-term Treasury securities declined modestly yesterday.

headline: U.S. to Resume Sending Arms to Contras
abstract: LEAD: President Reagan formally reported to Congress today that he did not believe the Nicaraguan Government was trying in good faith to comply with the Central American peace plan. Under the law, that allowed the Administration to resume weapons shipments to the contras that had been suspended for a week.

headline: REAGAN STRESSES DIFFICULTY OF SUMMIT ISSUES
abstract: LEAD: President Reagan said today that pre-summit conference talks have ''made clear how difficult the issues are between the United States and the Soviet Union'' and that it remains to be seen how much good the sessions in Moscow this spring will do.

headline: Advertising; Accounts
abstract: LEAD: * Business Week's Business Information Program to Sader & Associates for advertising and direct marketing.

headline: Iran and Iraq Fire Missiles For the 5th Day at Capitals
abstract: LEAD: Iran and Iraq mounted new missile attacks at each other today in a long-range rocket duel, which has lasted five days and killed scores of people.

headline: COMPANY BRIEFS
abstract: LEAD: * Ameron Inc., Monterey Park, Calif., a maker of construction products, basic steel products and protective coatings and liners, said it had repurchased 911,400 common shares, or about 18.6 percent, from Industrial Equity Pacific Ltd. for $36 a share, a total of $32.8 million.

headline: Bid for Rover Proceeding
abstract: LEAD: Price appears to be the only thing standing in the way of British Aerospace P.L.C.'s surprise bid to take over Britain's state-owned car manufacturer, Rover.

headline: The Prosecutor's Inquiry: 4 Major Targets
abstract: LEAD: The special prosecutor in the Iran-contra affair is expected to reach a decision soon about whether to bring indictments against four prominent subjects of his investigation. Here are descriptions of their roles in the affair:  JOHN M. POINDEXTER  Vice admiral and national security adviser from December 1985 to November 1986, when he was allowed to resign.

headline: BUSINESS FORUM: CORPORATE STREAMLINING; The Right Way to Shrink a Company
abstract: LEAD: LAST year's holiday season was a time of mixed blessings for many middle managers and staff professionals. The holidays coincided with the end of many corporate fiscal years, the time when the pressure is often greatest to increase results by cutting costs. Unfortunately this meant that for thousands the festive spirit was dampened by the news that they were losing their jobs.

headline: Fruehauf Unit Sale
abstract: LEAD: The Fruehauf Corporation has completed the sale of its 91 percent stake in Fruehauf Canada, a truck and trailer servicing operation, to FRH Acquisitions, an affiliate of the Trailmobile Group of Companies of Brantford, Ontario. The sale totaled about $96 million (Canadian), equal to $74.5 million (American), or about $30.20 (American) a share.

headline: Yeutter Warns Korea on Trade
abstract: LEAD: Clayton K. Yeutter, the United States trade representative, said today that if South Korea and other Asian nations did not end what he called unfair trading practices, they would face retaliation and curbs on their exports.

headline: Greenspan's Fast Action Reassured the Skeptics
abstract: LEAD: When Alan Greenspan was sworn in as Federal Reserve chairman in August, few doubted his powers as an economic analyst, but whether this lifelong adviser could adequately set policy as head of the nation's central bank remained to be seen.

headline: Patents; Method for Performing Laser Eye Surgery
abstract: LEAD: A New York eye surgeon, Dr. Francis A. L'Esperance Jr., was awarded a patent this week for his method of performing ophthalmic laser surgery. Patent 4,732,148 is related to one he was granted on March 8 for the apparatus that is used.

headline: Brief Period of Stability Seen for Interest Rates
abstract: LEAD: Continuing a consolidation phase after the sharp declines registered in January, interest rates are likely to move in a relatively narrow range for the next week or so, credit market analysts said. But they added that a further drop in yields seemed quite probable before the quarter ends.

headline: Waldheim Assails Racial Hatred
abstract: LEAD: President Kurt Waldheim, who has been accused of involvement in wartime atrocities, today denounced the period of Nazi rule in Austria and urged his countrymen to avoid racial hatred and intolerance.

headline: Grey Said to Be Agency For Olympic Coins
abstract: LEAD: The word around the street is that Grey Advertising, which knows a thing or two about the marketing of gold and silver, has been selected by the Treasury to promote its Olympic Coins, which will be available in both precious metals. Reports also have it that the billings will be $20 million.

headline: Judge Bars Shifting of Air Shuttle
abstract: LEAD: A Federal judge yesterday ordered Eastern Air Lines Inc. to abandon its plans to sell or transfer its shuttle to its parent, the Texas Air Corporation.

headline: Colombia Denies Vow To U.S. on Drug Figure
abstract: LEAD: Colombia said today it had never promised the United States it would hold Jorge Luis Ochoa, a reputed major figure in the drug traffic, in jail, and called the attitude of the United States Government offensive.

headline: 2d Grolier Rebuff
abstract: LEAD: Grolier Inc. has again rejected a $415 million bid by the French publisher Hachette S.A. as inadequate. Grolier, an encyclopedia and reference book company based in Danbury, last week rejected the $21-a-share offer made earlier this month. Amory Hall, a Hatchette spokesman, called his company's offer fair.

headline: Snuff Merger Hits Snag
abstract: LEAD: The Federal Trade Commission said today that it would ask a court to bar the American Maize-Products Company temporarily from going ahead with its planned $36.5 million acquisition of the dry snuff assets of the United States Tobacco Company. The F.T.C. said the merger ''could substantially reduce competition.

headline: Construction Spending Declines
abstract: LEAD: Construction spending fell 2.9 percent in January, the biggest decline in 10 months, reflecting widespread weakness in all sectors of the building industry, the Commerce Department reported today.

headline: Swami Falls From Grace In New Delhi
abstract: LEAD: At the height of his influence, the tall, bearded swami was regarded as one of the most powerful men in India and was an adviser to Indira Gandhi, then Prime Minister, and her son Sanjay.

headline: Sale by Occidental
abstract: LEAD: The Occidental Petroleum Corporation will sell a stake in its Colombian interests to Repsol, Spain's national oil company, for $272 million. The proposed transaction includes an interest in the Cano Limon and the Redondo fields, which currently produce 215,000 barrels of oil a day. Occidental, based in Los Angeles, said it would continue to operate the properties.

headline: The Rally That Was: Gone, Almost Forgotten
abstract: LEAD: Only a year ago, the stock market was cheering the longest string of day-to-day gains on record. The Dow Jones industrial average rose 13 consecutive days before falling back on Jan. 21. Indeed, from the year's opening session on Jan. 2 through the early spring the Dow stocks were bid higher and higher.

headline: Advertising; Liberty Travel to Start TV Effort on Sunday
abstract: LEAD: Liberty Travel, a major independent travel agency that is the largest newspaper advertiser in the travel-service business, will start a big television effort in the New York market on Sunday.

headline: I.B.M. PS/2 Shipments
abstract: LEAD: Shipments of the International Business Machines Corporation's new line of personal computers, introduced last April, reached 1.5 million units by the end of January, the company's senior vice president, George Conrades, said today.

headline: 10 SENATORS URGE $48 MILLION IN AID FOR THE CONTRAS
abstract: LEAD: A bipartisan group of senators introduced a $48 million package of aid for the Nicaraguan rebels today that would also permit delivery of as much as $2.5 million worth of previously authorized arms and ammunition.

headline: Panamanian Chief Dismisses Aide Seeking Political Deal
abstract: LEAD: Panama's military leader has dismissed a close adviser who had been trying to arrange a transition to true civilian rule, senior Latin American diplomats said tonight.

headline: Reader's Digest to Acquire Magazine
abstract: LEAD: For 60 years, the Reader's Digest Company's sole magazine was the highly successful Reader's Digest. Now George V. Grune, the company's chairman since 1984, is seeking to expand the company's publishing empire.

headline: The Guerrilla Fight in Mozambique Also Takes a Toll on Zimbabwe
abstract: LEAD: As the crippling war in Mozambique spills over into Zimbabwe, the Government of Executive President Robert G. Mugabe is increasingly faced with competing pressures over this country's military involvement in the conflict.

headline: First Issue of Sassy Due Out Next Week
abstract: LEAD: The premier issue of Sassy, a magazine for teen-age girls, is scheduled to hit newsstands on Tuesday. An issue will cost $2, with a yearly subscription $13.98.

headline: Award in Channel Disaster
abstract: LEAD: Britain's High Court awarded more than $295,000 in compensation to a family whose father died when a English Channel ferry, the Herald of Free Enterprise, sank off Belgium in March, killing nearly 200 people.

headline: Campeau Threatens Suit in Takeover Bid
abstract: LEAD: Putting additional pressure on Federated Department Stores to surrender to its takeover offer, the Campeau Corporation yesterday warned Kohlberg Kravis Roberts & Company, the No. 1 firm in leveraged buyouts, that it would sue if the firm entered into arrangements with Federated calling for ''breakup'' fees or ''lock-ups'' as part of a leveraged buyout.

headline: Still Struggling
abstract: LEAD: To the Editor:

headline: New Alliances Seen in Computers; Ashton in Project With Microsoft
abstract: LEAD: The Ashton-Tate Corporation and the Microsoft Corporation, two leading producers of personal computer software, said yesterday that they plan to jointly offer a new software product that manages data bases on computer networks.

headline: U.S. Said to Set Korea Deadline
abstract: LEAD: The United States has given South Korea three weeks to open its markets to more than 100 American agricultural products, according to a Korean news report.

headline: Kodak-Fuqua Deal Blocked
abstract: LEAD: A Federal judge has issued a temporary injunction blocking the Eastman Kodak Company's deal to merge its photofinishing operations with those of Fuqua Industries of Atlanta. United States District Judge

headline: Patents; An Improved Method For TV Physical Exams
abstract: LEAD: Scientists at the Medical Center of Georgetown University in Washington were awarded a patent this week for an improved method of physical examination by means of television. The method involves scanning microscope images of tissues.

headline: Real Runaway
abstract: LEAD: To the Editor:

headline: Blast Disables P.L.O.'s 'Exodus' Ferry in Port
abstract: LEAD: An explosion today crippled a ferry that was expected to carry Palestinian deportees on a symbolic voyage to Israel, port officials and the Palestine Liberation Organization said.

headline: Face to Face for Sandinistas and Rebels
abstract: LEAD: Officials of the Nicaraguan Government and anti-Sandinista guerrillas met for their first face-to-face negotiations here this afternoon and agreed to hold further talks Friday morning.

headline: PROSPECTS
abstract: LEAD:  What's Next for G.M.?

headline: Marxist IdeaL Loses Allure For Sao Tome
abstract: LEAD: In this West African city where Edwardian-era lanterns illuminate sandy streets and ceiling fans gather dust at the airport, language is a good indicator of change.

headline: Pakistan's Afghan Moves Perplex U.S.
abstract: LEAD: The Reagan Administration appears to have been thrown off balance by Pakistan's recent statements that members of the pro-Moscow Government in Afghanistan should be retained as part of a government that would take office as a condition of a Soviet troop withdrawal.

headline: Eastern Air to Cut 600 From Its Staff
abstract: LEAD: Eastern Airlines said it was eliminating 600 jobs, most of which will affect airport workers, like skycaps, represented by the machinists' union. Eastern's management has been putting pressure on Charles E. Bryan, the leader of the International Brotherhood of Machinists and Aerospace Workers, to accept wage and benefit cuts in a new contract.

headline: Contra Aid: Ups and Downs in Congress
abstract: LEAD: The House rejection of a contra aid plan yesterday continued a fluctuating pattern of Congressional support for such assistance. The fiscal-year figures below do not include money from other sources - for example, from a contingency fund, from third countries, or from the Iran-contra arms sales.

headline: Apartheid Takes a New Year Break
abstract: LEAD: Tyson Kobus sat under an oak tree here the other day and vented his disgust. Mr. Kobus is black and works as a $65-a-week driver for a local engineering company. But what troubled him as he relaxed on a garden chair was nothing to do with apartheid.

headline: Stocks Mixed; Dow Drops 7.80, to 2,063.49
abstract: LEAD: Stock prices closed mixed yesterday, as takeover activity continued to be the dominant theme on Wall Street.

headline: Higher Sales Buoy Atari's Results
abstract: LEAD: The Atari Corporation today reported operating gains for the fourth quarter and all of 1987 as sales increased. The computer maker was hampered, however, by a write-down related to Atari's October acquisition of the Federated Group, a troubled electronics retailer.

headline: Tax Cuts in Hong Kong
abstract: LEAD: Hong Kong's Financial Secretary, Piers Jacobs, cut taxes on corporate profits and personal income in the 1988-89 budget released today. Corporate taxes fell to 17 percent from 18 percent in the British colony, and the personal income tax base rate was reduced by one percentage point, to 15.5 percent.

headline: Chinese Plan For Investment
abstract: LEAD: China plans to set up five companies to supervise investment in such areas of the economy as energy and transportation, the Deputy Prime Minister Yao Yilin said today.

headline: Clause in Texaco Pact Is Questioned
abstract: LEAD: Lawyers for shareholders of Texaco Inc. yesterday questioned a key figure in the company's settlement with the Pennzoil Company on why the plan to bring Texaco out of bankruptcy protects the company's officers from lawsuits charging mismanagement.

headline: 13.09 Drop Sends Dow To 1,910.48
abstract: LEAD: Stock prices remained listless most of yesterday before late selling pushed the the Dow Jones industrial average down 13.09 points to close at 1,910.48. Over all, the market ended mixed.

headline: E-II to Talk With Brands
abstract: LEAD: Donald P. Kelly, chairman of E-II Holdings Inc., a Chicago-based offshoot of the Beatrice Companies, will meet today with William J. Alley, chairman of American Brands Inc., to discuss ideas to improve American Brands' stock price, both companies said yesterday.

headline: The Afghan Future: With Soviet Pullout Offer, the Talks Build Momentum
abstract: LEAD: The Soviet Union's proposal for a 10-month withdrawal of its 115,000 troops from Afghanistan has plunged the United States, Pakistan and the Afghan guerrillas into intensive negotiations with one another over the wisdom of demanding that a coalition government be established in Kabul before an agreement is signed.

headline: When Women's Work Is Done
abstract: LEAD: A DECADE ago, outplacement firms saw relatively few women. But as more women reach senior management posts, where outplacement counseling is a company-paid benefit, that is changing.

headline: U.S. Asserts Soviet Shifts Nuclear Subs to Europe
abstract: LEAD: The Soviet Union has recently stopped sending Yankee nuclear missile submarines to patrol off the Atlantic coast of the United States, diverting them to European waters instead, according to the United States Director of Naval Intelligence.

headline: AGS to Acquire C3
abstract: LEAD: AGS Computers Inc. said it had agreed in principle to acquire C3 Inc., a computer systems integration company based in Herndon, Va., for $15.75 a share, or about $157.5 million. C3 designs, assembles and maintains computer systems to solve the automation needs of the Federal Government. AGS, based in Mountainside, N.J., is involved in computer automation of telecommunication and computer systems.

headline: Hong Kong: A City Bent on Erasing Its Past
abstract: LEAD: The only synagogue in Hong Kong - a turn-of-the-century Sephardic building with creamy white walls, marble pillars and graceful buttresses - is facing demolition as developers prepare to build two high-rise apartment towers.

headline: Correction
abstract: LEAD: The Week in Business column last week misidentified the company from which Steve S. Chen recently resigned. It was Cray Research Inc.

headline: Federated, Campeau Near Deal
abstract: LEAD: Federated Department Stores Inc. and the Campeau Corporation yesterday moved close to a $6.3 billion merger that would be the biggest ever in American retailing.

headline: Zero-Coupon Bonds and the 'Kiddie' Tax
abstract: LEAD: Below are answers to some recent questions from readers of the Personal Finance column.

headline: Excerpt From Summary Of Brady Stock Report
abstract: LEAD: Following is an excerpt from a summary prepared by the President's Task Force on Market Mechanisms of its report on the October stock market collapse, as released today by the White House:  THE MARKET BREAK

headline: BUSINESS DIGEST: MONDAY, JANUARY 25, 1988
abstract: LEAD: INTERNATIONAL REPORT  Unemployment in Western Europe is expected to get worse as a result of the dollar's drop, which has made American goods more competitive with European products. The situation is already grim, with Europe's jobless rate at 11 percent. No net new jobs have been created in Europe since 1980.

headline: Nkomo Sees Beginning of Zimbabwean Unity
abstract: LEAD: Joshua Nkomo, the patriarch of Zimbabwean black nationalism, stood before an attentive crowd at a political rally and said he had a story to tell.

headline: Infighting Is on Rise At Troubled Firms After Stock Plunge
