abstract: LEAD:         *3*** COMPANY REPORTS **    *3*HAWKEYE BANCORPORATION (OTC)       Year to Dec 31   1987   1986                     Net inc   b14,305,000   c58,969,000              Per share   1.33   -              b-Includes a gain of $7,446,000 from the extinguishment of debt.   c-Net loss  Results for 1986 are restated to reflect a reconsolidation of five bank units designated for sale but not sold.

headline: Hughes Aircraft To Buy Satellites
abstract: LEAD: The Hughes Aircraft Company said it had agreed to buy the satellite system of the Western Union Corporation. Terms were not disclosed. Hughes, the Los Angeles-based subsidiary of the General Motors Corporation, said that it would operate the three orbiting satellites in Western Union's Westar VI-S system and that it intended to replace one with a newer model.

headline: Car Plant Shift Seen in Japan
abstract: LEAD: Japanese auto makers will probably increase their annual production capacity at their United States and Canadian plants to 2.2 million vehicles by early 1990, from 300,000 in 1985, the Confederation of Japan Automobile Workers Unions said today.

headline: Gulf War Premiums Cut
abstract: LEAD: War risk insurance premiums have been cut, effective Thursday, for cargoes on ships sailing to and from many Persian Gulf ports, the War Risk Rating Committee said today. The decision stemmed from what the committee said was a slightly less volatile situation in the Persian Gulf and a decline in attacks on shipping.

headline: Grand Jury Questions Regan
abstract: LEAD: Donald T. Regan, the former White House chief of staff, and Assistant Attorney General William Bradford Reynolds were questioned today by the Federal grand jury investigating the Iran-contra affair.

headline: Lawmakers Met Israel Envoy on Shooting of Arabs
abstract: LEAD: A dozen members of the House of Representatives met privately last week with the Israeli Ambassador to the United States to express their concern over the beatings and shootings by Israeli soldiers of Palestinians in the occupied West Bank and Gaza Strip.

headline: Allegheny Needs $75 Million to Run
abstract: LEAD: Allegheny International Inc., the consumer-products company hit by financial losses and a scandal over benefits paid to former executives, said it needed another $75 million to operate through April. The company said the $75 million reflected the amount it would fall short after calculating the revenues expected to be generated during this period.

headline: Palestinian Demonstrations Continue
abstract: LEAD: Twenty or more Palestinian boys and young men - rocks and chunks of concrete in their hands, checkered kaffiyehs wrapped around their faces - clustered excitedly by their barricade of burning tires at the turnoff to this isolated village among the stony hills, waiting for cars with yellow Israeli license plates.

headline: 4.4% Growth in Britain
abstract: LEAD: Consumer spending helped Britain's gross domestic product grow by 4.4 percent last year, according to Government figures released today. Consumer spending grew by slightly more than 5 percent in 1987 compared with 6 percent in 1986, the figures showed. Officials said Britain's economy had not been so buoyant since gross domestic product grew 7.25 percent in 1973.

headline: Cooper Is Selling Lens Solution Unit
abstract: LEAD: The Cooper Companies, based in Palo Alto, Calif., said it had agreed to sell its United States contact lens care solutions business to Wesley-Jessen Inc., a subsidiary of the Schering-Plough Corporation, for about $63 million in cash. The transaction is subject to the completion of Cooper's previously announced agreement to sell its worldwide contact lens business to Wesley

headline: 2 Kohl-Gorbachev Meetings
abstract: LEAD: Chancellor Helmut Kohl will visit Moscow this autumn and Mikhail S. Gorbachev will travel to Bonn in the first half of next year, West Germany and the Soviet Union said today, confirming a thaw in relations.

headline: After Kidnappings, U.N. Curtails Its Operations in Lebanon
abstract: LEAD: Some United Nations operations in southern Lebanon have been curtailed sharply since the kidnapping of a United States Marine officer and other United Nations personnel this month.

headline: CONSUMER PRICE INDEX
abstract: LEAD:            Index   Pct.   Pct.       for   chng. from   chng. from       Feb. '88   Jan. '88   Feb. '87       Revised              ALL ITEMS        U.S.   116.0   0.2*   3.9        N.Y.   121.1    -0.2    5.0               FOOD AND BEVERAGE        U.S.   115.3*   -0.2*   2.9        N.Y.   122.7    0.2    5.3               HOUSING        U.S.   116.8*   0.3*   3.7        N.Y.

headline: BUSINESS DIGEST: FRIDAY, MARCH 25, 1988
abstract: LEAD:  Markets

headline: Noriega Foils Coup Attempt; Civilians Take to the Streets
abstract: LEAD: An attempt to overthrow Gen. Manuel Antonio Noriega failed here today, but it was followed by widespread civil disorders across Panama.

headline: Latins Fighting U.S. Bid for Veto Power at Bank
abstract: LEAD: Eight Latin American countries are threatening to block the appointment of a new president of an international lending agency unless the United States backs off from a demand for virtual veto power over new loans.

headline: 108 Killed as Turboprop Plane Crashes in China
abstract: LEAD: A domestic airliner crashed in southwestern China, killing all 108 people aboard, the official New China News Agency reported today.

headline: I.M.F. Studying Plan To Ease Debt Burden
abstract: LEAD: The International Monetary Fund would play a major role in facilitating debt relief for third-world countries under a plan put forward by Arjun Sengupta of India, one of the fund's 22 executive directors.

headline: Foreign Edge in Takeovers
abstract: LEAD: Companies in Britain, West Germany and Japan have an advantage in acquiring American companies because of how laws regarding good will payments are handled by their countries, a Congressional report says.

headline: Sea-Land Ships
abstract: LEAD: The Sea-Land Corporation, a subsidiary of the CSX Corporation, said it had agreed to buy 12 container ships from Econ Associates Limited Partnership for $13 million to $14 million each. Sea-Land said that it would operate the ships for Atlantic trade. The ships originally cost about $47.5 million each when they were built three years ago.

headline: Hanoi Seeks Talks With Beijing
abstract: LEAD: After a flare-up of hostilities this week in the South China Sea, Vietnam appealed to China today to negotiate an end to naval attacks around a contested offshore island chain ''and all other matters of border disputes.''

headline: Chrysler Seeks Growth in China
abstract: LEAD: The Chrysler Corporation hopes to add passenger cars to the line of Jeeps that it produces in China, a top official of the auto maker said. Gerald Greenwald, head of the Chrysler Motors division of the Chrysler Corporation, said his company had been negotiating with First Automotive Works of Changchun, in northeast

headline: U.S. Says It Will Stay Firm in Arms Talks With Soviet
abstract: LEAD: The United States will stick to key elements of its position on reducing long-range nuclear arms when American and Soviet negotiators begin a new round of talks in Geneva on Thursday, Administration officials said today.

headline: 3 Senators Wary of Bank Mergers
abstract: LEAD: Members of Congress cautioned the Federal Reserve Board today about the possible ill effects of permitting hostile takeovers among the nation's largest banks.

headline: Advertising; Addenda
abstract: LEAD: * D'Arcy Masius Benton & Bowles has agreed to acquire a majority interest in Imparc, Dusseldorf, West Germany, from BBDO Worldwide, a unit of the Omnicom Group.

headline: Soviet Reports Riot at Embassy in Iran
abstract: LEAD: Iranian rioters attacked the Soviet Embassy in Teheran today, flinging rocks and firebombs and trying to break into the compound, the official Tass press agency reported tonight.

headline: Advertising; Marketers Prepare for Cup Races
abstract: LEAD: Dennis Conner and his crew are not the only ones scrambling to get ready for the America's Cup races to be held off Long Beach, Calif., in September, three years earlier than the defenders had planned.

headline: Oil Rig Count Declines
abstract: LEAD: The number of oil and gas drilling rigs working in the United States fell by 24 last week, to 1,121, Baker Hughes said today. A year ago the total was 962.

headline: U.S. Vetoes U.N. Resolution Urging Restraint by Israelis
abstract: LEAD: The United States today vetoed a Security Council resolution that appealed to Israel to exercise restraint in the occupied territories and called for the Middle East situation to be resolved under United Nations auspices.

headline: Investor Demand Is Strong For Triple-A Georgia Bonds
abstract: LEAD: The State of Georgia, one of few states that still has a rating of triple-A, priced $277.6 million of general obligation bonds in competitive bidding yesterday. Because there have been only a few issues of significant size with high-quality ratings priced this year, investor demand is strong.

headline: Precious Metals and Oil Rise During New York Trading
abstract: LEAD: Precious metals and crude oil futures prices advanced yesterday in New York after meandering in narrow ranges earlier on the Asian and European markets.

headline: What to Do With $3 Billion
abstract: LEAD: J. Hugh Liedtke, the chairman of the Pennzoil Company, now faces a task others envy -spending the spoils of a settlement unprecedented in size.

headline: U.S. TO SEND FORCE TO AID HONDURAS, CITING 'INCURSION'
abstract: LEAD: President Reagan tonight ordered the deployment of four battalions of American troops, about 3,200 men, to Honduras as a sign of support for the Government there.

headline: India Confronts Horrors Of the Past in TV Series
abstract: LEAD: Forty years after the upheaval of India's birth and partition with Pakistan, an extraordinary television series is confronting millions of Indians anew with questions of blame for past and present violence.

headline: 2 Azerbaijani Officials Dismissed Over Rioting
abstract: LEAD: The Communist Party chief of the Azerbaijani city of Sumgait, where at least 32 people were killed in attacks against Armenians last month, has been dismissed for ''major shortcomings'' in his work, officials said today.

headline: STATE DEPT. GIVEN A BUDGET REPRIEVE
abstract: LEAD: Congress has forestalled the State Department budget crisis for at least a year by quietly appropriating additional funding in the final days of its last session.

headline: A MEMO TO MEESE SAID TO ASK CASH FOR ISRAELI PARTY
abstract: LEAD: Attorney General Edwin Meese 3d was told in a 1985 memo from a close friend who wanted his help in arranging Government support for a billion-dollar Iraqi oil pipeline that the project would involve payments to the Israeli Labor Party, present and former United States Government officials said today.

headline: BankAmerica's Settlements
abstract: LEAD: The BankAmerica Corporation said today that it had reached settlements involving a number of lawsuits against its employees and others that will net the company about $28 million in payments from its insurance company, the Employers Insurance of Wausau Mutual Company.

headline: Norway's Statoil in Red
abstract: LEAD: Norway's state oil company, Statoil, today reported a record loss of $300 million for 1987, in contrast to 1986's profit of $180 million. The loss was caused by cost overruns in the expansion of the Mongstad refinery.

headline: Three Are Held In Hong Kong
abstract: LEAD: The former chairman of Hong Kong's stock exchange and two top aides were arrested today in connection with a investigation into suspected corruption. Ronald Li, the chairman, Jeffrey Sun, the former chief executive of the stock exchange, and Donald Tsang, the former head of the stock listing department, were arrested at their homes by the Independent Commission Against

headline: STRIKES CHALLENGE PORTUGAL'S LEADER
abstract: LEAD: A rash of strikes in Portugal since the beginning of the year represents the first serious test for the Government of Prime Minister Anibal Cavaco Silva and his promise of political stability.

headline: U.S. Delays Brazil Action
abstract: LEAD: The Reagan Administration said today that it was postponing the imposition of $105 million in retaliatory sanctions against exports from Brazil, citing a new Brazilian law that may ease barriers against sales of American computers.

headline: Matra Offering Oversubscribed
abstract: LEAD: The French Government's public offering of its 51 percent stake in Matra S.A., a military and electronics company, was oversubscribed almost fivefold, the Finance Ministry said today.

headline: Single-Premium Policies a Target
abstract: LEAD: ONE of the fastest-growing ''investment'' products available is single-premium whole life insurance. Its appeal comes primarily from the tax advantages it retained after the Tax Reform Act of 1986 took effect last Jan. 1.

headline: U.S. Officials Say Haiti Election Will Not Lead to Aid Resumption
abstract: LEAD: The election of Leslie F. Manigat as Haiti's President will not affect the cutoff of most United States aid to that country, Administration officials say.

headline: Pepsi Sets Off a Cola War in India
abstract: LEAD: More than a decade after Coca-Cola was kicked out of India in a burst of economic nationalism, a new cola war has erupted here over a proposal to let Pepsi-Cola compete with local soft-drink producers.

headline: Japan's U.S. Surplus at 2-Year Low
abstract: LEAD: Japan's trade surplus with the United States fell in January to $2.97 billion, the lowest level in two years, the Ministry of Finance reported today.

headline: Discussions Of Phone Bid Were Taped
abstract: LEAD: An employee of the General Services Administration made tape recordings of phone conversations in which an official of a regional Bell phone company told the employee that a G.S.A. official had leaked secret bid information about Government phone contracts.

headline: NICARAGUA ORDERS A 10% BUDGET CUT
abstract: LEAD: President Daniel Ortega Saavedra announced new austerity measures today to accompany the jarring currency devaluation he decreed a week ago.

headline: Ruling Due on Bhopal Plea
abstract: LEAD: A judge said Friday that he would rule March 7 on the Union Carbide Corporation's appeal of a court order that it pay $270 million in interim relief to victims of the Bhopal gas leak.

headline: TANDEM PLUNGES ON SALES NEWS
abstract: LEAD: Tandem Computer Inc.'s shares lost a quarter of their value yesterday after the company, which makes business computer systems, said revenues for the quarter just ended would not meet its expectations.

headline: BUSINESS DIGEST: MONDAY, MARCH 14, 1988
abstract: LEAD: COMPANIES  A rescue plan for First City Bancorporation of Texas is in jeopardy because creditors have balked at its provisions. Federal agencies are weighing alternative moves. [ Page D1. ] Hachette of France offered $415 million for Grolier, a major American educational publisher.

headline: TRW Agrees to Buy Borg-Warner's Chilton
abstract: LEAD: In a further move into the information-systems business, TRW Inc. said today that it had agreed to buy the Chilton Corporation, a unit of the Borg-Warner Corporation, for about $360 million.

headline: Insider Curb in British Bill
abstract: LEAD: Britain said this week that it intends to make insider trading on financial markets an extraditable offense.

headline: Patents; Vocal Sounds Improved In Voice Messaging
abstract: LEAD: In voice messaging systems, the voice is coded for transmission or storage and can be decoded later. An improved system, patented this week for Texas Instruments Inc. in Dallas, is directed at avoiding reproduction of vocal sounds with erroneous, squeaky, cracking, coarse or grating qualities. Sounds that seem to be whispered rather than spoken are also avoided.

headline: Addendum
abstract: LEAD: * Livingston & Co., Seattle, will open a San Francisco office on March. 1.

headline: Canadians Acquire Stake in U.S. Trust
abstract: LEAD: The Central Capital Corporastion, a Canadian financial services concern based in Toronto, bought a 7.8 percent stake in the U.S. Trust Corporation of New York for $31.3 million.

headline: Lebanon's President Invites West to Rescue Its Hostages
abstract: LEAD: President Amin Gemayel has said Western powers are welcome to come and rescue any of their citizens held hostage in Lebanon.

headline: Bilzerian Looks At SSMC Sale
abstract: LEAD: The Florida corporate raider Paul A. Bilzerian, who took over the Singer Company earlier this year, said today that he might seek a buyer for SSMC Inc., the sewing machine company spun off from Singer two years ago.

headline: LEADING INDICATORS: COMPONENT ANALYSIS
abstract: LEAD:  Components of the index of leading economic indicators and their net weighted contribution to the index's change in January.           Contrib.       To Index        Dec. to Jan.              Average workweek of        production workers in        manufacturing   +0.10               Average weekly claims for        State unemployment        insurance*   -0.43

headline: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
abstract: LEAD: * British Petroleum Co. said that Lord Barber would retirefrom its board on March 31 and that James H. Ross would be appointed president and chief executive of its BP America subsidiary in Cleveland.

headline: BUSINESS DIGEST: WEDNESDAY, MARCH 2, 1988
abstract: LEAD: THE ECONOMY  The Government's main forecasting index was revised upward for December, avoiding the three consecutive monthly declines that are viewed as a signal of an imminent recession. The index fell 0.6 percent in January, slightly more than most analysts had expected. But private forecasters said they still expected the economy to expand, though sluggishly, in the next few months.

headline: BUSINESS PEOPLE; Chairman of Dyncorp Heads Buyout Group
abstract: LEAD: Jorge E. Carnicero, who co-founded the Dynalectron Corporation in 1946 and remains its chairman, is now leading an investment group seeking to purchase the company, which was recently renamed Dyncorp. The group has offered a package of cash and securities worth about $246 million, or $23.25 a share.

headline: LITTLE GAIN SEEN AS SHULTZ VISITS JORDAN AND SYRIA
abstract: LEAD: Secretary of State George P. Shultz flew to Jordan and Syria today to discuss a package of American proposals for a Middle East negotiating formula but made little apparent headway in his quest.

headline: The Latest for Asthmatics: OROS Push Pull Osmotic System
abstract: LEAD: Later this year, the Food and Drug Administration is expected to approve a prescription asthma drug developed by Glaxo Inc. that uses time-release technology invented by the Alza Corporation. Although the technology has been available for most of this decade, the time required for regulatory approval has delayed its use with prescription drugs in this country.

headline: America Is Running Out of Time
abstract: LEAD: AMERICA can't compete.

headline: Mubarak, in U.S., Seeks Peace Efforts
abstract: LEAD: President Hosni Mubarak of Egypt was reported today to have appealed to Secretary of State George P. Shultz to step up American peace efforts in the Middle East during this time of clashes between Palestinian Arabs and Israeli troops.

headline: NORIEGA REBUFFS U.S. ON AN OFFER TO LEAVE PANAMA
abstract: LEAD: Rebuffing the Reagan Administration, Panama's military leader, Gen. Manuel Antonio Noriega, has rejected an American offer to let him leave the country without facing extradition to the United States on drug charges, senior Administration officials said today.

headline: Lilly Oraflex Fund Urged
abstract: LEAD: Some 100 members of Britain's Parliament took the unusual step today of asking Eli Lilly & Company, the United States drug concern, to create a trust fund to pay British claims for injuries tied to Oraflex, the company's arthritis treatment.

headline: Article 695088 -- No Title
abstract: LEAD: American Standard Inc. is expected to announce today that it has agreed to sell the company for an estimated $2.6 billion, or about $79 a share, people close to the deal said last night.

headline: E-II Seeking Key Role At American Brands
abstract: LEAD: E-II Holdings Inc., a publicly traded spinoff of the Beatrice Company, said today that it plans to nominate six candidates for election to the board of American Brands Inc., the diversified giant whose businesses includes tobacco and numerous consumer products.

headline: 800 Attend Mass for Nicaraguan
abstract: LEAD: More than 800 people gathered last night in St. Patrick's Cathedral for a memorial Mass for Nora Astorga, Nicaragua's chief delegate to the United Nations, who died of cancer last week at the age of 39.

headline: Advertising; Hearst Gives Its Magazine Deals a Push
abstract: LEAD: TEN years ago Hearst Magazines, which then had eight magazines, began offering a ''corporate buy'' that gave advertisers discounts for running ads in at least three of the magazines at least three times each.

headline: Nokia Oy Buys Stake in Ericsson
abstract: LEAD: The Finnish high-technology company Nokia Oy said it had bought a controlling interest in the data systems division of the Swedish telecommunications giant L. M. Ericsson. The sale, in which Nokia acquired an 80 percent share of the Ericsson division, makes Nokia the largest computer company in Scandinavia and the second-biggest

headline: KEY RATES
abstract: LEAD:               Previous   Year     In percent   Yesterday   Day   Ago              PRIME RATE   8.50   8.50   7.50        DISCOUNT RATE   6.00   6.00   5.50        FEDERAL FUNDS   6.55   6.66   6.01        3-MO. TREAS. BILLS   5.84   5.62   5.50        6-MO. TREAS. BILLS   6.15   5.88   5.52        7-YR. TREAS. NOTES   7.88   7.92   6.92        30-YR.

headline: Shultz to Discuss Arms In Shevardnadze Talks
abstract: LEAD: Secretary of State George P. Shultz will meet with Foreign Minister Eduard A. Shevardnadze of the Soviet Union later this month in an effort to narrow differences on the issue of reducing long-range arms in preparation for another summit meeting in May or June, Administration officials said today.

headline: BUSINESS DIGEST: WEDNESDAY, FEBRUARY 17, 1988
abstract: LEAD:  Companies

headline: MacGregor Unit Bid Is Canceled
abstract: LEAD: MacGregor Sporting Goods Inc. said it had been notified that Oppenheimer-Palmieri Fund L.P. would not complete the acquisiiton of the assets of MacGregor's Riddell Inc. football equipment unit and the capital stock of its Equilink Licensing Corporation, a licensor of the MacGregor trademark. The fund said it had been unable to obtain satisfactory financing for the transaction, which was to have been completed by Jan.

headline: Greece Won't Extradite Italian
abstract: LEAD: The Greek Gov ernment today overruled a Supreme Court decision to extradite to Italy a member of the Red Brigades who was sought by the Italian authorities for terrorist attacks.

headline: Yields Move A Bit Lower
abstract: LEAD: Yields on certificates of deposit, bank money market accounts and money market mutual funds were mostly lower for the week ended yesterday, continuing a downward pattern in recent weeks.

headline: SOVIET SETS MAY 15 AS GOAL TO START AFGHANISTAN EXIT
abstract: LEAD: Mikhail S. Gorbachev announced today that the Soviet Union would begin withdrawing its troops from Afghanistan on May 15 if the Geneva talks on the war there result in a settlement two months before that date.

headline: U.S. ASKING BANKS NOT TO SEND FUNDS TO NORIEGA REGIME
abstract: LEAD: The State Department has prepared a document advising a group of New York banks not to disburse any Panamanian Government funds to Gen. Manuel Antonio Noriega because he is not the lawful head of the country, department officials said today.

headline: Decline on Amex Paced By Battered Oil Stocks
abstract: LEAD: Although the October stock market collapse took its toll on virtually every stock on the American Stock Exchange, those that held onto most of their gains had very little in common. The winners for the year ranged from a bedcovering importer to a cable television system, while losers ran the gamut from a poultry processor to a jewelry maker.

headline: FINANCE BRIEFS
abstract: LEAD: * Armstrong World Industries has filed with the Securities and Exchange Commission for up to $250 million of debt securities.

headline: Tourism Up in O.E.C.D.
abstract: LEAD: Tourism flourished in major industrial countries last year, tentatively topping the record set in 1985, the Organization for Economic Cooperation and Development said today. Real tourist trade earnings (allowing for inflation and exchange rate fluctuations) climbed 6 percent in the 24-nation O.E.C.D., compared with the 1986 rise of three-tenths of 1 percent.

headline: Reagan Considering Measures to Weaken Panamanian Leader
abstract: LEAD: President Reagan and his senior advisers today considered a range of sanctions for the United States to impose to worsen a crippling cash flow crisis for the Government of Gen. Manuel Antonio Noriega in Panama.

headline: Advertising; Merger Goes Smoothly for Saatchi Unit
abstract: LEAD: THE much-talked-about merger by Britain's Saatchi & Saatchi of its Ted Bates Worldwide and Backer & Spielvogel, forming Backer Spielvogel Bates, was completed Oct. 1. Now, three months later, G. Robert Holmen, who is chairman and chief executive domestically, is on the verge of calling the merger a success.

headline: Merrill Research Chief To Head Equity Unit
abstract: LEAD: In the latest example of how securities firms are responding to the tougher environment on Wall Street, Merrill Lynch & Company yesterday announced a reorganization of its huge capital-markets operation.

headline: Metromedia Is Buying Chain of Steakhouses
abstract: LEAD: In a foray into a business far removed from its history, the former media giant, the Metromedia Company, said yesterday that it had agreed to buy the company that owns the Ponderosa restaurants.

headline: 2 Die in Bangladesh Quake
abstract: LEAD: At least two people were killed and more than 100 injured Saturday night when a moderate earthquake shook Bangladesh and eastern India. The Government newspaper Dainik Bangla reported today that the deaths and most of the injuries occurred in the northeastern city of Sylhet. Walls of houses caved in around Slyhet, cracks opened up in a hospital building containing 500 beds and people ran into the streets in panic, the newspaper said.

headline: Soviet Called Ready to Back Iran Embargo
abstract: LEAD: A Soviet official said today that Moscow is ready to support a United Nations Security Council resolution that would impose an arms embargo on Iran for failing to accept a cease-fire in its war with Iraq.

headline: Afghan Parley Is to Resume Next Month
abstract: LEAD: The next round of United Nations-sponsored peace talks on Afghanistan will open in Geneva in February and appear likely to produce agreement on a timetable for the withdrawal of Soviet forces, according to United Nations officials and diplomats here.

headline: Salvador Rebels Kill 12 in Raid on City
abstract: LEAD: Salvadoran guerrillas killed a family of seven and five soldiers early today in a poorly executed attack aimed at the main army headquarters in this eastern city.

headline: Insurance Loans
abstract: LEAD: To the Editor:

headline: BRIEFS
abstract: LEAD: * Chrysler Corp. said it would consider resuming vehicle production in Europe if its new trans-Atlantic marketing drive leads to several years of rising sales. Chrysler expects to be selling cars and Jeeps in Europe at the rate of 25,000 a year by the end of 1988.

headline: Presidio Oil Makes Hostile Sabine Bid
abstract: LEAD: The Presidio Oil Company, an oil and gas concern based in Englewood, Colo., began a hostile tender offer of $20 a share, or $256 million, for the Sabine Corporation. Presidio also plans a proxy contest to gain control of the board of the Dallas oil and gas exploration and production concern, according to documents filed with the Securities and Exchange Commission.

headline: Bomb Kills 14 Near a Base in Namibia
abstract: LEAD: At least 14 people were killed and more than 30 wounded today when a bomb exploded in a bank branch office near a military base in South-West Africa, the territory also known as Namibia.

headline: Transcripts of New Year's Greetings From Reagan and Gorbachev on TV
abstract: LEAD: Following are transcripts of New Year's greetings, televised today, by President Reagan to the Soviet people and by Mikhail S. Gorbachev to the American people. The transcripts were supplied by the White House, with the translation from the Russian provided by an official interpreter.  MR. REAG

headline: COMPANY BRIEFS
abstract: LEAD: * Boeing Co., Seattle, said it had received a $60 million order for a Boeing 767-200 jet from Britannia Airways Ltd.

headline: Advertising; 2 New Bakery Accounts At Muller Jordan Weiss
abstract: LEAD: Stroehmann Bakeries of Horsham, Pa., has acquired two additional bakeries - Taystee in New York and Dreikorn's in Holyoke, Mass. - and it has assigned them to its agency, Muller Jordan Weiss. Stroehmann, a powerhouse brand in Philadelphia, has been spending about $3 million through the agency. The new business adds more than $1 million to the pot.

headline: Atlantic Air Traffic Gain
abstract: LEAD: More than 25.8 million passengers flew across the North Atlantic in 1987, a 21.7 percent rise from the previous year, the International Air Transport Association said today. David Kyd, a spokesman for the Geneva-based association, said that the number of North Atlantic passengers in 1986 totaled only 21.1 million as Americans stayed away from Europe because of the dollar's weakness, fear of terrorism and concern about the fallout from the Chernobyl accident.

headline: More Wheat to Soviet
abstract: LEAD: An additional 500,000 metric tons of subsidized United States wheat has been sold to the Soviet Union, the Agriculture Department said Wednesday. At recent prices averaging $2.82 a bushel, the wheat would have a value of $52 million. Nearly 5.7 million tons of subsidized wheat has been sold to the Soviet Union under the department's Export Enhancement Program for delivery in the fiscal year that began Oct.

headline: Advertising; Ex-Ogilvy Officer to B.J.K.&E.
abstract: LEAD: JAY SCHULBERG, who quit his job as the creative head of the New York office of Ogilvy & Mather to look for something different, has now become creative head of the New York office of Bozell, Jacobs, Kenyon & Eckhardt.

headline: TRW Lays Off 3,000 Workers
abstract: LEAD: TRW Inc. said today that it would furlough 3,000 workers, or about 10 percent of its space and military sector work force, in the next few months because of proposed cutbacks in military spending.

headline: No Irving Decision by Fed
abstract: LEAD: The Federal Reserve Board said today that, as scheduled, it had considered the hostile takeover bid by the Bank of New York Company for the Irving Bank Corporation but had reached no decision as to whether to permit the offer. Officials of the Fed said the central bank would continue consideration of the takeover proposal on

headline: Remy Martin Bid
abstract: LEAD: The French brandy distiller Remy Martin said it would bid for a 60 percent stake in the venerable liqueur maker Benedictine. Terms were not dis-closed, but based on its recent market price, Benedictine is valued at 854 million francs, or about $155 million.

headline: Sydney Journal; A Bad Lot, the Convict Fathers? Goodness, No!
abstract: LEAD: Aunt Laura is not to be told, but old Ellen, the other relatives acknowledge with an indulgent smile, was rather a bad hat.

headline: Trial of Hunt Brothers In Silver Case Begins
abstract: LEAD: A $150 million lawsuit against the Hunt brothers of Dallas went to trial yesterday in Manhattan, with a lawyer representing the leading Peruvian mineral company accusing the Hunts of engaging in an elaborate scheme in 1979 and 1980 to manipulate silver prices.

headline: About Real Estate; Converting All-Suite Hotels in Stamford
abstract: LEAD: As all-suite hotels continue to proliferate around the nation, some owners are taking advantage of their broader potential: transformation into residential condominiums should an oversupply develop or demand for transient accommodations slacken.

headline: Grolier's Response Expected Soon
abstract: LEAD: Andrew J. Reinhart, president and chief operating officer of Grolier Inc., said Friday that the company's board will make a recommendation to shareholders by the middle of this week on the offer by Hachette S.A. of France.

headline: Shevardnadze in Bonn; He Hails 'New Era'
abstract: LEAD: The Soviet Foreign Minister, Eduard A. Shevardnadze, arrived in Bonn today for a three-day visit, the first by a senior Soviet official under Mikhail S. Gorbachev.

headline: Brazil Agrees to Renew Meetings With I.M.F.
abstract: LEAD: Ending a three-year boycott of talks with the International Monetary Fund, Brazil expects to start negotiations on a new borrowing arrangement next month and to conclude an agreement by the end of June, Finance Minister Mailson Ferreira da Nobrega said here today.

headline: PAKISTANI LEADERS BACK COMPROMISE FOR AFGHAN PEACE
abstract: LEAD: Pakistan's two senior leaders have concluded that some members of the pro-Moscow Government in Afghanistan must be allowed to take part in a successor government as a condition for the withdrawal of Soviet troops.

headline: McKesson Sale Of Stationer
abstract: LEAD: The McKesson Corporation plans to divest itself of its unprofitable office products operation. McKesson said on Monday that it had agreed to combine the unit with the Stationers Distributing Company Inc. of Fort Worth, a wholly owned subsidiary of the privately held SDC Corporation, exchanging inventory and certain other assets in return for a 20 percent equity interest in the combined operation.

headline: Gerber to Shut Unit
abstract: LEAD: The Gerber Products Company of Fremont, Mich., said it would close its trucking subsidiary, CW Transport Inc. of Wisconsin Rapids, Wis., because its management had been unable to secure financing for a leveraged buyout and no other acceptable offer for the company had been received. Closing of the company and its operating subsidiaries will put 1,500 people out of work.

headline: First Republicbank in Bailout Talks
abstract: LEAD: Officers of the Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation met with executives of the First Republicbank Corporation today to prepare a temporary bailout intended to stanch a growing run on the bank company's deposits, officials close to the talks said.

headline: In Britain, Tax Overhaul and a Feud
abstract: LEAD: Britain's annual Budget Day, always a time of suspense in the House of Commons, arrived today with an extra fillip of drama because of a feud between Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher and her strong-willed Chancellor of the Exchequer, Nigel Lawson.

headline: STUDY TRACES AIDS IN AFRICA CHILDREN
abstract: LEAD: Nearly one in 15 Central African children receiving blood transfusions to combat malaria-related anemia may become infected with the AIDS virus as a result, a new study has found.

headline: Israel Cuts Phone Lines to Arabs; 4 More Are Slain
abstract: LEAD: Israel severed international telephone links to the occupied West Bank and Gaza Strip today in what the authorities described as a new effort to put pressure on the organization of the Palestinian uprising in the occupied territories.

headline: Groups Are Bracing to Help More Refugees on Slim Funds
abstract: LEAD: Private American aid organizations, bracing for a substantial increase in foreign refugees seeking new homes in the United States, are being advised by the State Department that they cannot expect more money to cover rising costs.

headline: Los Angeles Harbor Unit Issue
abstract: LEAD: The Los Angeles Harbor Depart-ment if offering $138.8 million of tax-exempt revenue bonds with a maxi-mum yield of 7.60 percent for an issue due in 2018 through underwriters led by Shearson Lehman Brothers.

headline: Advertising; People
abstract: LEAD: Ira Berkowitz has become president of Beaumont-Bennett, a sales promotion agency subsidiary of Grey Advertising.

headline: I.R.S. Action to Allow Spinoff of IC Rail Unit
abstract: LEAD: IC Industries plans to spin off the Illinois Central Gulf Railroad into a separate company after it receives a favorable tax ruling from the Internal Revenue Service, a company vice president, Bruce S. Chelberg, said this week.

headline: Advertising; New Fashion Magazine Fills Its Editor Post
abstract: LEAD: Gay Bryant, former editor of Family Circle, is now editor of Model, a fashion and beauty magazine for a younger crowd that will make its debut in June as a joint venture between Family Media and Times Mirror Magazines, with Family Media managing the show.

headline: Noriega's Opponents Set Up a Coalition
abstract: LEAD: Major opposition political parties and civic groups announced today that they were joining with the deposed President, Eric Arturo Delvalle, to form a ''government of national reconciliation'' in place of the regime dominated by Gen. Manuel Antonio Noriega.

headline: American Brands
abstract: LEAD: American Brands Inc. of Old Greenwich, Conn., said it had decided to dispose of three additional subsidiaries of its recently acquired E-II Holdings Inc.: the Culligan International Company, the Samsonite Corporation and most of the Samsonite Furniture Company. American Brands said it would retain the Vogel Peterson division of Samsonite Furniture.

headline: COMPANY BRIEFS
abstract: LEAD: * Alexander & Alexander Services Inc., an insurance brokerage, completed sales of its two major underwriting units, Sphere Drake Insurance Group P.L.C. and Shand Morahan & Co., to separate investor groups. Terms were not disclosed.

headline: A MERCHANT BANKER STARTS OWN FIRM
abstract: LEAD: It has been a long and winding road from the 1960's to the late 1980's for Ken Miller, a route that has taken him from social activism to the hottest money-making realm of Wall Street, merchant banking.

headline: Patents; A Method to Form A Blood Substitute
abstract: LEAD: A method of mixing chemicals to form a blood substitute was patented this week for the Air Force. Patent 4,730,936 was granted to Philip S. Thorjusen Jr., a medical laboratory technician at Keesler Air Force Base in Mississippi.

headline: 2 Israelis Are Killed in Ambush in South Lebanon
abstract: LEAD: Two Israelis were killed and several were wounded today in a guerrilla ambush in southern Lebanon, according to police officials here.

headline: Israeli Troops Kill 2 Arabs; Palestinian General Strike Protests Shultz Visit
abstract: LEAD: Two Palestinian demonstrators were shot and killed by Israeli soldiers in the occupied territories today and 100 were arrested.

headline: Ruder Sees Disagreement on Market Curbs
abstract: LEAD: The chairman of the Securities and Exchange Commission warned today that talks between the exchanges and regulators have yet to produce sufficient agreement on new measures -including coordinated trading halts, price limits and other ''circuit breakers'' - to prevent another collapse of the stock market.

headline: FINANCE/NEW ISSUES;
abstract: LEAD: The Indianapolis Airport Authority is tentatively offering $69 million of airport revenue bonds with a maximum yield of 8.494 percent for an issue due in 2018 through underwriters led by Merrill Lynch Capital Markets.

headline: Bond Prices Are Little Changed
abstract: LEAD: Note and bond prices were little changed yesterday and remained near their highest levels of the year.

headline: Brazil Pays Creditor Banks
abstract: LEAD: Brazil's creditor banks said yesterday that they had received a $360 million payment of overdue 1987 interest. With another interest payment on Dec. 31, the latest remittance brings to $1.46 billion the amount of 1987 interest that Brazil has paid so far.

headline: Desert Partners Extends USG Bid
abstract: LEAD: Desert Partners L.P. extended its $42-a-share tender offer for 21.5 million shares of the USG Corporation. The offer had been scheduled to expire at midnight today. A Desert Partners spokesman said that a nominal number of shares had been tendered through last Friday and that the offer is now scheduled to expire at 5 P.M., Eastern time, on

headline: Ruling on Texaco
abstract: LEAD: United States District Court Judge Charles L. Brieant is expected to rule early next week on whether Texaco Inc. may continue mailing its bankruptcy reorganization plan to shareholders. Judge Brieant heard arguments from shareholders opposed to the plan but has made no decision on their request to halt the mailing, which began on Wednesday.

headline: Advertising; Sherwood & Schneider
abstract: LEAD: After a three-way review, Curtain Country, a bed and bath retail chain of 33 stores in six states, has awarded its $2 million business to Sherwood & Schneider Advertising. The agency will focus on newspaper advertising, as well as the yearly production of 7.5 million circulars. Previous advertising was handled in-house.

headline: Boeing Updates 2 Jets In a Shift of Strategy
abstract: LEAD: The Boeing Company introduced new versions of its popular 737 and 747 jet airliners today that are expected to produce the bulk of its sales and earnings through the end of the century.

headline: BRIEFS
abstract: LEAD: * Allied-Signal Inc., Morristown, N.J., said it had repurchased 27.4 million shares last year for $1.1 billion.

headline: Hundreds of Marchers Clash With Police at Seoul Campus
abstract: LEAD: Hundreds of protesters demanding the release of political prisoners today threw rocks and firebombs at policemen, who responded by firing tear gas to disperse the crowd.

headline: HAITI GOVERNMENT PRAISES ELECTION
abstract: LEAD: The army-dominated Government defended Sunday's presidential election today as ''beautifully'' done, but several candidates charged widespread fraud and opposition leaders said irregularities and a lack of voter participation robbed the elections of credibility.

headline: Wynn Halts Sale
abstract: LEAD: Wynn's International Inc., an automotive products supplier, said that it was abandoning a two-month effort to find a buyer. The company had received an unsolicited $27.25-a-share, $109 million buyout proposal from a unit of the Security Pacific Corporation in September. That offer was dropped on Oct.

headline: U.S. Applauds (Softly) at Changes in Eastern Europe
abstract: LEAD: As Eastern Europe enters a period of political and economic fluidity, the United States faces a quandary. If it does nothing, it forfeits an opportunity. If it does too much, it risks fostering an instability that could deliver a severe setback to Soviet-American relations.

headline: 6 MURDERS LINKED IN BELFAST COURT
abstract: LEAD: A self-described paramilitary retribution gunman, his eyes blackened, his face puffy, was charged today with the murders of three mourners in a grenade attack here last Wednesday on an Irish Republican Army funeral.

headline: Patents; Stretchable Sheets
abstract: LEAD: Sidney M. Weiss of New York reports that hospitals and nursing homes are adding pads to mattresses to provide skin care. As a result conventional sheets do not fit. He was granted patent 4,723,331 this week for a stretchable knitted sheet that serves as a bedcover, accommodating the pads. The patent is assigned to Sleep-Knit International, of Greenwich, Conn., which manufactures the knitted sheets.

headline: Batus Takes Step To Support Offer
abstract: LEAD: To obtain support for its takeover offer, Batus Inc. has begun to solicit proxies from the shareholders of the Farmers Group Inc. to submit them at the company's annual meeting on May 20. Farmers, a Los Angeles-based insurance company, has spurned a $4.4 billion tender offer from Batus. The company has held discussions with other unspecified suitors and has outlined other possible defensive moves to remain independent.

headline: Advertising; New Yorker's New Publisher
abstract: LEAD: Steven T. Florio, the president of The New Yorker, announced yesterday that Rebecca Wesson Darwin, a long-time associate, had been promoted to publisher of the magazine, a title that he had previously held.

headline: The U.N. Today
abstract: LEAD:  General Assembly

headline: Kodak Pays the Price for Change
abstract: LEAD: In January, the Eastman Kodak Company announced a new product called Create-a-Print that would enable anyone with a color negative to walk into a photoprocessing lab, sit at a computer terminal and design a cropped or enlarged print. Amid the hoopla - and criticism - over Kodak's $5.1 billion acquisition of the Sterling Drug Company later that month, the new product went virtually unnoticed.

headline: The Hostage Scourge: How Europe Is Faring
abstract: LEAD: Chancellor Helmut Kohl recently referred to hostage-taking as ''the pest of modern times,'' and it is one few West European countries have escaped.

headline: Economy On Brink In Panama
abstract: LEAD: The festivities at the traditional pre-Lenten carnival here recently seemed more subdued than usual, and no one needed to ask why. ''There's not a cent for dancing in the streets or any other fun,'' one newspaper complained on its front page.

headline: Autonomy in Industry To Challenge Worker
abstract: LEAD: The Soviet Union today entered a critical phase in Mikhail S. Gorbachev's attempt to resuscitate the economy, in which workers will be asked to change their notion of work radically without yet having enjoyed any great rewards from two years of economic experiments and promises.

headline: Peugeot Alive and Going Global
abstract: LEAD: WHEN Jacques Calvet, chairman of the Peugeot automobile group, joined the company in 1982, it was in shambles. It lost $300 million that year, its market share in Europe was plummeting and many analysts said bankruptcy was just around the corner.

headline: A Broad Decentralization at I.B.M.
abstract: LEAD: In a sweeping restructuring intended to reverse three years of disappointing performance, the International Business Machines Corporation yesterday created five new, highly autonomous organizations that will be responsible for all of the company's innovation, design and manufacturing.

headline: EAST TIMOR SEEKS TO OPEN ITS DOORS
abstract: LEAD: The Governor of Indonesia's disputed province of East Timor plans to ask the Suharto Administration to lift restrictions on travel and communications that have isolated the territory since Indonesia invaded and annexed it in the 1970's.

headline: Dow Advances 18.74 in Late Rally
abstract: LEAD: A late rally that traders said was tied to stock index arbitrage pushed prices higher yesterday. The Dow Jones industrial average, after trading in a narrow range all day, closed at 1,914.46, up 18.74 points.

headline: An Avid and Successful Risk-Taker
abstract: LEAD: If John A. Mulheren Jr. had his way, he would now be a member of the United States Olympic luge team in Calgary, Alberta, where he hoped to become an instant celebrity. Not only had he developed a daring new technique in his training, but the fun-loving Mr. Mulheren even planned to speed down the Calgary run wearing a mask.

headline: Standard To Talk To Decker
abstract: LEAD: American Standard Inc. said today that it would negotiate with the Black & Decker Corporation, which has made a hostile $2.26 billion tender offer, and also with other potential buyers.

headline: Cambodians in Pol Pot's Camps Await a Liberator
abstract: LEAD: Of all the Cambodians whose future will be discussed in coming talks on a political compromise, perhaps none have so much to gain or lose as the tens of thousands of civilians still living under the control of Communists who run several refugee camps along the Thai-Cambodian border.

headline: MUBARAK TO TOUR GULF ARAB LANDS
abstract: LEAD: Amid reports of a deepening Egyptian military involvement in the Persian Gulf, President Hosni Mubarak is to embark this week on a tour of gulf Arab nations, sealing Cairo's emergence from ostracism because of its peace with Israel.

headline: New Income Tax Rules Mean Work and Confusion for Filers
abstract: LEAD: This year's tax filing season will be a historic, if confusing, time for American taxpayers as they grapple with the intricacies of the vastly revised Federal income tax system for the first time.

headline: Socialist's Victory on Gibraltar Favors Britain
abstract: LEAD: In elections with broad implications for relations between Spain and Britain, Gibraltar voters have chosen a Socialist government opposed to negotiations between the two countries over the status of the territory.

headline: CSX Corporation Joins Hawaii Plan
abstract: LEAD: Castle & Cooke Inc. said that the CSX Corporation had agreed to become a partner in a $200 million project to develop two hotels and 150 homes on the Hawaiian island of Lanai.

headline: Japan Chip Imports Slip
abstract: LEAD: Japanese imports of foreign microchips appear to have tapered off after reaching a peak in the second quarter of 1987, an official with the Ministry of International Trade and Industry said today. The United States has charged that Japan has failed to open its market to foreign semiconductor makers.

headline: Trading Plan for N.A.S.D.
abstract: LEAD: Still smarting from criticism that some of its market makers failed to cope with the crush of customer orders in the Oct. 19 stock trading rout, the National Association of Securities Dealers plans further improvements in executing transactions electronically.

headline: Banks' Plans On Mexico
abstract: LEAD: Leading United States banks are not expected to participate in Mexico's innovative debt-reduction plan, an American banker said today. But a senior official at the Swiss Bank Corporation said his bank will tender some loans.

headline: ACCOUNTS
abstract: LEAD: *  Camp socks, Chain Store Age Executive magazine and the Victrex line of ICI Advanced Materials to Baron & Zaretsky.

headline: Chrysler Financial To Offer Notes
abstract: LEAD: The Chrysler Financial Corporation, the financing subsidiary of the Chrysler Corporation, will offer $500 million in medium-term notes, probably this week, and plans additional debt issues in Europe soon.

headline: Prominent U.S. Jews, Visiting Israel, Voice Unease
abstract: LEAD: This is the time of year when, by recent tradition, the leaders of American Jewish organizations meet with the leaders of Israel to cement and renew a bond. This year, more than usual, the occasion is shot through with unease and worries framed in terms of war and peace and morality.

headline: Accounts
abstract: LEAD: * Warnaco to Wells, Rich, Greene for Valentino Intimo intimate apparel.

headline: BUSINESS DIGEST: TUESDAY, FEBRUARY 2, 1988
abstract: LEAD:  Companies

headline: Careers; Some Advice On Securing Business Jobs
abstract: LEAD: LIKE advice to the lovelorn, helpful words for job losers and job seekers are widely available. Now an economist and a forecaster offer some advice for middle managers who have lost their jobs and for people with new M.B.A. degrees who are looking for their first jobs.

headline: Seoul Threatens North Korea After Confession on Jet Bomb
abstract: LEAD: South Korean officials threatened today to retaliate against North Korea for the bombing of a Korean Air Lines plane in which 115 people died in November.

headline: Bass Group Trims Stake in Church's
abstract: LEAD: An investment group led by members of the Bass family of Texas has lowered its stake in Church's Fried Chicken Inc. to 2.7 percent, from 8.2 percent. In a Securities and Exchange Commission filing, the Bass group gave no reason for the sale.

headline: Brazil's Reversal of Debt Strategy
abstract: LEAD: When a slump in hard currency reserves forced Brazil to suspend most payments on its $113 billion foreign debt last February, the Government felt confident that the moratorium would serve as a weapon for extracting a dramatically better deal from its creditors.

headline: Canadian Bank Examines Loss
abstract: LEAD: The National Bank of Canada, the nation's sixth-largest bank, said today that it was investigating unauthorized trades by a bond dealer in its New York office. The trades cost the bank $25 million in Canadian funds, it said, and the amount will be taken as a loss against its first-quarter earnings.

headline: Union Carbide Posts a Profit
abstract: LEAD: The Union Carbide Corporation yesterday reported fourth-quarter net income of $23 million, or 17 cents a share. In the period a year earlier, the giant chemical company reported a net loss of $495 million, reflecting an after-tax charge of $473 million from the company's repurchase of shares during a takeover battle with the GAF

headline: Jets for Northwest
abstract: LEAD: Northwest Airlines Inc. has agreed to buy three more B-757 aircraft from the Boeing Company for an undisclosed amount. Northwest, a subsidiary of NWA Inc., also said it had accelerated deliveries of two B-757's ordered previously. The aircraft are to be delivered in the second half of 1988. The aircraft will seat 184 passengers each and will expand Northwest's B-757 fleet to 33.

headline: U.N. Cuts Lebanon Relief
abstract: LEAD: Relief services for about 260,000 Palestinian refugees in Lebanon will be cut to the minimum because the kidnapping of two employees of the United Nations Relief and Works Agency have raised fears over staff safety, the agency said today. The two employees - Jan Stening, 44 years old, of Sweden, and William Jorgensen, 58, of Norway - were kidnapped Feb.

headline: Swallowing Hutton in 1,200 Bites
abstract: LEAD: THEY were taking turns at the microphone a few weeks ago in the auditorium of Shearson Lehman Brothers' data-processing center in downtown Manhattan. About 225 managers entrusted with carrying out the firm's merger with E. F. Hutton & Company lined up to give their weekly progress reports to Leonard V.

headline: An Uneasy Alliance in Smokestack U.S.A.
abstract: LEAD: THEY make motors here at the General Electric Company's aging plants on Taylor Street and on Broadway, and they want to keep making them. They like to say that they are the best motor makers in the world.

headline: Japan Insider Curbs Asked
abstract: LEAD: A Finance Ministry committee today approved a report calling for tougher laws against insider trading on Japan's stock markets, where traders say information about companies is frequently leaked to investors.

headline: Afghan Guerrillas Are Said to Clash
abstract: LEAD: At a time when Moscow has increasingly talked of an early withdrawal of its troops from Afghanistan, differences among the Afghan insurgent groups have worsened and led to new fighting among them on Afghan soil, according to guerrilla spokesmen and diplomats.

headline: Advertising; Chock Full o'Nuts Spot by TBWA
abstract: LEAD: New Yorkers may get plenty of Chock Full o'Nuts coffee, but of late they haven't been getting much Chock Full o'Nuts advertising. And those of you who remember the advertising are probably glad.

headline: Amiens Journal; On the Far Right Is Le Pen, Talking of the Deluge
abstract: LEAD: Like the stand-up comic he sometimes resembles, Jean-Marie Le Pen, attired in a double-breasted blue blazer and gray slacks, strode the stage, a microphone pinned to his lapel. For two hours, without notes, he announced the apocalypse that awaits France if it does not reverse an ''invasion'' of third-world immigrants.

headline: Profit Scoreboard

headline: Times Mirror Swaps Cable Units
abstract: LEAD: The Times Mirror Company reached an agreement with a partnership of Tele-Communications Inc. and United Artists Communications Inc. to swap cable televison systems in several states. No value on the deal was announced, but analysts estimated it would be worth about $740 million, based on an average price of $2,000 per subscriber.

headline: A.T.&T. Plant Will Be Closed
abstract: LEAD: The American Telephone and Telegraph Company said today that it would close a manufacturing plant employing 3,300 workers in this central North Carolina city, where it has had operations for more than 40 years. The factory - part of

headline: Non-Seabrook Assets Sought
abstract: LEAD: A second New England utility has begun talks with the Public Service Company of New Hampshire, which was driven to file under Chapter 11 of the Federal Bankruptcy Code by its investment in the Seabrook nuclear plant, for the possible purchase of the company's non-Seabrook assets.

headline: Poles Said Ready to Admit Error In Purging Jews From Party in 60's
abstract: LEAD: Poland will soon acknowledge ''political error'' in 1967-68, when thousands of Jews were purged from the Communist Party, according to a scholar who said he was conveying a message from the Polish leader.

headline: Town Hall Democracy Urged for China
abstract: LEAD: Zhao Ziyang, in his first major elaboration on China's political future since his formal appointment as Communist Party chief last November, has called for the development of a type of town hall democracy throughout the country.

headline: Rumania Rejects U.S. Trade Benefits Over Human Rights Dispute
abstract: LEAD: Apparently rebuffing American demands for improvement in human rights policies, Rumania has told the United States it no longer wants the trade benefits that Washington links to such policies, the State Department announced today.

headline: P.L.O. Is Said to Delay on Government in Exile
abstract: LEAD: Faced with internal dissent, the Palestine Liberation Organization has put off an immediate decision on whether to set up a government in exile, according to Western and Arab diplomats here.

headline: Soviet Armenians Mourn Their Dead
abstract: LEAD: Tens of thousands of Armenians held a silent march and vigil in the Armenian capital of Yerevan this afternoon in memory of those slain in the recent rampages in the neighboring republic of Azerbaijan, according to Armenians and Westerners who were present.

headline: Robins Seeks Support for Merger
abstract: LEAD: The A. H. Robins Company, which has operated under a bankruptcy court's protection since August 1985, yesterday began an uphill battle to win support for a plan to clear its debts and reorganize itself as a subsidiary of Sanofi, a big French drug company.

headline: U.S. Aide Urged Panama General To Yield Control, Diplomats Say
abstract: LEAD: A senior Defense Department official made a secret trip to Panama last week to urge the country's military leader, Gen. Manuel Antonio Noriega, to withdraw from politics and allow an elected civilian government to take power, State Department and senior Latin American diplomats said Thursday night.

headline: Senate Committee Bars Abrams From Session
abstract: LEAD: Elliott Abrams, the Assistant Secretary of State for Inter-American Affairs, was barred today by the Senate Foreign Relations Committee from appearing at a closed briefing for members on the fighting along the Honduran border.

headline: International Trade Official Resigns at Commerce Dept.
abstract: LEAD: S. Bruce Smart Jr. resigned today as the Commerce Department's top international trade official.

headline: A Nonwhite Gets a Finger on the Levers of Power
abstract: LEAD: Of all the South African political figures likely to pose serious problems for President P. W. Botha, the Rev. Allan Hendrickse has never figured very prominently.

headline: South Africa's Economy Faces an Unsteady Future
abstract: LEAD: ALONG the undulating highway that leads southwest from this city, a traveler passes through countryside made lush by summer rains. It is a place of farms and fruit stalls, but on the hillsides back from the road stand the sentinels of a harsher world - the towers of concrete and steel atop South Africa's richest gold field.

headline: Advertising; Ketchum Will Phase In Executive Realignment
abstract: LEAD: Ketchum Communications, Pittsburgh, has announced an executive realignment to be accomplished during a year-long transition period. Edward L. Graf, 49, now executive vice president, will become vice chairman and remain chief financial officer. Herbert D. Gordon, 49, president of Ketchum Yellow Pages, will become executive vice president.

headline: South Africa's Liberals: Divided and Dropping Out
abstract: LEAD: South African liberals are more divided than ever about their future.

headline: Afghan Siege Over, Troops Still Duck
abstract: LEAD: Three weeks after Soviet and Afghan forces broke the prolonged siege of this dusty garrison town near the Pakistani border, Government control seems precarious.

headline: Steel Group Seeks Renewed Quotas
abstract: LEAD: President Reagan's program of voluntarily restraining steel imports has been a success and a decision to renew it should be made promptly, the steel industry said in a statement today.

headline: White House Berates the Foes of Contra Aid
abstract: LEAD: The White House attacked Congressional opponents of renewed aid to the contras today, saying their criticisms of the Administration's Central America policy were ''outrageous'' and tantamount to ''surrender.''

headline: Components Expected For I.B.M. PS/2 Clones
abstract: LEAD: A group of small computer companies will announce Wednesday that they have succeeded in making chips and software that will allow computers to be built that are compatible with the new PS/2 line of personal computers from the International Business Machines Corporation.

headline: The U.N. Today
abstract: LEAD:  General Assembly  CONVENTION ON ELIMINATION OF RACIAL DISCRIMINATION - 10:30 A.M. and 3:00 P.M.

headline: Tandon in Pact On Holders' Suits
abstract: LEAD: The Tandon Corporation, a disk drive maker in Chatsworth, Calif., said it had agreed in principle to the settlement of class action suits filed last July by shareholders charging Tandon had violated Federal securities and state laws in statements and public reports made in 1983 and 1984.

headline: Bulgaria Planning Value Tax
abstract: LEAD: Bulgaria plans to introduce a Western-style value-added tax to accompany major increases in prices, a leading Communist Party official said today. But the official, Emil Christov, a Central Committee Secretary, promised that wages would keep pace with the price rises.

headline: Iraqi Missile Attacks on Iran: A New Twist to the Old War
abstract: LEAD: Iran and Iraq bombarded each other's capitals with missiles today, continuing a dramatic escalation of attacks on cities.

headline: Pakistan Tied to Atom Shipping Plot
abstract: LEAD: The State Department was reported today to have sent a memorandum to President Reagan concluding that the Pakistani Government was probably involved in a plot by a Pakistani-born businessman to smuggle material for nuclear weapons out of the United States.

headline: Relief Convoy Ambushed
abstract: LEAD: Rebels ambushed a convoy in northern Ethiopia last Friday and burned seven trucks carrying food for famine victims, relief officials said today. Guerrillas of the Eritrean People's Liberation Front attacked a column of trucks on the road from the port of Massawa to Asmara, the capital of Eritrea Province, the officials said.

headline: Northrop Delays Test Of Stealth Bomber
abstract: LEAD: The top-secret Stealth bomber being built by the Northrop Corporation, which is already believed to be hampered by problems that have brought more than $200 million in write-offs, is now experiencing new delays and management problems.

headline: Optical Sets $13 Payment
abstract: LEAD: SAN FRANCISCO, Jan. 5 -

headline: A Tough Battle In Orange Juice
abstract: LEAD: One beverage business in which the Coca-Cola Company is being bruised is orange juice.

headline: Pretoria May Ban Foreign Funds for Rights Groups
abstract: LEAD: The South African Government continued its nationwide crackdown on anti-apartheid groups today by proposing legislation to block foreign financing of political groups and individuals.

headline: About Real Estate; A Middle-Income Project in Bayswater
abstract: LEAD: When the Trust for Public Land received a gift of 13.5 acres in the Bayswater section of the Rockaways in 1983, the nonprofit group, which seeks to preserve land for the public's use, hoped the city would buy the property for parkland. The city was not interested, however.

headline: Airlines: Labor Agreements Are Key For Carriers
abstract: LEAD: Lower fuel prices, fewer discounts, more modest additions of new planes, continuing good traffic. All portend a good year for the airlines. The wild card is labor settlements.

headline: Metromedia Chief Raises Orion Stake
abstract: LEAD: John W. Kluge, chairman and president of the Metromedia Company, has once again raised his stake in the Orion Pictures Corporation. In a filing with the Securities and Exchange Commission, Mr. Kluge said that he had increased his Orion stake to 25.6 percent, from 24 percent, through open market purchases of 283,000 Orion shares between Jan.

headline: BRIEFS
abstract: LEAD: Debt

headline: Chile's Inflation Rate
abstract: LEAD: Chile's cost of living rose by three-tenths of 1 percent in December, bringing the increase for the year to 21.5 percent, the Government reported on Tuesday.

headline: Why New Issues Usually Disappoint
abstract: LEAD: FEW investors who bought new stock offerings from companies in 1987 will look back with pleasure. The frothy pre-October market enabled Wall Street's underwriters to sell a record volume of initial public offerings - $24.2 billion worth, up 8 percent from a year earlier, according to Going Public, a service that tracks the new-issue market.

headline: Market Place; Analysts' View Of Oil Companies
abstract: LEAD: SELECTIVE ''buy'' recommendations for oil stocks, which have enjoyed a mini-rally in recent months, are the order of the day on Wall Street. Analysts attribute part of this group's improvement to the expectation that crude oil prices will climb during the second half of 1988.

headline: BANKRUPTCY FILED BY LEADING UTILITY IN SEABROOK PLANT
abstract: LEAD: Beleaguered by the controversy surrounding the Seabrook nuclear power plant, the Public Service Company of New Hampshire filed for bankruptcy protection yesterday, the first major public utility to take that step since the Depression.

headline: China's Money Supply
abstract: LEAD: China's central bank announced plans today to reduce the money supply to help curb inflation, which rose above 7 percent last year.

headline: American Cold Shoulder for Belfast School
abstract: LEAD: There is indeed an unsensational, nonviolent story to be told about the troubled Irish of Belfast. It is about a fragile integrated school started by Protestant and Roman Catholic parents sick of what the sectarian divide has done to the minds of children.

headline: Macy Plans Legal Step In Bidding
abstract: LEAD: In an intensifying struggle to win Federated Department Stores Inc., R. H. Macy & Company is expected to contest the legality of the Campeau Corporation's latest tender offer for the giant retailer.

headline: Manila Defense Chief Quits And Ramos Is Named to Job
abstract: LEAD: President Corazon C. Aquino accepted the protest resignation of Defense Secretary Rafael M. Ileto today and said she would nominate the armed forces Chief of Staff, Gen. Fidel V. Ramos, to replace him.

headline: Tool Orders Jumped 23.7% In January
abstract: LEAD: Bolstered by increased exports and Federal policies requiring some Government agencies to buy more domestic products, orders in January for American-made machine tools rose 23.7 percent from December's level, the industry's trade association said.

headline: Savings Group to Get L.F. Rothschild
abstract: LEAD: In its third venture into investment banking in the last 15 months, the Franklin Savings Corporation, of Ottawa, Kan., agreed yesterday to buy L. F. Rothschild Holdings Inc., the financially troubled 89-year-old investment house.

headline: Small Synthetic Spheres That Can Improve a Kiss
abstract: LEAD: IMAGINE a lipstick that moisturized every time a woman puckered up or kissed, or a foot powder that provided more antifungal relief with every step. These are two of many applications now possible with microsponges, microscopic synthetic spheres that can be ''programmed'' to release cosmetic or pharmaceutical agents in response to pressure, time or temperature.

headline: Light Activity For Bond Sales
abstract: LEAD: Treasury financings this week consist of today's regular weekly sale of new three-month and six-month bills, followed on Wednesday by an auction of seven-year notes.

headline: Who Killed Palme? Doggedly, the Hunt Goes On
abstract: LEAD: By now, the 22-month-old hunt for the killer of Prime Minister Olof Palme has become a workaday job.

headline: Black vs. Black in South Africa
abstract: LEAD: High in the hillside cemetery of Sinathingi, his name on a roughhewn cross, lies the freshly dug grave of Arron Mabuza. Nearby, in jumbled rows of still newer graves, lie at least three other blacks, perhaps as many as eight or nine, who were killed as they made their way to Mr. Mabuza's burial shortly before the New Year.

headline: Lisbon Journal; In Old Section of City, A Ghetto With a View
abstract: LEAD: The Alfama district is Lisbon's slum by the sea, along the banks of the Tagus River where it widens to enter the Atlantic.

headline: Economic Scene; Electoral Politics Dictates the Script
abstract: LEAD: FOR Americans traveling or residing abroad, the shrunken value of the dollar is felt not only as a strain on the pocketbook but as a personal insult. Feeling overcharged, overspent and over there, Americans ask: ''Is this what we're worth now - half what we were a few years ago?''

headline: Hopes Dim for Further Rate Cuts
abstract: LEAD: Hopes for lower interest rates were dealt a blow Friday when the Government announced stronger-than-expected employment data for December.

headline: A Puzzle at Border: Why the Pullback?
abstract: LEAD: Nicaraguan troops appear to be beginning to withdraw from Honduras even though they probably could have won an even more significant victory if they had destroyed contra positions inside Honduras, senior American officials said today.

headline: Talking Deals; Spirit of '92 Comes To Belgium Early
abstract: LEAD: WITH his bold bid for Societe Generale de Belgique - the holding company that is said to control a third of Belgian industry - Carlo de Benedetti, the Italian entrepreneur, seems to have moved far ahead of the crowd in building a European-wide business empire.

headline: Venezuela's Oil Dealings Abroad
abstract: LEAD: After Venezuela nationalized 14 American and other foreign oil companies in 1976, it came to recognize that much of the industry - the business of refining and marketing oil abroad - was in fact still in foreign hands.

headline: S.&S. Unit Has Fancy New Home
abstract: LEAD: WHEN the 1,350 employees of Saatchi & Saatchi DFS Compton show up for work next Tuesday after a long weekend, they may not have the Art Deco spire of the Chrysler Building towering majestically over their heads, but they will have a fully equipped health club and running track in their penthouse. Less for the soul, more for the body.
