headline: On Eve of the Peace Parley, Costa Rican Is Pessimistic
abstract: LEAD: Looking and sounding extremely somber, President Oscar Arias Sanchez said today that the meeting of Central American leaders here Friday will be a ''very difficult'' negotiating session with no guarantee of success.

headline: Brazil to Use Own Cash in Paying Debt
abstract: LEAD: In a move toward ending its year-long moratorium on debt repayment, Brazil said yesterday that it would pay $350 million today to banks around the world.

headline: A.L. Williams Sets Tie With Primerica
abstract: LEAD: The Primerica Corporation and the A. L. Williams Corporation said they had entered negotiations to create a new public company that will be known by the same name as the latter, A. L. Williams.

headline: T.W.A. Nominates 5 to Texaco Board
abstract: LEAD: Trans World Airlines Inc., which is controlled by Carl C. Icahn, said yesterday that it had nominated a slate of candidates to oppose the five Texaco directors up for re-election at the oil company's annual meeting in May.

headline: Advertising; Baltimore Agency Adds 2 Health Care Accounts
abstract: LEAD: Eisner & Associates, a 49-year-old Baltimore agency with $46 million in billings, is adding not only to its client list but also to its life expectancy with the acquisition of $2 million worth of health-related accounts.

headline: The U.N. Today
abstract: LEAD:  General Assembly  COMMISSION ON INTERNATIONAL TRADE LAW WORKING GROUP ON CONTRACT PRACTICES - 10:30 A.M. and 3 P.M.  SECURITY COUNCIL ON UNITED NATIONS INTERIM FORCE IN LEBANON - 11 A.M.  PREPARATORY COMMITTEE FOR SPECIAL SESSION OF ASSEMBLY DEVOTED TO DISARMAMENT - 11:30 A.M.

headline: OPEC Unity Called Crucial
abstract: LEAD: A prominent Arab oil expert, describing the oil market as ''very weak,'' warned today that the failure of members of the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries to abide by their output quotas could bring a collapse of oil prices.

headline: Greece Ceases Preparations To Upgrade Ties With Israel
abstract: LEAD: The Greek Government has suspended preparations to upgrade relations with Israel because of Israel's conduct with the Palestinians in the occupied territories, Prime Minister Andreas Papandreou said on Friday.

headline: Spending Lag Stirring Few Worries
abstract: LEAD: American consumers have been keeping a tighter grip on their wallets, but a close analysis of recent data and interviews with business people and consumers suggest there is little prospect that spending will fall far enough or long enough to end the nation's economic expansion, now in its sixth year.

headline: President of Forschner Adding Title of Chief
abstract: LEAD: James W. Kennedy has been an ace seller of Swiss Army knives, and for his reward he was named yesterday to the added post of chief executive of the Forschner Group, which distributes the leading brand of those knives in the United States.

headline: G.E. Files Suits Against Roper Pact
abstract: LEAD: Responding to a lawsuit by the Whirlpool Corporation, the General Electric Company yesterday filed two suits and formally announced its offer of $54 a share, or $507 million, for the Roper Corporation.

headline: As Arab Workers Stay Home, The Israeli Economy Suffers
abstract: LEAD: The past month of rioting in the occupied territories, which has kept thousands of Palestinians away from jobs in Israel, has been a bitter reminder to Israelis that the country's economy is largely dependent on its political foes.

headline: Batus Bid for Farmers Raised to $63 a Share
abstract: LEAD: Rebuffed in its first attempt to acquire Farmers Group Inc., Batus Inc. sweetened its tender offer today to $63 a share, or a total of about $4.5 billion, for the nation's seventh-largest insurance holding company. Batus's original offer was $60 a share.

headline: Hitachi to Expand
abstract: LEAD: Hitachi Ltd. said it would expand its semiconductor subsidiary here into a full-time production unit, which may employ 100 more workers. Hitachi Semiconductor America, which now employs 200 in an operation that handles computer chips imported from Japan, had suspended construction on its manufacturing plant here in October 1986 because of a slump in the semiconductor industry.

headline: Stocks Up by 7.79 in Quiet Trading
abstract: LEAD: Stock prices rose moderately yesterday in quiet holiday trading. The Dow Jones industrial average advanced 7.79 points, to 1,963.86, after rising by 39.96 points on Friday.

headline: BUSINESS DIGEST: WEDNESDAY, FEBRUARY 3, 1988
abstract: LEAD:  Markets

headline: Procter & Gamble Profit
abstract: LEAD: The Procter & Gamble Company, the giant consumer products concern, yesterday reported a 37 percent increase in its second-quarter profit. The company attributed the rise in large part to lowered tax rates. Procter & Gamble said that its earnings for the three months ended Dec. 31 totaled $261 million, or $1.52 a share, up from $190 million, or $1.11 a share, in the period a year ago.

headline: Real Estate; Vertical Plan Cuts Costs of Retail Space
abstract: LEAD: SHUNNED by retailers and office tenants, the cheapest space in most commercial buildings is to be found in the basement or on the second floor.

headline: MCI to Reduce Its Phone Rates
abstract: LEAD: The MCI Communications Corporation said it would reduce its long-distance telephone rates by about 3.5 percent on March 1, matching rate reductions announced earlier by the American Telephone and Telegraph Company.

headline: Tough Treatment For Tax Breaks
abstract: LEAD: Everyone is in favor of closing up loopholes in the tax law - a loophole, after all, is something the other guy is wriggling through to avoid taxes. And the Congressional tax writers did just that in the Tax Reform Act of 1986, tightening deductions and taxing income that was previously exempt. That was how they kept the law ''revenue neutral'' while lowering marginal tax rates.

headline: BUSINESS DIGEST: WEDNESDAY, FEBRUARY 10, 1988
abstract: LEAD:  Companies

headline: Reuters USA Account
abstract: LEAD: Doyle Graf Mabley has become agency for the Reuters USA Media Group, which sells the British news agency's services to newspapers, broadcasters and magazines. The billings could go as high as $1 million. The previous agency was Poppe Tyson.

headline: BUSINESS DIGEST: WEDNESDAY, FEBRUARY 24, 1988
abstract: LEAD:  Companies

headline: Third Investor Seeks Sizable Texaco Stake
abstract: LEAD: A third investor has announced plans to buy a stake in Texaco Inc.

headline: Cooper Lasersonics
abstract: LEAD: Cooper Lasersonics Inc. said that because of the difficulty it had encountered in turning around its laser business, it was no longer considering a spinoff of the business. Cooper had said in June that it would spin off the business as a separate public company by this month. The company said it was considering other divestitures to maximize shareholder values.

headline: U.N. Unit to Visit Nicaragua To Look Into Border Dispute
abstract: LEAD: A United Nations team will visit Nicaragua as soon as possible to investigate the border conflict with Honduras, a United Nations spokesman said today.

headline: Interpublic Profit Up
abstract: LEAD: The Interpublic Group - which comprises McCann-Erickson Worldwide; Lintas: Worldwide; Dailey & Associates, and interests in Lowe Marschalk and other companies -announced that fourth-quarter earnings rose 28 percent, to $18.7 million, or 86 cents a share, from $14.6 million, or 67 cents a share, a year earlier.

headline: Dubcek Sees a Link With Gorbachev Effort
abstract: LEAD: Alexander Dubcek, the Czechoslovak leader ousted by Soviet-led troops in 1968, sees a ''profound connection'' between the changes he tried to initiate 20 years ago and those now being undertaken by the Soviet leader, according to a rare interview to be published here Sunday.

headline: Money Fund Assets Off
abstract: LEAD: Assets of the nation's 422 money market mutual funds decreased by $730.4 million, to $278.78 billion, for the week ended Wednesday, the Investment Company Institute said yesterday. Assets of the 114 institutional funds decreased by $1.22 billion, to $78.89 billion. Assets of the 210 general-purpose funds were up $226.2 million, to $82.23 billion.

headline: Bank Officer To Join Mellon
abstract: LEAD: David L. Eyles, chief credit officer for the Chemical Bank, is leaving to become a vice chairman of the Mellon Bank Corporation in Pittsburgh, Mellon announced Friday. Mr. Eyles, 48 years old, will also be chairman of Mellon's credit policy committee and the senior credit committee. Chemical, a subsidiary of the

headline: Retail Sales Higher for December
abstract: LEAD: December sales at the nation's top retailers were generally, in some cases surprisingly, improved over the figures from December 1986.

headline: Economic Calendar
abstract: LEAD:  Listed below are the target release dates for major economic indicators scheduled to be released this week.  Monday

headline: Gene Deal for Beckman
abstract: LEAD: Beckman Instruments Inc. has signed an agreement with British Bio-technology Ltd. to distribute the British company's line of synthetic genes. The synthetic genes, sold under the trademark Designer Genes, produce proteins used in research, the company said. Until now, researchers have had to grow their own genes for medical research.

headline: Curbing Raiders Is Bad for Business
abstract: LEAD: Congressional action to preserve a free market is now more necessary than ever, since Delaware, the nation's second-smallest state, adopted legislation to sharply restrict contested mergers. The measure, signed by Delaware's Governor last week, will affect companies around the country.

headline: Patents; Optical-Cable Link
abstract: LEAD: Gordon Gould of Kinsale, Va., a physicist who has been called ''the father of the laser,'' was awarded a patent this week in a different field. Patent 4,721,355, assigned to the Chevron Research Company of San Francisco, a division of the Chevron Corporation, covers an optical-cable connector assembly link used in logging oil wells.

headline: Palestinian Gets 30 Years for Rome Airport Attack
abstract: LEAD: A confessed Palestinian gunman was convicted and sentenced to a 30-year prison term today for his part in the Rome airport attack in 1985 in which 16 people died. Two other defendants, including the Palestinian guerrilla leader known as Abu Nidal, were sentenced in absentia to life imprisonment for organizing the attack.

headline: As Truce Chances Developed, Contras Built Private Channel to Democrats
abstract: LEAD: In the weeks leading to the cease-fire agreement between the contras and the Nicaraguan Government, rebel leaders defied the Reagan Administration and opened a private channel of communication with the Speaker of the House, Jim Wright, and a handful of Democrats.

headline: Big Victory for Owners Of Hyde Park Holdings
abstract: LEAD: Two 1983 business school graduates successfully completed their first big tender offer yesterday.

headline: U.S. Faults Bahamas on Drug Effort
abstract: LEAD: Despite excellent official cooperation between the United States and the Bahamas on drug enforcement efforts, narcotics-related corruption remains a ''serious problem'' in the Bahamas, a senior State Department official said today.

headline: ISRAEL PUTS ARMY ON STREET PATROL TO PREVENT RIOTS
abstract: LEAD: The Israeli Army put hundreds of heavily armed troops onto the streets of Gaza, Jerusalem and the West Bank today, blocking Palestinian efforts to commemorate the 23d anniversary of Yasir Arafat's first military operation against Israel.

headline: Sihanouk Will Meet A Coalition Partner Before Peace Talks
abstract: LEAD: Prince Norodom Sihanouk and Son Sann, the leaders of the two non-Communist forces battling the Vietnamese-backed Government in Cambodia, are planning to meet in Paris on Monday, Mr. Son Sann said today.

headline: Market Place; Japanese Stocks Build Momentum
abstract: LEAD: STOCK prices in Japan, bolstered by domestic buying demand, have climbed to their highest levels since the Oct. 19 crash on Wall Street. And numerous Japanese issues that trade here as American depository shares are posting solid gains on the New York Stock Exchange in response to the higher prices in

headline: Pacific Gas Ends Offer
abstract: LEAD: The Pacific Gas and Electric Company said it was withdrawing its proposal to consolidate its gas service in the Sacramento, Calif., area with the electricity operations of the Sacramento Municipal Utility District. P.G.&E., which had proposed in September to take over the struggling utility and scrap its nonfunctioning nuclear power plant, said it was dropping the offer because of the Sacramento utility's failure to give it serious consideration.

headline: Colombia Convoy Ambushed
abstract: LEAD: Eight soldiers and a civilian were killed and 13 people were wounded on Tuesday during an ambush by left-wing guerrillas in the northern part of the country, a spokesman for the military said today. In the Atlantic province of Cordoba, Alfonso Cujavanta, the regional leader of the leftist Patrotic Union, became the first newly elected official to be assassinated.

headline: An Iraqi Missile Hits Teheran
abstract: LEAD: Iraq fired a missile at Teheran today and Iran vowed to retaliate, raising fears of a resumption of attacks on each other's cities after a two-day truce.

headline: New Chairman of C.F.T.C. Opposes Margin Increases
abstract: LEAD: The new chairman of the Commodity Futures Trading Commission took issue today with another key Federal regulator over whether margin, or down payment, requirements on stock-index futures need to be increased.

headline: Why New Delhi's Plans Just Don't Work
abstract: LEAD: Declaring population growth to be India's most serious problem, Prime Minister Rajiv Gandhi doubled expenditures for health and family planning services in the last two years. But the country's own experts say they have been disappointed by the results so far.

headline: HAITI'S NEIGHBORS OPPOSE SANCTIONS
abstract: LEAD: Leaders of seven Caribbean nations accused Haiti's military-led junta today of violating democratic principles, but after a day of talks they refused to impose diplomatic or economic sanctions.

headline: Whether Swings Will Continue Is Uncertain
abstract: LEAD: Although the stock market ended the year at about where it began, the last 12 months will go down as the most chaotic since World War II.

headline: Floating Point Names Chief
abstract: LEAD: Floating Point Systems Inc., the troubled maker of scientific computer systems based in Beaverton, Ore., has named Howard Thrailkill president, chief executive and a director. He succeeds Milton R. Smith, a co-founder who was appointed interim chief executive 15 months ago and who will continue as a board member.

headline: BRIEFS
abstract: LEAD: * Allied-Signal Aerospace Co., Morristown, N.J., a unit of Allied-Signal Inc., said it had completed the consolidation of its Bendix and Garrett units and would sell three divisions with combined annual sales of $200 million to sharpen its focus as a major supplier of aircraft systems.

headline: Italian Seeks New Support Special to The New York Times
abstract: LEAD: Carlo deBenedetti disclosed today that two of Europe's biggest industrial enterprises, N.V. Philips of the Netherlands and Nestle S.A. of Switzerland, were negotiating to join the Italian entrepreneur in his battle for control of Societe Generale de Belgique.

headline: ARGENTINA STILL CAN'T CARRY DEBTS
abstract: LEAD: Although a recent round of negotiations in Washington produced $550 million in new financing for Argentina, economic officials here say a major crisis in servicing the country's $54 billion foreign debt is still looming.

headline: Advertising; Visa Aims At American Express
abstract: LEAD: LIKE the cola and beer wars, credit card marketing has never been a gentle business. Consider the current Visa International campaign, which is tied to the Winter Olympics and takes dead aim at American Express.

headline: Humbler G.M. Is Now Listening
abstract: LEAD: For decades, executives of the General Motors Corporation decided among themselves what kind of cars Americans wanted. Now, with its market share down sharply executives at G.M. appear to be trying to find out what customers want.

headline: A Tax Worry Adds To Texaco's Burdens
abstract: LEAD: Texaco might face a $6.5 billion bill for back taxes relating to the pricing of Saudi Arabian oil from 1979 to 1981. The Internal Revenue Service would not comment, but Texaco said it was possible such a claim would be filed in the company's bankruptcy proceedings. Texaco's effort to get out of bankruptcy was already facing enormous expenses, principally a $3 billion payment to Pennzoil to settle their celebrated legal dispute.

headline: Malaysian Politician Freed
abstract: LEAD: A regional court today freed a leading opposition politician who had been imprisoned without trial since Oct. 27. The politician, Karpal Singh, was released in Ipoh, 120 miles north of Kuala Lumpur, after he won a lawsuit charging wrongful arrest. Mr. Karpal is a member of Parliament and the Vice President of the opposition Democratic Action Party.

abstract: LEAD:  Security Council  Meets at 11:30 A.M. on the situation in occupied territories.  General Assembly  PREPARATORY COMMITTEE FOR SPECIAL SESSION OF ASSEMBLY DEVOTED TO DISARMAMENT - 10 A.M. and 3 P.M  COMMITTEE ON DRAFTING CONVENTION AGAINST RECRUITMENT, USE, FINANCING AND TRAINING OF MERCENARIES - 10:30 A.M.

headline: Chip Indicator Is Up Again
abstract: LEAD: The semiconductor industry's leading indicator continued to improve in February, as chip makers based in the United States, Europe and Japan reported their third consecutive month with more than $1 billion in orders, a trade group reported today. The Semiconductor Industry

headline: Mexico City Journal; Season of Smog in 'Makesicko City'
abstract: LEAD: To a large extent, the 20 million people in the world's largest metropolis have reluctantly adapted to living with the pollution that fouls the air here.

headline: Pirelli Cancels Loan Facility For Aborted Firestone Bid
abstract: LEAD: Pirelli S.p.A. has canceled the $2.3 billion loan facility that it had arranged to finance an acquisition of the Firestone Tire and Rubber Company, the Swiss Bank Corporation International said today. Pirelli's effort to buy Firestone has been abandoned.

headline: Japanese Unemployment
abstract: LEAD: Unemployment in Japan fell to a seasonally adjusted 2.7 percent in January from 3 percent a year earlier, but it was up one-tenth percentage point from the previous month, the Government said today. The number of job holders rose in the 12-month period by 1.12 million, or 1.9 percent, to 58.28 million.

headline: Iraq Attacks Iran Oil Terminal
abstract: LEAD: Waves of Iraqi planes pounded Iran's biggest oil terminal today, leaving at least two tankers ablaze in the northern Persian Gulf. Iran said it shot down three Iraqi planes.

headline: Court Allows Photo Merger
abstract: LEAD: A merger between the Eastman Kodak Company and the Colorcraft Corporation is not an effort to force other companies out of the photo-finishing industry, the United States Court of Appeals for the Fifth Circuit ruled today.

headline: Small Movements for Bond Yields
abstract: LEAD: While economic statistics have moved from signs of strength to weakness like a playground seesaw, investors and traders have been content to stand by idly and watch bond yields move in a very narrow range.

headline: Crazy Eddie Reports a Loss
abstract: LEAD: Crazy Eddie Inc., a financially troubled retailer of electronics products, said yesterday that it had lost $73 million in its third quarter that ended Nov. 29. In the quarter a year earlier, Crazy Eddie posted net income of $3.7 million.

headline: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
abstract: LEAD: * ABB Composites Inc., Irvine, Calif., an Asea Brown Boveri subsidiary that makes fiber-reinforced plastic products, appointed Rolf R. Berglund president.

headline: Militants Encouraged
abstract: LEAD: Palestinian hardliners see the protests in the West Bank and Gaza as a new opportunity to regain lost influence. Page 18.

headline: Bill in House Would Limit Banks' Underwriting Power
abstract: LEAD: The chairman of the House Banking Committee today released a draft of his proposed legislation that would give the nation's banks only modest new securities underwriting powers. The proposal contrasts sharply with a bill in the Senate that would give broad new powers to banks.

headline: First Boston Sets Pact on Jewelcor
abstract: LEAD: A group led by Jewelcor Inc.'s president, Seymour Holtzman, has agreed to work with First Boston LBO Inc., a unit of the First Boston Corporation, on a plan to acquire Jewelcor. The group led by Mr. Holtzman, which holds or has options to buy 26.3 percent of Jewelcor's common stock, disclosed the agreement in a Securities and Exchange

headline: Utility Officer Will Resign
abstract: LEAD: Charles M. Heidel said today that he would resign as president and chief operating officer of the Detroit Edison Company.

headline: Cineplex Film Deal
abstract: LEAD: The Cineplex Odeon Corporation said it had formed a joint venture with the New Century Entertainment Corporation to finance and distribute 25 to 30 New Century films in the next five years. The venture follows an agreement last week by which New Century acquired the independent film maker New Visions Inc.

headline: Bank-Failure Causes Cited
abstract: LEAD: A study of bank failures from 1979 to 1987 shows that although troubled regional economies had an obvious impact, much of the blame had to be placed on poor managers, the Comptroller of the Currency, Robert L. Clarke, said today.

headline: Swedes Expel Palestinians
abstract: LEAD: Four Palestinians who had sought political asylum in Sweden were ordered expelled today for undisclosed security reasons, Erik Lempert, a senior official of the Labor Ministry, said. The order was issued after Prime Minister Ingvar Carlsson's Government met in a special session to consider their appeal against a ruling by police and immigration authorities that they leave the country, he said.

headline: BUSINESS DIGEST: SATURDAY, FEBRUARY 6, 1988
abstract: LEAD:  Markets

headline: G.S.A., Citing Report, May Fight A.T.&T. Bids
abstract: LEAD: The General Services Administration said today that, if the American Telephone and Telegraph Company received secret bid prices of its competitors for Federal Government telephone switch contracts, as said in a news report, it would seek to prevent the company from gaining the contracts.

headline: Computer's Sale Studied
abstract: LEAD: The Reagan Administration confirmed today that it was investigating accusations that a United States computer system that could help determine optimal targets for nuclear missiles had been illegally shipped to the Soviet Union.

headline: Factory Use Rate Unchanged
abstract: LEAD: The nation's factories, mines and utilities operated at 82.4 percent of capacity in February, the third consecutive month at that level, the Federal Reserve reported today.

headline: A Car Bomb Is Found in Spain Near Gibraltar
abstract: LEAD: The Spanish police found an explosives-laden car Tuesday that was thought to be linked to three members of the Irish Republican Army who were shot dead in Gibraltar by British commandos, officials said.

headline: The Incredible I.R.A. Withdrawal Game
abstract: LEAD: THE Internal Revenue Service has an April Fool's gift for some taxpayers: new rules dictating how much must be withdrawn from individual retirement accounts by April 1 to avoid a stiff penalty.

headline: Oil Contracts Rise Modestly After 'Squeeze' In London
abstract: LEAD: Crude oil futures posted modest gains yesterday on carry-over buying from Monday, when prices of all energy contracts soared on reports of a ''squeeze'' in London's cash market for North Sea Brent grade oil.

headline: New York Area Costs in '87 Up 5.9%
abstract: LEAD: Consumer prices for the New York-northeastern New Jersey area rose slightly in December, ending 1987 on a ''welcome quiet note'' after a 12-month increase of 5.9 percent, the largest in six years, Samuel M. Ehrenhalt, regional commissioner of labor statistics, said yesterday.

headline: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
abstract: LEAD: Angeles Corp., Los Angeles, a holding company involved in investment programs, said Edward J. Hall had joined the company as executive vice president and chief financial officer.

headline: Army Unit Taps Open Secrets of Soviet
abstract: LEAD: For two years, the Army has been operating a small research unit with an unusual mission - delving into the inner workings of Soviet military power by relying solely on publicly available sources.

headline: Late Rally Sends Dow Up by 16.91
abstract: LEAD: A late rally spurred an otherwise dreary stock market to a strong gain yesterday. The Dow Jones industrial average, down much of the session, closed at 2,064.32, up 16.91 points.

headline: Webb to Sell Gaming Unit
abstract: LEAD: In a long-expected restructuring, the Del E. Webb Corporation said today that it would quit the gaming business this year and sell its three hotel-casinos, which analysts said could raise about $160 million.

headline: Chevron Buys PPG Unit
abstract: LEAD: PPG Industries said Friday it had agreed to sell its commercial biochemical business to the Chevron Chemical Company, a subsidiary of the Chevron Corporation. The terms were not disclosed.

headline: KEY RATES
abstract: LEAD:               Previous   Year     In percent   Yesterday   Day   Ago              PRIME RATE   8.50   8.50   7.50        DISCOUNT RATE   6.00   6.00   5.50        FEDERAL FUNDS   5.58   6.68   6.33        3-MO. headline: Big Navy Contract
abstract: LEAD: The Navy awarded a $4.38 billion contract to the General Dynamics Corporation and the McDonnell Douglas Corporation to develop its new Advanced Tactical Aircraft for delivery in the 1990's. The joint program, one of the largest ever undertaken by the Navy, is expected to produce 450 attack aircraft, at an eventual cost of $45 billion, to replace the service's current A-6 attack planes.

headline: West Berlin Links Woman Sought In Disco Bombing to Palestinians
abstract: LEAD: The police suspect that a West Berlin woman working for Palestinian terrorists planted the bomb that killed two American soldiers and a Turkish woman and wounded 229 people in a West Berlin discotheque in April 1986, the authorities said today.

headline: Article 741588 -- No Title
abstract: LEAD: Hoffmann-La Roche & Company, the big Swiss drug producer, said last night that it was offering $4.2 billion in cash for Sterling Drug Inc., makers of Bayer aspirin, Phillips Milk of Magnesia and dozens of other pharmaceutical products.

headline: Rail Workers Strike in Brazil
abstract: LEAD: Brazilian rail workers began their first national strike today to press for pay increases of 60 to 80 percent, union leaders said. Antonio Araujo do Valle, president of the Rio de Janeiro rail workers' union and a member of the national strike command, said all 85,000 workers were on strike.

headline: 10 ARABS WOUNDED BY ISRAELI GUNFIRE
abstract: LEAD: The Israeli Army opened fire today on Palestinian demonstrators in the occupied West Bank and Gaza Strip, wounding at least 10 people.

headline: Soviet Reports an Arms Buildup by Afghan Rebels
abstract: LEAD: The Soviet Union charged today that Afghan insurgents are moving large quantities of arms and ammunition into Afghanistan in the midst of negotiations seeking an end to the country's civil war.
